 Static Protected Attributes inherited from matplotlib.axes._base._AxesBase
tuple _axis_names = ("x", "y")
 
dict _shared_axes = {name: cbook.Grouper() for name in _axis_names}
 
 _twinned_axes = cbook.Grouper()
 
bool _subclass_uses_cla = False
 

Detailed Description

The `Axes` contains most of the figure elements: `~.axis.Axis`,
`~.axis.Tick`, `~.lines.Line2D`, `~.text.Text`, `~.patches.Polygon`, etc.,
and sets the coordinate system.

The `Axes` instance supports callbacks through a callbacks attribute which
is a `~.cbook.CallbackRegistry` instance.  The events you can connect to
are 'xlim_changed' and 'ylim_changed' and the callback will be called with
func(*ax*) where *ax* is the `Axes` instance.

Attributes
----------
dataLim : `.Bbox`
    The bounding box enclosing all data displayed in the Axes.
viewLim : `.Bbox`
    The view limits in data coordinates.

Member Function Documentation

◆ _check_no_units()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._check_no_units (   vals,
  names 
)
staticprotected
836 def _check_no_units(vals, names):
837 # Helper method to check that vals are not unitized
838 for val, name in zip(vals, names):
839 if not munits._is_natively_supported(val):
840 raise ValueError(f"{name} must be a single scalar value, "
841 f"but got {val}")
842

◆ _convert_dx()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._convert_dx (   dx,
  x0,
  xconv,
  convert 
)
staticprotected 
Small helper to do logic of width conversion flexibly.

*dx* and *x0* have units, but *xconv* has already been converted
to unitless (and is an ndarray).  This allows the *dx* to have units
that are different from *x0*, but are still accepted by the
``__add__`` operator of *x0*.
2153 def _convert_dx(dx, x0, xconv, convert):
2154 """
2155 Small helper to do logic of width conversion flexibly.
2156
2157 *dx* and *x0* have units, but *xconv* has already been converted
2158 to unitless (and is an ndarray). This allows the *dx* to have units
2159 that are different from *x0*, but are still accepted by the
2160 ``__add__`` operator of *x0*.
2161 """
2162
2163 # x should be an array...
2164 assert type(xconv) is np.ndarray
2165
2166 if xconv.size == 0:
2167 # xconv has already been converted, but maybe empty...
2168 return convert(dx)
2169
2170 try:
2171 # attempt to add the width to x0; this works for
2172 # datetime+timedelta, for instance
2173
2174 # only use the first element of x and x0. This saves
2175 # having to be sure addition works across the whole
2176 # vector. This is particularly an issue if
2177 # x0 and dx are lists so x0 + dx just concatenates the lists.
2178 # We can't just cast x0 and dx to numpy arrays because that
2179 # removes the units from unit packages like `pint` that
2180 # wrap numpy arrays.
2181 try:
2182 x0 = cbook._safe_first_finite(x0)
2183 except (TypeError, IndexError, KeyError):
2184 pass
2185 except StopIteration:
2186 # this means we found no finite element, fall back to first
2187 # element unconditionally
2188 x0 = cbook.safe_first_element(x0)
2189
2190 try:
2191 x = cbook._safe_first_finite(xconv)
2192 except (TypeError, IndexError, KeyError):
2193 x = xconv
2194 except StopIteration:
2195 # this means we found no finite element, fall back to first
2196 # element unconditionally
2197 x = cbook.safe_first_element(xconv)
2198
2199 delist = False
2200 if not np.iterable(dx):
2201 dx = [dx]
2202 delist = True
2203 dx = [convert(x0 + ddx) - x for ddx in dx]
2204 if delist:
2205 dx = dx[0]
2206 except (ValueError, TypeError, AttributeError):
2207 # if the above fails (for any reason) just fallback to what
2208 # we do by default and convert dx by itself.
2209 dx = convert(dx)
2210 return dx
2211

◆ _errorevery_to_mask()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._errorevery_to_mask (   x,
  errorevery 
)
staticprotected 
Normalize `errorbar`'s *errorevery* to be a boolean mask for data *x*.

This function is split out to be usable both by 2D and 3D errorbars.
3270 def _errorevery_to_mask(x, errorevery):
3271 """
3272 Normalize `errorbar`'s *errorevery* to be a boolean mask for data *x*.
3273
3274 This function is split out to be usable both by 2D and 3D errorbars.
3275 """
3276 if isinstance(errorevery, Integral):
3277 errorevery = (0, errorevery)
3278 if isinstance(errorevery, tuple):
3279 if (len(errorevery) == 2 and
3280 isinstance(errorevery[0], Integral) and
3281 isinstance(errorevery[1], Integral)):
3282 errorevery = slice(errorevery[0], None, errorevery[1])
3283 else:
3284 raise ValueError(
3285 f'{errorevery=!r} is a not a tuple of two integers')
3286 elif isinstance(errorevery, slice):
3287 pass
3288 elif not isinstance(errorevery, str) and np.iterable(errorevery):
3289 try:
3290 x[errorevery] # fancy indexing
3291 except (ValueError, IndexError) as err:
3292 raise ValueError(
3293 f"{errorevery=!r} is iterable but not a valid NumPy fancy "
3294 "index to match 'xerr'/'yerr'") from err
3295 else:
3296 raise ValueError(f"{errorevery=!r} is not a recognized value")
3297 everymask = np.zeros(len(x), bool)
3298 everymask[errorevery] = True
3299 return everymask
3300

◆ _fill_between_x_or_y()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._fill_between_x_or_y (   self,
  ind_dir,
  ind,
  dep1,
  dep2 = 0,
*  where = None,
  interpolate = False,
  step = None,
**  kwargs 
)
protected 
Fill the area between two {dir} curves.

The curves are defined by the points (*{ind}*, *{dep}1*) and (*{ind}*,
*{dep}2*).  This creates one or multiple polygons describing the filled
area.

You may exclude some {dir} sections from filling using *where*.

By default, the edges connect the given points directly.  Use *step*
if the filling should be a step function, i.e. constant in between
*{ind}*.

Parameters
----------
{ind} : array (length N)
    The {ind} coordinates of the nodes defining the curves.

{dep}1 : array (length N) or scalar
    The {dep} coordinates of the nodes defining the first curve.

{dep}2 : array (length N) or scalar, default: 0
    The {dep} coordinates of the nodes defining the second curve.

where : array of bool (length N), optional
    Define *where* to exclude some {dir} regions from being filled.
    The filled regions are defined by the coordinates ``{ind}[where]``.
    More precisely, fill between ``{ind}[i]`` and ``{ind}[i+1]`` if
    ``where[i] and where[i+1]``.  Note that this definition implies
    that an isolated *True* value between two *False* values in *where*
    will not result in filling.  Both sides of the *True* position
    remain unfilled due to the adjacent *False* values.

interpolate : bool, default: False
    This option is only relevant if *where* is used and the two curves
    are crossing each other.

    Semantically, *where* is often used for *{dep}1* > *{dep}2* or
    similar.  By default, the nodes of the polygon defining the filled
    region will only be placed at the positions in the *{ind}* array.
    Such a polygon cannot describe the above semantics close to the
    intersection.  The {ind}-sections containing the intersection are
    simply clipped.

    Setting *interpolate* to *True* will calculate the actual
    intersection point and extend the filled region up to this point.

step : {{'pre', 'post', 'mid'}}, optional
    Define *step* if the filling should be a step function,
    i.e. constant in between *{ind}*.  The value determines where the
    step will occur:

    - 'pre': The y value is continued constantly to the left from
      every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``(x[i-1], x[i]]`` has the
      value ``y[i]``.
    - 'post': The y value is continued constantly to the right from
      every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``[x[i], x[i+1])`` has the
      value ``y[i]``.
    - 'mid': Steps occur half-way between the *x* positions.

Returns
-------
`.PolyCollection`
    A `.PolyCollection` containing the plotted polygons.

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    All other keyword arguments are passed on to `.PolyCollection`.
    They control the `.Polygon` properties:

    %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
fill_between : Fill between two sets of y-values.
fill_betweenx : Fill between two sets of x-values.
5176 where=None, interpolate=False, step=None, **kwargs):
5177 # Common implementation between fill_between (*ind_dir*="x") and
5178 # fill_betweenx (*ind_dir*="y"). *ind* is the independent variable,
5179 # *dep* the dependent variable. The docstring below is interpolated
5180 # to generate both methods' docstrings.
5181 """
5182 Fill the area between two {dir} curves.
5183
5184 The curves are defined by the points (*{ind}*, *{dep}1*) and (*{ind}*,
5185 *{dep}2*). This creates one or multiple polygons describing the filled
5186 area.
5187
5188 You may exclude some {dir} sections from filling using *where*.
5189
5190 By default, the edges connect the given points directly. Use *step*
5191 if the filling should be a step function, i.e. constant in between
5192 *{ind}*.
5193
5194 Parameters
5195 ----------
5196 {ind} : array (length N)
5197 The {ind} coordinates of the nodes defining the curves.
5198
5199 {dep}1 : array (length N) or scalar
5200 The {dep} coordinates of the nodes defining the first curve.
5201
5202 {dep}2 : array (length N) or scalar, default: 0
5203 The {dep} coordinates of the nodes defining the second curve.
5204
5205 where : array of bool (length N), optional
5206 Define *where* to exclude some {dir} regions from being filled.
5207 The filled regions are defined by the coordinates ``{ind}[where]``.
5208 More precisely, fill between ``{ind}[i]`` and ``{ind}[i+1]`` if
5209 ``where[i] and where[i+1]``. Note that this definition implies
5210 that an isolated *True* value between two *False* values in *where*
5211 will not result in filling. Both sides of the *True* position
5212 remain unfilled due to the adjacent *False* values.
5213
5214 interpolate : bool, default: False
5215 This option is only relevant if *where* is used and the two curves
5216 are crossing each other.
5217
5218 Semantically, *where* is often used for *{dep}1* > *{dep}2* or
5219 similar. By default, the nodes of the polygon defining the filled
5220 region will only be placed at the positions in the *{ind}* array.
5221 Such a polygon cannot describe the above semantics close to the
5222 intersection. The {ind}-sections containing the intersection are
5223 simply clipped.
5224
5225 Setting *interpolate* to *True* will calculate the actual
5226 intersection point and extend the filled region up to this point.
5227
5228 step : {{'pre', 'post', 'mid'}}, optional
5229 Define *step* if the filling should be a step function,
5230 i.e. constant in between *{ind}*. The value determines where the
5231 step will occur:
5232
5233 - 'pre': The y value is continued constantly to the left from
5234 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``(x[i-1], x[i]]`` has the
5235 value ``y[i]``.
5236 - 'post': The y value is continued constantly to the right from
5237 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``[x[i], x[i+1])`` has the
5238 value ``y[i]``.
5239 - 'mid': Steps occur half-way between the *x* positions.
5240
5241 Returns
5242 -------
5243 `.PolyCollection`
5244 A `.PolyCollection` containing the plotted polygons.
5245
5246 Other Parameters
5247 ----------------
5248 data : indexable object, optional
5249 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
5250
5251 **kwargs
5252 All other keyword arguments are passed on to `.PolyCollection`.
5253 They control the `.Polygon` properties:
5254
5255 %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s
5256
5257 See Also
5258 --------
5259 fill_between : Fill between two sets of y-values.
5260 fill_betweenx : Fill between two sets of x-values.
5261 """
5262
5263 dep_dir = {"x": "y", "y": "x"}[ind_dir]
5264
5265 if not mpl.rcParams["_internal.classic_mode"]:
5266 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mcoll.Collection)
5267 if not any(c in kwargs for c in ("color", "facecolor")):
5268 kwargs["facecolor"] = \
5269 self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color()
5270
5271 # Handle united data, such as dates
5272 ind, dep1, dep2 = map(
5273 ma.masked_invalid, self._process_unit_info(
5274 [(ind_dir, ind), (dep_dir, dep1), (dep_dir, dep2)], kwargs))
5275
5276 for name, array in [
5277 (ind_dir, ind), (f"{dep_dir}1", dep1), (f"{dep_dir}2", dep2)]:
5278 if array.ndim > 1:
5279 raise ValueError(f"{name!r} is not 1-dimensional")
5280
5281 if where is None:
5282 where = True
5283 else:
5284 where = np.asarray(where, dtype=bool)
5285 if where.size != ind.size:
5286 raise ValueError(f"where size ({where.size}) does not match "
5287 f"{ind_dir} size ({ind.size})")
5288 where = where & ~functools.reduce(
5289 np.logical_or, map(np.ma.getmaskarray, [ind, dep1, dep2]))
5290
5291 ind, dep1, dep2 = np.broadcast_arrays(
5292 np.atleast_1d(ind), dep1, dep2, subok=True)
5293
5294 polys = []
5295 for idx0, idx1 in cbook.contiguous_regions(where):
5296 indslice = ind[idx0:idx1]
5297 dep1slice = dep1[idx0:idx1]
5298 dep2slice = dep2[idx0:idx1]
5299 if step is not None:
5300 step_func = cbook.STEP_LOOKUP_MAP["steps-" + step]
5301 indslice, dep1slice, dep2slice = \
5302 step_func(indslice, dep1slice, dep2slice)
5303
5304 if not len(indslice):
5305 continue
5306
5307 N = len(indslice)
5308 pts = np.zeros((2 * N + 2, 2))
5309
5310 if interpolate:
5311 def get_interp_point(idx):
5312 im1 = max(idx - 1, 0)
5313 ind_values = ind[im1:idx+1]
5314 diff_values = dep1[im1:idx+1] - dep2[im1:idx+1]
5315 dep1_values = dep1[im1:idx+1]
5316
5317 if len(diff_values) == 2:
5318 if np.ma.is_masked(diff_values[1]):
5319 return ind[im1], dep1[im1]
5320 elif np.ma.is_masked(diff_values[0]):
5321 return ind[idx], dep1[idx]
5322
5323 diff_order = diff_values.argsort()
5324 diff_root_ind = np.interp(
5325 0, diff_values[diff_order], ind_values[diff_order])
5326 ind_order = ind_values.argsort()
5327 diff_root_dep = np.interp(
5328 diff_root_ind,
5329 ind_values[ind_order], dep1_values[ind_order])
5330 return diff_root_ind, diff_root_dep
5331
5332 start = get_interp_point(idx0)
5333 end = get_interp_point(idx1)
5334 else:
5335 # Handle scalar dep2 (e.g. 0): the fill should go all
5336 # the way down to 0 even if none of the dep1 sample points do.
5337 start = indslice[0], dep2slice[0]
5338 end = indslice[-1], dep2slice[-1]
5339
5340 pts[0] = start
5341 pts[N + 1] = end
5342
5343 pts[1:N+1, 0] = indslice
5344 pts[1:N+1, 1] = dep1slice
5345 pts[N+2:, 0] = indslice[::-1]
5346 pts[N+2:, 1] = dep2slice[::-1]
5347
5348 if ind_dir == "y":
5349 pts = pts[:, ::-1]
5350
5351 polys.append(pts)
5352
5353 collection = mcoll.PolyCollection(polys, **kwargs)
5354
5355 # now update the datalim and autoscale
5356 pts = np.row_stack([np.column_stack([ind[where], dep1[where]]),
5357 np.column_stack([ind[where], dep2[where]])])
5358 if ind_dir == "y":
5359 pts = pts[:, ::-1]
5360 self.update_datalim(pts, updatex=True, updatey=True)
5361 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
5362 self._request_autoscale_view()
5363 return collection
5364

◆ _get_aspect_ratio()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._get_aspect_ratio (   self)
protected 
Convenience method to calculate the aspect ratio of the axes in
the display coordinate system.
8225 def _get_aspect_ratio(self):
8226 """
8227 Convenience method to calculate the aspect ratio of the axes in
8228 the display coordinate system.
8229 """
8230 figure_size = self.get_figure().get_size_inches()
8231 ll, ur = self.get_position() * figure_size
8232 width, height = ur - ll
8233 return height / (width * self.get_data_ratio())

◆ _parse_scatter_color_args()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._parse_scatter_color_args (   c,
  edgecolors,
  kwargs,
  xsize,
  get_next_color_func 
)
staticprotected 
Helper function to process color related arguments of `.Axes.scatter`.

Argument precedence for facecolors:

- c (if not None)
- kwargs['facecolor']
- kwargs['facecolors']
- kwargs['color'] (==kwcolor)
- 'b' if in classic mode else the result of ``get_next_color_func()``

Argument precedence for edgecolors:

- kwargs['edgecolor']
- edgecolors (is an explicit kw argument in scatter())
- kwargs['color'] (==kwcolor)
- 'face' if not in classic mode else None

Parameters
----------
c : color or sequence or sequence of color or None
    See argument description of `.Axes.scatter`.
edgecolors : color or sequence of color or {'face', 'none'} or None
    See argument description of `.Axes.scatter`.
kwargs : dict
    Additional kwargs. If these keys exist, we pop and process them:
    'facecolors', 'facecolor', 'edgecolor', 'color'
    Note: The dict is modified by this function.
xsize : int
    The size of the x and y arrays passed to `.Axes.scatter`.
get_next_color_func : callable
    A callable that returns a color. This color is used as facecolor
    if no other color is provided.

    Note, that this is a function rather than a fixed color value to
    support conditional evaluation of the next color.  As of the
    current implementation obtaining the next color from the
    property cycle advances the cycle. This must only happen if we
    actually use the color, which will only be decided within this
    method.

Returns
-------
c
    The input *c* if it was not *None*, else a color derived from the
    other inputs or defaults.
colors : array(N, 4) or None
    The facecolors as RGBA values, or *None* if a colormap is used.
edgecolors
    The edgecolor.
4248 get_next_color_func):
4249 """
4250 Helper function to process color related arguments of `.Axes.scatter`.
4251
4252 Argument precedence for facecolors:
4253
4254 - c (if not None)
4255 - kwargs['facecolor']
4256 - kwargs['facecolors']
4257 - kwargs['color'] (==kwcolor)
4258 - 'b' if in classic mode else the result of ``get_next_color_func()``
4259
4260 Argument precedence for edgecolors:
4261
4262 - kwargs['edgecolor']
4263 - edgecolors (is an explicit kw argument in scatter())
4264 - kwargs['color'] (==kwcolor)
4265 - 'face' if not in classic mode else None
4266
4267 Parameters
4268 ----------
4269 c : color or sequence or sequence of color or None
4270 See argument description of `.Axes.scatter`.
4271 edgecolors : color or sequence of color or {'face', 'none'} or None
4272 See argument description of `.Axes.scatter`.
4273 kwargs : dict
4274 Additional kwargs. If these keys exist, we pop and process them:
4275 'facecolors', 'facecolor', 'edgecolor', 'color'
4276 Note: The dict is modified by this function.
4277 xsize : int
4278 The size of the x and y arrays passed to `.Axes.scatter`.
4279 get_next_color_func : callable
4280 A callable that returns a color. This color is used as facecolor
4281 if no other color is provided.
4282
4283 Note, that this is a function rather than a fixed color value to
4284 support conditional evaluation of the next color. As of the
4285 current implementation obtaining the next color from the
4286 property cycle advances the cycle. This must only happen if we
4287 actually use the color, which will only be decided within this
4288 method.
4289
4290 Returns
4291 -------
4292 c
4293 The input *c* if it was not *None*, else a color derived from the
4294 other inputs or defaults.
4295 colors : array(N, 4) or None
4296 The facecolors as RGBA values, or *None* if a colormap is used.
4297 edgecolors
4298 The edgecolor.
4299
4300 """
4301 facecolors = kwargs.pop('facecolors', None)
4302 facecolors = kwargs.pop('facecolor', facecolors)
4303 edgecolors = kwargs.pop('edgecolor', edgecolors)
4304
4305 kwcolor = kwargs.pop('color', None)
4306
4307 if kwcolor is not None and c is not None:
4308 raise ValueError("Supply a 'c' argument or a 'color'"
4309 " kwarg but not both; they differ but"
4310 " their functionalities overlap.")
4311
4312 if kwcolor is not None:
4313 try:
4314 mcolors.to_rgba_array(kwcolor)
4315 except ValueError as err:
4316 raise ValueError(
4317 "'color' kwarg must be a color or sequence of color "
4318 "specs. For a sequence of values to be color-mapped, use "
4319 "the 'c' argument instead.") from err
4320 if edgecolors is None:
4321 edgecolors = kwcolor
4322 if facecolors is None:
4323 facecolors = kwcolor
4324
4325 if edgecolors is None and not mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']:
4326 edgecolors = mpl.rcParams['scatter.edgecolors']
4327
4328 c_was_none = c is None
4329 if c is None:
4330 c = (facecolors if facecolors is not None
4331 else "b" if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']
4332 else get_next_color_func())
4333 c_is_string_or_strings = (
4334 isinstance(c, str)
4335 or (np.iterable(c) and len(c) > 0
4336 and isinstance(cbook._safe_first_finite(c), str)))
4337
4338 def invalid_shape_exception(csize, xsize):
4339 return ValueError(
4340 f"'c' argument has {csize} elements, which is inconsistent "
4341 f"with 'x' and 'y' with size {xsize}.")
4342
4343 c_is_mapped = False # Unless proven otherwise below.
4344 valid_shape = True # Unless proven otherwise below.
4345 if not c_was_none and kwcolor is None and not c_is_string_or_strings:
4346 try: # First, does 'c' look suitable for value-mapping?
4347 c = np.asanyarray(c, dtype=float)
4348 except ValueError:
4349 pass # Failed to convert to float array; must be color specs.
4350 else:
4351 # handle the documented special case of a 2D array with 1
4352 # row which as RGB(A) to broadcast.
4353 if c.shape == (1, 4) or c.shape == (1, 3):
4354 c_is_mapped = False
4355 if c.size != xsize:
4356 valid_shape = False
4357 # If c can be either mapped values or a RGB(A) color, prefer
4358 # the former if shapes match, the latter otherwise.
4359 elif c.size == xsize:
4360 c = c.ravel()
4361 c_is_mapped = True
4362 else: # Wrong size; it must not be intended for mapping.
4363 if c.shape in ((3,), (4,)):
4364 _log.warning(
4365 "*c* argument looks like a single numeric RGB or "
4366 "RGBA sequence, which should be avoided as value-"
4367 "mapping will have precedence in case its length "
4368 "matches with *x* & *y*. Please use the *color* "
4369 "keyword-argument or provide a 2D array "
4370 "with a single row if you intend to specify "
4371 "the same RGB or RGBA value for all points.")
4372 valid_shape = False
4373 if not c_is_mapped:
4374 try: # Is 'c' acceptable as PathCollection facecolors?
4375 colors = mcolors.to_rgba_array(c)
4376 except (TypeError, ValueError) as err:
4377 if "RGBA values should be within 0-1 range" in str(err):
4378 raise
4379 else:
4380 if not valid_shape:
4381 raise invalid_shape_exception(c.size, xsize) from err
4382 # Both the mapping *and* the RGBA conversion failed: pretty
4383 # severe failure => one may appreciate a verbose feedback.
4384 raise ValueError(
4385 f"'c' argument must be a color, a sequence of colors, "
4386 f"or a sequence of numbers, not {c}") from err
4387 else:
4388 if len(colors) not in (0, 1, xsize):
4389 # NB: remember that a single color is also acceptable.
4390 # Besides *colors* will be an empty array if c == 'none'.
4391 raise invalid_shape_exception(len(colors), xsize)
4392 else:
4393 colors = None # use cmap, norm after collection is created
4394 return c, colors, edgecolors
4395

◆ _pcolor_grid_deprecation_helper()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._pcolor_grid_deprecation_helper (   self)
protected
5735 def _pcolor_grid_deprecation_helper(self):
5736 grid_active = any(axis._major_tick_kw["gridOn"]
5737 for axis in self._axis_map.values())
5738 # explicit is-True check because get_axisbelow() can also be 'line'
5739 grid_hidden_by_pcolor = self.get_axisbelow() is True
5740 if grid_active and not grid_hidden_by_pcolor:
5741 _api.warn_deprecated(
5742 "3.5", message="Auto-removal of grids by pcolor() and "
5743 "pcolormesh() is deprecated since %(since)s and will be "
5744 "removed %(removal)s; please call grid(False) first.")
5745 self.grid(False)
5746

◆ _pcolorargs()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._pcolorargs (   self,
  funcname,
*  args,
  shading = 'auto',
**  kwargs 
)
protected
5619 def _pcolorargs(self, funcname, *args, shading='auto', **kwargs):
5620 # - create X and Y if not present;
5621 # - reshape X and Y as needed if they are 1-D;
5622 # - check for proper sizes based on `shading` kwarg;
5623 # - reset shading if shading='auto' to flat or nearest
5624 # depending on size;
5625
5626 _valid_shading = ['gouraud', 'nearest', 'flat', 'auto']
5627 try:
5628 _api.check_in_list(_valid_shading, shading=shading)
5629 except ValueError:
5630 _api.warn_external(f"shading value '{shading}' not in list of "
5631 f"valid values {_valid_shading}. Setting "
5632 "shading='auto'.")
5633 shading = 'auto'
5634
5635 if len(args) == 1:
5636 C = np.asanyarray(args[0])
5637 nrows, ncols = C.shape
5638 if shading in ['gouraud', 'nearest']:
5639 X, Y = np.meshgrid(np.arange(ncols), np.arange(nrows))
5640 else:
5641 X, Y = np.meshgrid(np.arange(ncols + 1), np.arange(nrows + 1))
5642 shading = 'flat'
5643 C = cbook.safe_masked_invalid(C)
5644 return X, Y, C, shading
5645
5646 if len(args) == 3:
5647 # Check x and y for bad data...
5648 C = np.asanyarray(args[2])
5649 # unit conversion allows e.g. datetime objects as axis values
5650 X, Y = args[:2]
5651 X, Y = self._process_unit_info([("x", X), ("y", Y)], kwargs)
5652 X, Y = [cbook.safe_masked_invalid(a) for a in [X, Y]]
5653
5654 if funcname == 'pcolormesh':
5655 if np.ma.is_masked(X) or np.ma.is_masked(Y):
5656 raise ValueError(
5657 'x and y arguments to pcolormesh cannot have '
5658 'non-finite values or be of type '
5659 'numpy.ma.core.MaskedArray with masked values')
5660 # safe_masked_invalid() returns an ndarray for dtypes other
5661 # than floating point.
5662 if isinstance(X, np.ma.core.MaskedArray):
5663 X = X.data # strip mask as downstream doesn't like it...
5664 if isinstance(Y, np.ma.core.MaskedArray):
5665 Y = Y.data
5666 nrows, ncols = C.shape
5667 else:
5668 raise TypeError(f'{funcname}() takes 1 or 3 positional arguments '
5669 f'but {len(args)} were given')
5670
5671 Nx = X.shape[-1]
5672 Ny = Y.shape[0]
5673 if X.ndim != 2 or X.shape[0] == 1:
5674 x = X.reshape(1, Nx)
5675 X = x.repeat(Ny, axis=0)
5676 if Y.ndim != 2 or Y.shape[1] == 1:
5677 y = Y.reshape(Ny, 1)
5678 Y = y.repeat(Nx, axis=1)
5679 if X.shape != Y.shape:
5680 raise TypeError(f'Incompatible X, Y inputs to {funcname}; '
5681 f'see help({funcname})')
5682
5683 if shading == 'auto':
5684 if ncols == Nx and nrows == Ny:
5685 shading = 'nearest'
5686 else:
5687 shading = 'flat'
5688
5689 if shading == 'flat':
5690 if (Nx, Ny) != (ncols + 1, nrows + 1):
5691 raise TypeError('Dimensions of C %s are incompatible with'
5692 ' X (%d) and/or Y (%d); see help(%s)' % (
5693 C.shape, Nx, Ny, funcname))
5694 else: # ['nearest', 'gouraud']:
5695 if (Nx, Ny) != (ncols, nrows):
5696 raise TypeError('Dimensions of C %s are incompatible with'
5697 ' X (%d) and/or Y (%d); see help(%s)' % (
5698 C.shape, Nx, Ny, funcname))
5699 if shading == 'nearest':
5700 # grid is specified at the center, so define corners
5701 # at the midpoints between the grid centers and then use the
5702 # flat algorithm.
5703 def _interp_grid(X):
5704 # helper for below
5705 if np.shape(X)[1] > 1:
5706 dX = np.diff(X, axis=1)/2.
5707 if not (np.all(dX >= 0) or np.all(dX <= 0)):
5708 _api.warn_external(
5709 f"The input coordinates to {funcname} are "
5710 "interpreted as cell centers, but are not "
5711 "monotonically increasing or decreasing. "
5712 "This may lead to incorrectly calculated cell "
5713 "edges, in which case, please supply "
5714 f"explicit cell edges to {funcname}.")
5715 X = np.hstack((X[:, [0]] - dX[:, [0]],
5716 X[:, :-1] + dX,
5717 X[:, [-1]] + dX[:, [-1]]))
5718 else:
5719 # This is just degenerate, but we can't reliably guess
5720 # a dX if there is just one value.
5721 X = np.hstack((X, X))
5722 return X
5723
5724 if ncols == Nx:
5725 X = _interp_grid(X)
5726 Y = _interp_grid(Y)
5727 if nrows == Ny:
5728 X = _interp_grid(X.T).T
5729 Y = _interp_grid(Y.T).T
5730 shading = 'flat'
5731
5732 C = cbook.safe_masked_invalid(C)
5733 return X, Y, C, shading
5734

◆ _quiver_units()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._quiver_units (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
)
protected
5089 def _quiver_units(self, args, kwargs):
5090 if len(args) > 3:
5091 x, y = args[0:2]
5092 x, y = self._process_unit_info([("x", x), ("y", y)], kwargs)
5093 return (x, y) + args[2:]
5094 return args
5095

◆ _remove_legend()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes._remove_legend (   self,

311 def _remove_legend(self, legend):
312 self.legend_ = None
313

◆ acorr()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.acorr (   self,
  x,
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot the autocorrelation of *x*.

Parameters
----------
x : array-like

detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending)
    A detrending function applied to *x*.  It must have the
    signature ::

        detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray

normed : bool, default: True
    If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length.

usevlines : bool, default: True
    Determines the plot style.

    If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the acorr value
    using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted
    at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`.

    If ``False``, markers are plotted at the acorr values using
    `.Axes.plot`.

maxlags : int, default: 10
    Number of lags to show. If ``None``, will return all
    ``2 * len(x) - 1`` lags.

Returns
-------
lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
    The lag vector.
c : array  (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
    The auto correlation vector.
line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D`
    `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation:

    - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True.
    - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False.
b : `.Line2D` or None
    Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True
    None *usevlines* is False.

Other Parameters
----------------
linestyle : `.Line2D` property, optional
    The linestyle for plotting the data points.
    Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.

marker : str, default: 'o'
    The marker for plotting the data points.
    Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.

data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and
    `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are
    passed to `.Axes.plot`.

Notes
-----
The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with
``mode = "full"``.
1901 def acorr(self, x, **kwargs):
1902 """
1903 Plot the autocorrelation of *x*.
1904
1905 Parameters
1906 ----------
1907 x : array-like
1908
1909 detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending)
1910 A detrending function applied to *x*. It must have the
1911 signature ::
1912
1913 detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray
1914
1915 normed : bool, default: True
1916 If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length.
1917
1918 usevlines : bool, default: True
1919 Determines the plot style.
1920
1921 If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the acorr value
1922 using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted
1923 at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`.
1924
1925 If ``False``, markers are plotted at the acorr values using
1926 `.Axes.plot`.
1927
1928 maxlags : int, default: 10
1929 Number of lags to show. If ``None``, will return all
1930 ``2 * len(x) - 1`` lags.
1931
1932 Returns
1933 -------
1934 lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
1935 The lag vector.
1936 c : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
1937 The auto correlation vector.
1938 line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D`
1939 `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation:
1940
1941 - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True.
1942 - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False.
1943 b : `.Line2D` or None
1944 Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True
1945 None *usevlines* is False.
1946
1947 Other Parameters
1948 ----------------
1949 linestyle : `.Line2D` property, optional
1950 The linestyle for plotting the data points.
1951 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.
1952
1953 marker : str, default: 'o'
1954 The marker for plotting the data points.
1955 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.
1956
1957 data : indexable object, optional
1958 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
1959
1960 **kwargs
1961 Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and
1962 `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are
1963 passed to `.Axes.plot`.
1964
1965 Notes
1966 -----
1967 The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with
1968 ``mode = "full"``.
1969 """
1970 return self.xcorr(x, x, **kwargs)
1971

◆ angle_spectrum()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.angle_spectrum (   self,
  x,
  Fs = None,
  Fc = None,
  window = None,
  pad_to = None,
  sides = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot the angle spectrum.

Compute the angle spectrum (wrapped phase spectrum) of *x*.
Data is padded to a length of *pad_to* and the windowing function
*window* is applied to the signal.

Parameters
----------
x : 1-D array or sequence
    Array or sequence containing the data.

%(Spectral)s

%(Single_Spectrum)s

Fc : int, default: 0
    The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
    plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
    and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.

Returns
-------
spectrum : 1-D array
    The values for the angle spectrum in radians (real valued).

freqs : 1-D array
    The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*.

line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
    The line created by this function.

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
magnitude_spectrum
    Plots the magnitudes of the corresponding frequencies.
phase_spectrum
    Plots the unwrapped version of this function.
specgram
    Can plot the angle spectrum of segments within the signal in a
    colormap.
7390 pad_to=None, sides=None, **kwargs):
7391 """
7392 Plot the angle spectrum.
7393
7394 Compute the angle spectrum (wrapped phase spectrum) of *x*.
7395 Data is padded to a length of *pad_to* and the windowing function
7396 *window* is applied to the signal.
7397
7398 Parameters
7399 ----------
7400 x : 1-D array or sequence
7401 Array or sequence containing the data.
7402
7403 %(Spectral)s
7404
7405 %(Single_Spectrum)s
7406
7407 Fc : int, default: 0
7408 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
7409 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
7410 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.
7411
7412 Returns
7413 -------
7414 spectrum : 1-D array
7415 The values for the angle spectrum in radians (real valued).
7416
7417 freqs : 1-D array
7418 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*.
7419
7420 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
7421 The line created by this function.
7422
7423 Other Parameters
7424 ----------------
7425 data : indexable object, optional
7426 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
7427
7428 **kwargs
7429 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:
7430
7431 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
7432
7433 See Also
7434 --------
7435 magnitude_spectrum
7436 Plots the magnitudes of the corresponding frequencies.
7437 phase_spectrum
7438 Plots the unwrapped version of this function.
7439 specgram
7440 Can plot the angle spectrum of segments within the signal in a
7441 colormap.
7442 """
7443 if Fc is None:
7444 Fc = 0
7445
7446 spec, freqs = mlab.angle_spectrum(x=x, Fs=Fs, window=window,
7447 pad_to=pad_to, sides=sides)
7448 freqs += Fc
7449
7450 lines = self.plot(freqs, spec, **kwargs)
7451 self.set_xlabel('Frequency')
7452 self.set_ylabel('Angle (radians)')
7453
7454 return spec, freqs, lines[0]
7455

◆ annotate()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.annotate (   self,
  text,
  xy,
  xytext = None,
  xycoords = 'data',
  textcoords = None,
  arrowprops = None,
  annotation_clip = None,
**  kwargs 
)
685 arrowprops=None, annotation_clip=None, **kwargs):
686 # Signature must match Annotation. This is verified in
687 # test_annotate_signature().
688 a = mtext.Annotation(text, xy, xytext=xytext, xycoords=xycoords,
689 textcoords=textcoords, arrowprops=arrowprops,
690 annotation_clip=annotation_clip, **kwargs)
691 a.set_transform(mtransforms.IdentityTransform())
692 if 'clip_on' in kwargs:
693 a.set_clip_path(self.patch)
694 self._add_text(a)
695 return a

◆ arrow()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.arrow (   self,
  x,
  y,
  dx,
  dy,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add an arrow to the Axes.

This draws an arrow from ``(x, y)`` to ``(x+dx, y+dy)``.

Parameters
----------
%(FancyArrow)s

Returns
-------
`.FancyArrow`
    The created `.FancyArrow` object.

Notes
-----
The resulting arrow is affected by the Axes aspect ratio and limits.
This may produce an arrow whose head is not square with its stem. To
create an arrow whose head is square with its stem,
use :meth:`annotate` for example:

>>> ax.annotate("", xy=(0.5, 0.5), xytext=(0, 0),
...             arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->"))
5044 def arrow(self, x, y, dx, dy, **kwargs):
5045 """
5046 Add an arrow to the Axes.
5047
5048 This draws an arrow from ``(x, y)`` to ``(x+dx, y+dy)``.
5049
5050 Parameters
5051 ----------
5052 %(FancyArrow)s
5053
5054 Returns
5055 -------
5056 `.FancyArrow`
5057 The created `.FancyArrow` object.
5058
5059 Notes
5060 -----
5061 The resulting arrow is affected by the Axes aspect ratio and limits.
5062 This may produce an arrow whose head is not square with its stem. To
5063 create an arrow whose head is square with its stem,
5064 use :meth:`annotate` for example:
5065
5066 >>> ax.annotate("", xy=(0.5, 0.5), xytext=(0, 0),
5067 ... arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->"))
5068
5069 """
5070 # Strip away units for the underlying patch since units
5071 # do not make sense to most patch-like code
5072 x = self.convert_xunits(x)
5073 y = self.convert_yunits(y)
5074 dx = self.convert_xunits(dx)
5075 dy = self.convert_yunits(dy)
5076
5077 a = mpatches.FancyArrow(x, y, dx, dy, **kwargs)
5078 self.add_patch(a)
5079 self._request_autoscale_view()
5080 return a
5081

◆ axhline()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.axhline (   self,
  y = 0,
  xmin = 0,
  xmax = 1,
**  kwargs 
)

Lines and spans. 

Add a horizontal line across the Axes.

Parameters
----------
y : float, default: 0
    y position in data coordinates of the horizontal line.

xmin : float, default: 0
    Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 1 the
    far right of the plot.

xmax : float, default: 1
    Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 1 the
    far right of the plot.

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs
    Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, with the
    exception of 'transform':

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
hlines : Add horizontal lines in data coordinates.
axhspan : Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the axis.
axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope.

Examples
--------
* draw a thick red hline at 'y' = 0 that spans the xrange::

    >>> axhline(linewidth=4, color='r')

* draw a default hline at 'y' = 1 that spans the xrange::

    >>> axhline(y=1)

* draw a default hline at 'y' = .5 that spans the middle half of
  the xrange::

    >>> axhline(y=.5, xmin=0.25, xmax=0.75)
700 def axhline(self, y=0, xmin=0, xmax=1, **kwargs):
701 """
702 Add a horizontal line across the Axes.
703
704 Parameters
705 ----------
706 y : float, default: 0
707 y position in data coordinates of the horizontal line.
708
709 xmin : float, default: 0
710 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 1 the
711 far right of the plot.
712
713 xmax : float, default: 1
714 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 1 the
715 far right of the plot.
716
717 Returns
718 -------
719 `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
720
721 Other Parameters
722 ----------------
723 **kwargs
724 Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, with the
725 exception of 'transform':
726
727 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
728
729 See Also
730 --------
731 hlines : Add horizontal lines in data coordinates.
732 axhspan : Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the axis.
733 axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope.
734
735 Examples
736 --------
737 * draw a thick red hline at 'y' = 0 that spans the xrange::
738
739 >>> axhline(linewidth=4, color='r')
740
741 * draw a default hline at 'y' = 1 that spans the xrange::
742
743 >>> axhline(y=1)
744
745 * draw a default hline at 'y' = .5 that spans the middle half of
746 the xrange::
747
748 >>> axhline(y=.5, xmin=0.25, xmax=0.75)
749 """
750 self._check_no_units([xmin, xmax], ['xmin', 'xmax'])
751 if "transform" in kwargs:
752 raise ValueError("'transform' is not allowed as a keyword "
753 "argument; axhline generates its own transform.")
754 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound()
755
756 # Strip away the units for comparison with non-unitized bounds.
757 yy, = self._process_unit_info([("y", y)], kwargs)
758 scaley = (yy < ymin) or (yy > ymax)
759
760 trans = self.get_yaxis_transform(which='grid')
761 l = mlines.Line2D([xmin, xmax], [y, y], transform=trans, **kwargs)
762 self.add_line(l)
763 if scaley:
764 self._request_autoscale_view("y")
765 return l
766

◆ axhspan()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.axhspan (   self,
  ymin,
  ymax,
  xmin = 0,
  xmax = 1,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the Axes.

The rectangle spans from *ymin* to *ymax* vertically, and, by default,
the whole x-axis horizontally.  The x-span can be set using *xmin*
(default: 0) and *xmax* (default: 1) which are in axis units; e.g.
``xmin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the x-axis regardless of
the limits set by `~.Axes.set_xlim`.

Parameters
----------
ymin : float
    Lower y-coordinate of the span, in data units.
ymax : float
    Upper y-coordinate of the span, in data units.
xmin : float, default: 0
    Lower x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units.
xmax : float, default: 1
    Upper x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units.

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.patches.Polygon`
    Horizontal span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax).

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties

%(Polygon:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
axvspan : Add a vertical span across the Axes.
918 def axhspan(self, ymin, ymax, xmin=0, xmax=1, **kwargs):
919 """
920 Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the Axes.
921
922 The rectangle spans from *ymin* to *ymax* vertically, and, by default,
923 the whole x-axis horizontally. The x-span can be set using *xmin*
924 (default: 0) and *xmax* (default: 1) which are in axis units; e.g.
925 ``xmin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the x-axis regardless of
926 the limits set by `~.Axes.set_xlim`.
927
928 Parameters
929 ----------
930 ymin : float
931 Lower y-coordinate of the span, in data units.
932 ymax : float
933 Upper y-coordinate of the span, in data units.
934 xmin : float, default: 0
935 Lower x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units.
936 xmax : float, default: 1
937 Upper x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units.
938
939 Returns
940 -------
941 `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon`
942 Horizontal span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax).
943
944 Other Parameters
945 ----------------
946 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties
947
948 %(Polygon:kwdoc)s
949
950 See Also
951 --------
952 axvspan : Add a vertical span across the Axes.
953 """
954 # Strip units away.
955 self._check_no_units([xmin, xmax], ['xmin', 'xmax'])
956 (ymin, ymax), = self._process_unit_info([("y", [ymin, ymax])], kwargs)
957
958 verts = (xmin, ymin), (xmin, ymax), (xmax, ymax), (xmax, ymin)
959 p = mpatches.Polygon(verts, **kwargs)
960 p.set_transform(self.get_yaxis_transform(which="grid"))
961 self.add_patch(p)
962 self._request_autoscale_view("y")
963 return p
964

◆ axline()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.axline (   self,
  xy1,
  xy2 = None,
*  slope = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add an infinitely long straight line.

The line can be defined either by two points *xy1* and *xy2*, or
by one point *xy1* and a *slope*.

This draws a straight line "on the screen", regardless of the x and y
scales, and is thus also suitable for drawing exponential decays in
semilog plots, power laws in loglog plots, etc. However, *slope*
should only be used with linear scales; It has no clear meaning for
all other scales, and thus the behavior is undefined. Please specify
the line using the points *xy1*, *xy2* for non-linear scales.

The *transform* keyword argument only applies to the points *xy1*,
*xy2*. The *slope* (if given) is always in data coordinates. This can
be used e.g. with ``ax.transAxes`` for drawing grid lines with a fixed
slope.

Parameters
----------
xy1, xy2 : (float, float)
    Points for the line to pass through.
    Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given.
slope : float, optional
    The slope of the line. Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given.

Returns
-------
`.Line2D`

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs
    Valid kwargs are `.Line2D` properties

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
axhline : for horizontal lines
axvline : for vertical lines

Examples
--------
Draw a thick red line passing through (0, 0) and (1, 1)::

    >>> axline((0, 0), (1, 1), linewidth=4, color='r')
844 def axline(self, xy1, xy2=None, *, slope=None, **kwargs):
845 """
846 Add an infinitely long straight line.
847
848 The line can be defined either by two points *xy1* and *xy2*, or
849 by one point *xy1* and a *slope*.
850
851 This draws a straight line "on the screen", regardless of the x and y
852 scales, and is thus also suitable for drawing exponential decays in
853 semilog plots, power laws in loglog plots, etc. However, *slope*
854 should only be used with linear scales; It has no clear meaning for
855 all other scales, and thus the behavior is undefined. Please specify
856 the line using the points *xy1*, *xy2* for non-linear scales.
857
858 The *transform* keyword argument only applies to the points *xy1*,
859 *xy2*. The *slope* (if given) is always in data coordinates. This can
860 be used e.g. with ``ax.transAxes`` for drawing grid lines with a fixed
861 slope.
862
863 Parameters
864 ----------
865 xy1, xy2 : (float, float)
866 Points for the line to pass through.
867 Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given.
868 slope : float, optional
869 The slope of the line. Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given.
870
871 Returns
872 -------
873 `.Line2D`
874
875 Other Parameters
876 ----------------
877 **kwargs
878 Valid kwargs are `.Line2D` properties
879
880 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
881
882 See Also
883 --------
884 axhline : for horizontal lines
885 axvline : for vertical lines
886
887 Examples
888 --------
889 Draw a thick red line passing through (0, 0) and (1, 1)::
890
891 >>> axline((0, 0), (1, 1), linewidth=4, color='r')
892 """
893 if slope is not None and (self.get_xscale() != 'linear' or
894 self.get_yscale() != 'linear'):
895 raise TypeError("'slope' cannot be used with non-linear scales")
896
897 datalim = [xy1] if xy2 is None else [xy1, xy2]
898 if "transform" in kwargs:
899 # if a transform is passed (i.e. line points not in data space),
900 # data limits should not be adjusted.
901 datalim = []
902
903 line = mlines._AxLine(xy1, xy2, slope, **kwargs)
904 # Like add_line, but correctly handling data limits.
905 self._set_artist_props(line)
906 if line.get_clip_path() is None:
907 line.set_clip_path(self.patch)
908 if not line.get_label():
909 line.set_label(f"_child{len(self._children)}")
910 self._children.append(line)
911 line._remove_method = self._children.remove
912 self.update_datalim(datalim)
913
914 self._request_autoscale_view()
915 return line
916

◆ axvline()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.axvline (   self,
  x = 0,
  ymin = 0,
  ymax = 1,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add a vertical line across the Axes.

Parameters
----------
x : float, default: 0
    x position in data coordinates of the vertical line.

ymin : float, default: 0
    Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the
    top of the plot.

ymax : float, default: 1
    Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the
    top of the plot.

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs
    Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, with the
    exception of 'transform':

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
vlines : Add vertical lines in data coordinates.
axvspan : Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the axis.
axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope.

Examples
--------
* draw a thick red vline at *x* = 0 that spans the yrange::

    >>> axvline(linewidth=4, color='r')

* draw a default vline at *x* = 1 that spans the yrange::

    >>> axvline(x=1)

* draw a default vline at *x* = .5 that spans the middle half of
  the yrange::

    >>> axvline(x=.5, ymin=0.25, ymax=0.75)
768 def axvline(self, x=0, ymin=0, ymax=1, **kwargs):
769 """
770 Add a vertical line across the Axes.
771
772 Parameters
773 ----------
774 x : float, default: 0
775 x position in data coordinates of the vertical line.
776
777 ymin : float, default: 0
778 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the
779 top of the plot.
780
781 ymax : float, default: 1
782 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the
783 top of the plot.
784
785 Returns
786 -------
787 `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
788
789 Other Parameters
790 ----------------
791 **kwargs
792 Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, with the
793 exception of 'transform':
794
795 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
796
797 See Also
798 --------
799 vlines : Add vertical lines in data coordinates.
800 axvspan : Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the axis.
801 axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope.
802
803 Examples
804 --------
805 * draw a thick red vline at *x* = 0 that spans the yrange::
806
807 >>> axvline(linewidth=4, color='r')
808
809 * draw a default vline at *x* = 1 that spans the yrange::
810
811 >>> axvline(x=1)
812
813 * draw a default vline at *x* = .5 that spans the middle half of
814 the yrange::
815
816 >>> axvline(x=.5, ymin=0.25, ymax=0.75)
817 """
818 self._check_no_units([ymin, ymax], ['ymin', 'ymax'])
819 if "transform" in kwargs:
820 raise ValueError("'transform' is not allowed as a keyword "
821 "argument; axvline generates its own transform.")
822 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound()
823
824 # Strip away the units for comparison with non-unitized bounds.
825 xx, = self._process_unit_info([("x", x)], kwargs)
826 scalex = (xx < xmin) or (xx > xmax)
827
828 trans = self.get_xaxis_transform(which='grid')
829 l = mlines.Line2D([x, x], [ymin, ymax], transform=trans, **kwargs)
830 self.add_line(l)
831 if scalex:
832 self._request_autoscale_view("x")
833 return l
834

◆ axvspan()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.axvspan (   self,
  xmin,
  xmax,
  ymin = 0,
  ymax = 1,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the Axes.

The rectangle spans from *xmin* to *xmax* horizontally, and, by
default, the whole y-axis vertically.  The y-span can be set using
*ymin* (default: 0) and *ymax* (default: 1) which are in axis units;
e.g. ``ymin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the y-axis
regardless of the limits set by `~.Axes.set_ylim`.

Parameters
----------
xmin : float
    Lower x-coordinate of the span, in data units.
xmax : float
    Upper x-coordinate of the span, in data units.
ymin : float, default: 0
    Lower y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1).
ymax : float, default: 1
    Upper y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1).

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.patches.Polygon`
    Vertical span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax).

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties

%(Polygon:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
axhspan : Add a horizontal span across the Axes.

Examples
--------
Draw a vertical, green, translucent rectangle from x = 1.25 to
x = 1.55 that spans the yrange of the Axes.

>>> axvspan(1.25, 1.55, facecolor='g', alpha=0.5)
966 def axvspan(self, xmin, xmax, ymin=0, ymax=1, **kwargs):
967 """
968 Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the Axes.
969
970 The rectangle spans from *xmin* to *xmax* horizontally, and, by
971 default, the whole y-axis vertically. The y-span can be set using
972 *ymin* (default: 0) and *ymax* (default: 1) which are in axis units;
973 e.g. ``ymin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the y-axis
974 regardless of the limits set by `~.Axes.set_ylim`.
975
976 Parameters
977 ----------
978 xmin : float
979 Lower x-coordinate of the span, in data units.
980 xmax : float
981 Upper x-coordinate of the span, in data units.
982 ymin : float, default: 0
983 Lower y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1).
984 ymax : float, default: 1
985 Upper y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1).
986
987 Returns
988 -------
989 `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon`
990 Vertical span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax).
991
992 Other Parameters
993 ----------------
994 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties
995
996 %(Polygon:kwdoc)s
997
998 See Also
999 --------
1000 axhspan : Add a horizontal span across the Axes.
1001
1002 Examples
1003 --------
1004 Draw a vertical, green, translucent rectangle from x = 1.25 to
1005 x = 1.55 that spans the yrange of the Axes.
1006
1007 >>> axvspan(1.25, 1.55, facecolor='g', alpha=0.5)
1008
1009 """
1010 # Strip units away.
1011 self._check_no_units([ymin, ymax], ['ymin', 'ymax'])
1012 (xmin, xmax), = self._process_unit_info([("x", [xmin, xmax])], kwargs)
1013
1014 verts = [(xmin, ymin), (xmin, ymax), (xmax, ymax), (xmax, ymin)]
1015 p = mpatches.Polygon(verts, **kwargs)
1016 p.set_transform(self.get_xaxis_transform(which="grid"))
1017 p.get_path()._interpolation_steps = 100
1018 self.add_patch(p)
1019 self._request_autoscale_view("x")
1020 return p
1021

◆ bar()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.bar (   self,
  x,
  height,
  width = 0.8,
  bottom = None,
*  align = "center",
**  kwargs 
) 
    Make a bar plot.

    The bars are positioned at *x* with the given *align*\ment. Their
    dimensions are given by *height* and *width*. The vertical baseline
    is *bottom* (default 0).

    Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars
    or a sequence of values, one for each bar.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x : float or array-like
        The x coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the
        alignment of the bars to the coordinates.

    height : float or array-like
        The height(s) of the bars.

    width : float or array-like, default: 0.8
        The width(s) of the bars.

    bottom : float or array-like, default: 0
        The y coordinate(s) of the bottom side(s) of the bars.

    align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center'
        Alignment of the bars to the *x* coordinates:

        - 'center': Center the base on the *x* positions.
        - 'edge': Align the left edges of the bars with the *x* positions.

        To align the bars on the right edge pass a negative *width* and
        ``align='edge'``.

    Returns
    -------
    `.BarContainer`
        Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars.

    Other Parameters
    ----------------
    color : color or list of color, optional
        The colors of the bar faces.

    edgecolor : color or list of color, optional
        The colors of the bar edges.

    linewidth : float or array-like, optional
        Width of the bar edge(s). If 0, don't draw edges.

    tick_label : str or list of str, optional
        The tick labels of the bars.
        Default: None (Use default numeric labels.)

    label : str or list of str, optional
        A single label is attached to the resulting `.BarContainer` as a
        label for the whole dataset.
        If a list is provided, it must be the same length as *x* and
        labels the individual bars. Repeated labels are not de-duplicated
        and will cause repeated label entries, so this is best used when
        bars also differ in style (e.g., by passing a list to *color*.)

    xerr, yerr : float or array-like of shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional
        If not *None*, add horizontal / vertical errorbars to the bar tips.
        The values are +/- sizes relative to the data:

        - scalar: symmetric +/- values for all bars
        - shape(N,): symmetric +/- values for each bar
        - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row
          contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper
          errors.
        - *None*: No errorbar. (Default)

        See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features` for an example on
        the usage of *xerr* and *yerr*.

    ecolor : color or list of color, default: 'black'
        The line color of the errorbars.

    capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize`
       The length of the error bar caps in points.

    error_kw : dict, optional
        Dictionary of keyword arguments to be passed to the
        `~.Axes.errorbar` method. Values of *ecolor* or *capsize* defined
        here take precedence over the independent keyword arguments.

    log : bool, default: False
        If *True*, set the y-axis to be log scale.

    data : indexable object, optional
        DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

    **kwargs : `.Rectangle` properties

    %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s

    See Also
    --------
    barh : Plot a horizontal bar plot.

    Notes
    -----
    Stacked bars can be achieved by passing individual *bottom* values per
    bar. See :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_stacked`.

Reimplemented in mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.

2215 **kwargs):
2216 r"""
2217 Make a bar plot.
2218
2219 The bars are positioned at *x* with the given *align*\ment. Their
2220 dimensions are given by *height* and *width*. The vertical baseline
2221 is *bottom* (default 0).
2222
2223 Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars
2224 or a sequence of values, one for each bar.
2225
2226 Parameters
2227 ----------
2228 x : float or array-like
2229 The x coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the
2230 alignment of the bars to the coordinates.
2231
2232 height : float or array-like
2233 The height(s) of the bars.
2234
2235 width : float or array-like, default: 0.8
2236 The width(s) of the bars.
2237
2238 bottom : float or array-like, default: 0
2239 The y coordinate(s) of the bottom side(s) of the bars.
2240
2241 align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center'
2242 Alignment of the bars to the *x* coordinates:
2243
2244 - 'center': Center the base on the *x* positions.
2245 - 'edge': Align the left edges of the bars with the *x* positions.
2246
2247 To align the bars on the right edge pass a negative *width* and
2248 ``align='edge'``.
2249
2250 Returns
2251 -------
2252 `.BarContainer`
2253 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars.
2254
2255 Other Parameters
2256 ----------------
2257 color : color or list of color, optional
2258 The colors of the bar faces.
2259
2260 edgecolor : color or list of color, optional
2261 The colors of the bar edges.
2262
2263 linewidth : float or array-like, optional
2264 Width of the bar edge(s). If 0, don't draw edges.
2265
2266 tick_label : str or list of str, optional
2267 The tick labels of the bars.
2268 Default: None (Use default numeric labels.)
2269
2270 label : str or list of str, optional
2271 A single label is attached to the resulting `.BarContainer` as a
2272 label for the whole dataset.
2273 If a list is provided, it must be the same length as *x* and
2274 labels the individual bars. Repeated labels are not de-duplicated
2275 and will cause repeated label entries, so this is best used when
2276 bars also differ in style (e.g., by passing a list to *color*.)
2277
2278 xerr, yerr : float or array-like of shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional
2279 If not *None*, add horizontal / vertical errorbars to the bar tips.
2280 The values are +/- sizes relative to the data:
2281
2282 - scalar: symmetric +/- values for all bars
2283 - shape(N,): symmetric +/- values for each bar
2284 - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row
2285 contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper
2286 errors.
2287 - *None*: No errorbar. (Default)
2288
2289 See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features` for an example on
2290 the usage of *xerr* and *yerr*.
2291
2292 ecolor : color or list of color, default: 'black'
2293 The line color of the errorbars.
2294
2295 capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize`
2296 The length of the error bar caps in points.
2297
2298 error_kw : dict, optional
2299 Dictionary of keyword arguments to be passed to the
2300 `~.Axes.errorbar` method. Values of *ecolor* or *capsize* defined
2301 here take precedence over the independent keyword arguments.
2302
2303 log : bool, default: False
2304 If *True*, set the y-axis to be log scale.
2305
2306 data : indexable object, optional
2307 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
2308
2309 **kwargs : `.Rectangle` properties
2310
2311 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s
2312
2313 See Also
2314 --------
2315 barh : Plot a horizontal bar plot.
2316
2317 Notes
2318 -----
2319 Stacked bars can be achieved by passing individual *bottom* values per
2320 bar. See :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_stacked`.
2321 """
2322 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mpatches.Patch)
2323 color = kwargs.pop('color', None)
2324 if color is None:
2325 color = self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color()
2326 edgecolor = kwargs.pop('edgecolor', None)
2327 linewidth = kwargs.pop('linewidth', None)
2328 hatch = kwargs.pop('hatch', None)
2329
2330 # Because xerr and yerr will be passed to errorbar, most dimension
2331 # checking and processing will be left to the errorbar method.
2332 xerr = kwargs.pop('xerr', None)
2333 yerr = kwargs.pop('yerr', None)
2334 error_kw = kwargs.pop('error_kw', {})
2335 ezorder = error_kw.pop('zorder', None)
2336 if ezorder is None:
2337 ezorder = kwargs.get('zorder', None)
2338 if ezorder is not None:
2339 # If using the bar zorder, increment slightly to make sure
2340 # errorbars are drawn on top of bars
2341 ezorder += 0.01
2342 error_kw.setdefault('zorder', ezorder)
2343 ecolor = kwargs.pop('ecolor', 'k')
2344 capsize = kwargs.pop('capsize', mpl.rcParams["errorbar.capsize"])
2345 error_kw.setdefault('ecolor', ecolor)
2346 error_kw.setdefault('capsize', capsize)
2347
2348 # The keyword argument *orientation* is used by barh() to defer all
2349 # logic and drawing to bar(). It is considered internal and is
2350 # intentionally not mentioned in the docstring.
2351 orientation = kwargs.pop('orientation', 'vertical')
2352 _api.check_in_list(['vertical', 'horizontal'], orientation=orientation)
2353 log = kwargs.pop('log', False)
2354 label = kwargs.pop('label', '')
2355 tick_labels = kwargs.pop('tick_label', None)
2356
2357 y = bottom # Matches barh call signature.
2358 if orientation == 'vertical':
2359 if y is None:
2360 y = 0
2361 else: # horizontal
2362 if x is None:
2363 x = 0
2364
2365 if orientation == 'vertical':
2366 self._process_unit_info(
2367 [("x", x), ("y", height)], kwargs, convert=False)
2368 if log:
2369 self.set_yscale('log', nonpositive='clip')
2370 else: # horizontal
2371 self._process_unit_info(
2372 [("x", width), ("y", y)], kwargs, convert=False)
2373 if log:
2374 self.set_xscale('log', nonpositive='clip')
2375
2376 # lets do some conversions now since some types cannot be
2377 # subtracted uniformly
2378 if self.xaxis is not None:
2379 x0 = x
2380 x = np.asarray(self.convert_xunits(x))
2381 width = self._convert_dx(width, x0, x, self.convert_xunits)
2382 if xerr is not None:
2383 xerr = self._convert_dx(xerr, x0, x, self.convert_xunits)
2384 if self.yaxis is not None:
2385 y0 = y
2386 y = np.asarray(self.convert_yunits(y))
2387 height = self._convert_dx(height, y0, y, self.convert_yunits)
2388 if yerr is not None:
2389 yerr = self._convert_dx(yerr, y0, y, self.convert_yunits)
2390
2391 x, height, width, y, linewidth, hatch = np.broadcast_arrays(
2392 # Make args iterable too.
2393 np.atleast_1d(x), height, width, y, linewidth, hatch)
2394
2395 # Now that units have been converted, set the tick locations.
2396 if orientation == 'vertical':
2397 tick_label_axis = self.xaxis
2398 tick_label_position = x
2399 else: # horizontal
2400 tick_label_axis = self.yaxis
2401 tick_label_position = y
2402
2403 if not isinstance(label, str) and np.iterable(label):
2404 bar_container_label = '_nolegend_'
2405 patch_labels = label
2406 else:
2407 bar_container_label = label
2408 patch_labels = ['_nolegend_'] * len(x)
2409 if len(patch_labels) != len(x):
2410 raise ValueError(f'number of labels ({len(patch_labels)}) '
2411 f'does not match number of bars ({len(x)}).')
2412
2413 linewidth = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(linewidth))
2414 hatch = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(hatch))
2415 color = itertools.chain(itertools.cycle(mcolors.to_rgba_array(color)),
2416 # Fallback if color == "none".
2417 itertools.repeat('none'))
2418 if edgecolor is None:
2419 edgecolor = itertools.repeat(None)
2420 else:
2421 edgecolor = itertools.chain(
2422 itertools.cycle(mcolors.to_rgba_array(edgecolor)),
2423 # Fallback if edgecolor == "none".
2424 itertools.repeat('none'))
2425
2426 # We will now resolve the alignment and really have
2427 # left, bottom, width, height vectors
2428 _api.check_in_list(['center', 'edge'], align=align)
2429 if align == 'center':
2430 if orientation == 'vertical':
2431 try:
2432 left = x - width / 2
2433 except TypeError as e:
2434 raise TypeError(f'the dtypes of parameters x ({x.dtype}) '
2435 f'and width ({width.dtype}) '
2436 f'are incompatible') from e
2437 bottom = y
2438 else: # horizontal
2439 try:
2440 bottom = y - height / 2
2441 except TypeError as e:
2442 raise TypeError(f'the dtypes of parameters y ({y.dtype}) '
2443 f'and height ({height.dtype}) '
2444 f'are incompatible') from e
2445 left = x
2446 else: # edge
2447 left = x
2448 bottom = y
2449
2450 patches = []
2451 args = zip(left, bottom, width, height, color, edgecolor, linewidth,
2452 hatch, patch_labels)
2453 for l, b, w, h, c, e, lw, htch, lbl in args:
2454 r = mpatches.Rectangle(
2455 xy=(l, b), width=w, height=h,
2456 facecolor=c,
2457 edgecolor=e,
2458 linewidth=lw,
2459 label=lbl,
2460 hatch=htch,
2461 )
2462 r._internal_update(kwargs)
2463 r.get_path()._interpolation_steps = 100
2464 if orientation == 'vertical':
2465 r.sticky_edges.y.append(b)
2466 else: # horizontal
2467 r.sticky_edges.x.append(l)
2468 self.add_patch(r)
2469 patches.append(r)
2470
2471 if xerr is not None or yerr is not None:
2472 if orientation == 'vertical':
2473 # using list comps rather than arrays to preserve unit info
2474 ex = [l + 0.5 * w for l, w in zip(left, width)]
2475 ey = [b + h for b, h in zip(bottom, height)]
2476
2477 else: # horizontal
2478 # using list comps rather than arrays to preserve unit info
2479 ex = [l + w for l, w in zip(left, width)]
2480 ey = [b + 0.5 * h for b, h in zip(bottom, height)]
2481
2482 error_kw.setdefault("label", '_nolegend_')
2483
2484 errorbar = self.errorbar(ex, ey,
2485 yerr=yerr, xerr=xerr,
2486 fmt='none', **error_kw)
2487 else:
2488 errorbar = None
2489
2490 self._request_autoscale_view()
2491
2492 if orientation == 'vertical':
2493 datavalues = height
2494 else: # horizontal
2495 datavalues = width
2496
2497 bar_container = BarContainer(patches, errorbar, datavalues=datavalues,
2498 orientation=orientation,
2499 label=bar_container_label)
2500 self.add_container(bar_container)
2501
2502 if tick_labels is not None:
2503 tick_labels = np.broadcast_to(tick_labels, len(patches))
2504 tick_label_axis.set_ticks(tick_label_position)
2505 tick_label_axis.set_ticklabels(tick_labels)
2506
2507 return bar_container
2508

◆ bar_label()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.bar_label (   self,
  container,
  labels = None,
*  fmt = "%g",
  label_type = "edge",
  padding = 0,
**  kwargs 
) 
Label a bar plot.

Adds labels to bars in the given `.BarContainer`.
You may need to adjust the axis limits to fit the labels.

Parameters
----------
container : `.BarContainer`
    Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars, likely
    returned from `.bar` or `.barh`.

labels : array-like, optional
    A list of label texts, that should be displayed. If not given, the
    label texts will be the data values formatted with *fmt*.

fmt : str, default: '%g'
    A format string for the label.

label_type : {'edge', 'center'}, default: 'edge'
    The label type. Possible values:

    - 'edge': label placed at the end-point of the bar segment, and the
      value displayed will be the position of that end-point.
    - 'center': label placed in the center of the bar segment, and the
      value displayed will be the length of that segment.
      (useful for stacked bars, i.e.,
      :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_label_demo`)

padding : float, default: 0
    Distance of label from the end of the bar, in points.

**kwargs
    Any remaining keyword arguments are passed through to
    `.Axes.annotate`. The alignment parameters (
    *horizontalalignment* / *ha*, *verticalalignment* / *va*) are
    not supported because the labels are automatically aligned to
    the bars.

Returns
-------
list of `.Text`
    A list of `.Text` instances for the labels.
2628 padding=0, **kwargs):
2629 """
2630 Label a bar plot.
2631
2632 Adds labels to bars in the given `.BarContainer`.
2633 You may need to adjust the axis limits to fit the labels.
2634
2635 Parameters
2636 ----------
2637 container : `.BarContainer`
2638 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars, likely
2639 returned from `.bar` or `.barh`.
2640
2641 labels : array-like, optional
2642 A list of label texts, that should be displayed. If not given, the
2643 label texts will be the data values formatted with *fmt*.
2644
2645 fmt : str, default: '%g'
2646 A format string for the label.
2647
2648 label_type : {'edge', 'center'}, default: 'edge'
2649 The label type. Possible values:
2650
2651 - 'edge': label placed at the end-point of the bar segment, and the
2652 value displayed will be the position of that end-point.
2653 - 'center': label placed in the center of the bar segment, and the
2654 value displayed will be the length of that segment.
2655 (useful for stacked bars, i.e.,
2656 :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_label_demo`)
2657
2658 padding : float, default: 0
2659 Distance of label from the end of the bar, in points.
2660
2661 **kwargs
2662 Any remaining keyword arguments are passed through to
2663 `.Axes.annotate`. The alignment parameters (
2664 *horizontalalignment* / *ha*, *verticalalignment* / *va*) are
2665 not supported because the labels are automatically aligned to
2666 the bars.
2667
2668 Returns
2669 -------
2670 list of `.Text`
2671 A list of `.Text` instances for the labels.
2672 """
2673 for key in ['horizontalalignment', 'ha', 'verticalalignment', 'va']:
2674 if key in kwargs:
2675 raise ValueError(
2676 f"Passing {key!r} to bar_label() is not supported.")
2677
2678 a, b = self.yaxis.get_view_interval()
2679 y_inverted = a > b
2680 c, d = self.xaxis.get_view_interval()
2681 x_inverted = c > d
2682
2683 # want to know whether to put label on positive or negative direction
2684 # cannot use np.sign here because it will return 0 if x == 0
2685 def sign(x):
2686 return 1 if x >= 0 else -1
2687
2688 _api.check_in_list(['edge', 'center'], label_type=label_type)
2689
2690 bars = container.patches
2691 errorbar = container.errorbar
2692 datavalues = container.datavalues
2693 orientation = container.orientation
2694
2695 if errorbar:
2696 # check "ErrorbarContainer" for the definition of these elements
2697 lines = errorbar.lines # attribute of "ErrorbarContainer" (tuple)
2698 barlinecols = lines[2] # 0: data_line, 1: caplines, 2: barlinecols
2699 barlinecol = barlinecols[0] # the "LineCollection" of error bars
2700 errs = barlinecol.get_segments()
2701 else:
2702 errs = []
2703
2704 if labels is None:
2705 labels = []
2706
2707 annotations = []
2708
2709 for bar, err, dat, lbl in itertools.zip_longest(
2710 bars, errs, datavalues, labels
2711 ):
2712 (x0, y0), (x1, y1) = bar.get_bbox().get_points()
2713 xc, yc = (x0 + x1) / 2, (y0 + y1) / 2
2714
2715 if orientation == "vertical":
2716 extrema = max(y0, y1) if dat >= 0 else min(y0, y1)
2717 length = abs(y0 - y1)
2718 else: # horizontal
2719 extrema = max(x0, x1) if dat >= 0 else min(x0, x1)
2720 length = abs(x0 - x1)
2721
2722 if err is None or np.size(err) == 0:
2723 endpt = extrema
2724 elif orientation == "vertical":
2725 endpt = err[:, 1].max() if dat >= 0 else err[:, 1].min()
2726 else: # horizontal
2727 endpt = err[:, 0].max() if dat >= 0 else err[:, 0].min()
2728
2729 if label_type == "center":
2730 value = sign(dat) * length
2731 else: # edge
2732 value = extrema
2733
2734 if label_type == "center":
2735 xy = xc, yc
2736 else: # edge
2737 if orientation == "vertical":
2738 xy = xc, endpt
2739 else: # horizontal
2740 xy = endpt, yc
2741
2742 if orientation == "vertical":
2743 y_direction = -1 if y_inverted else 1
2744 xytext = 0, y_direction * sign(dat) * padding
2745 else: # horizontal
2746 x_direction = -1 if x_inverted else 1
2747 xytext = x_direction * sign(dat) * padding, 0
2748
2749 if label_type == "center":
2750 ha, va = "center", "center"
2751 else: # edge
2752 if orientation == "vertical":
2753 ha = 'center'
2754 if y_inverted:
2755 va = 'top' if dat > 0 else 'bottom' # also handles NaN
2756 else:
2757 va = 'top' if dat < 0 else 'bottom' # also handles NaN
2758 else: # horizontal
2759 if x_inverted:
2760 ha = 'right' if dat > 0 else 'left' # also handles NaN
2761 else:
2762 ha = 'right' if dat < 0 else 'left' # also handles NaN
2763 va = 'center'
2764
2765 if np.isnan(dat):
2766 lbl = ''
2767
2768 annotation = self.annotate(fmt % value if lbl is None else lbl,
2769 xy, xytext, textcoords="offset points",
2770 ha=ha, va=va, **kwargs)
2771 annotations.append(annotation)
2772
2773 return annotations
2774

◆ barbs()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.barbs (   self,
*  args,
**  kwargs 
) 
%(barbs_doc)s
5111 def barbs(self, *args, **kwargs):
5112 """%(barbs_doc)s"""
5113 # Make sure units are handled for x and y values
5114 args = self._quiver_units(args, kwargs)
5115 b = mquiver.Barbs(self, *args, **kwargs)
5116 self.add_collection(b, autolim=True)
5117 self._request_autoscale_view()
5118 return b
5119

◆ barh()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.barh (   self,
  y,
  width,
  height = 0.8,
  left = None,
*  align = "center",
  data = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
    Make a horizontal bar plot.

    The bars are positioned at *y* with the given *align*\ment. Their
    dimensions are given by *width* and *height*. The horizontal baseline
    is *left* (default 0).

    Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars
    or a sequence of values, one for each bar.

    Parameters
    ----------
    y : float or array-like
        The y coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the
        alignment of the bars to the coordinates.

    width : float or array-like
        The width(s) of the bars.

    height : float or array-like, default: 0.8
        The heights of the bars.

    left : float or array-like, default: 0
        The x coordinates of the left side(s) of the bars.

    align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center'
        Alignment of the base to the *y* coordinates*:

        - 'center': Center the bars on the *y* positions.
        - 'edge': Align the bottom edges of the bars with the *y*
          positions.

        To align the bars on the top edge pass a negative *height* and
        ``align='edge'``.

    Returns
    -------
    `.BarContainer`
        Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars.

    Other Parameters
    ----------------
    color : color or list of color, optional
        The colors of the bar faces.

    edgecolor : color or list of color, optional
        The colors of the bar edges.

    linewidth : float or array-like, optional
        Width of the bar edge(s). If 0, don't draw edges.

    tick_label : str or list of str, optional
        The tick labels of the bars.
        Default: None (Use default numeric labels.)

    label : str or list of str, optional
        A single label is attached to the resulting `.BarContainer` as a
        label for the whole dataset.
        If a list is provided, it must be the same length as *y* and
        labels the individual bars. Repeated labels are not de-duplicated
        and will cause repeated label entries, so this is best used when
        bars also differ in style (e.g., by passing a list to *color*.)

    xerr, yerr : float or array-like of shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional
        If not *None*, add horizontal / vertical errorbars to the bar tips.
        The values are +/- sizes relative to the data:

        - scalar: symmetric +/- values for all bars
        - shape(N,): symmetric +/- values for each bar
        - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row
          contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper
          errors.
        - *None*: No errorbar. (default)

        See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features` for an example on
        the usage of *xerr* and *yerr*.

    ecolor : color or list of color, default: 'black'
        The line color of the errorbars.

    capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize`
       The length of the error bar caps in points.

    error_kw : dict, optional
        Dictionary of keyword arguments to be passed to the
        `~.Axes.errorbar` method. Values of *ecolor* or *capsize* defined
        here take precedence over the independent keyword arguments.

    log : bool, default: False
        If ``True``, set the x-axis to be log scale.

    data : indexable object, optional
        If given, all parameters also accept a string ``s``, which is
        interpreted as ``data[s]`` (unless this raises an exception).

    **kwargs : `.Rectangle` properties

    %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s

    See Also
    --------
    bar : Plot a vertical bar plot.

    Notes
    -----
    Stacked bars can be achieved by passing individual *left* values per
    bar. See
    :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/horizontal_barchart_distribution`.
2512 data=None, **kwargs):
2513 r"""
2514 Make a horizontal bar plot.
2515
2516 The bars are positioned at *y* with the given *align*\ment. Their
2517 dimensions are given by *width* and *height*. The horizontal baseline
2518 is *left* (default 0).
2519
2520 Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars
2521 or a sequence of values, one for each bar.
2522
2523 Parameters
2524 ----------
2525 y : float or array-like
2526 The y coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the
2527 alignment of the bars to the coordinates.
2528
2529 width : float or array-like
2530 The width(s) of the bars.
2531
2532 height : float or array-like, default: 0.8
2533 The heights of the bars.
2534
2535 left : float or array-like, default: 0
2536 The x coordinates of the left side(s) of the bars.
2537
2538 align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center'
2539 Alignment of the base to the *y* coordinates*:
2540
2541 - 'center': Center the bars on the *y* positions.
2542 - 'edge': Align the bottom edges of the bars with the *y*
2543 positions.
2544
2545 To align the bars on the top edge pass a negative *height* and
2546 ``align='edge'``.
2547
2548 Returns
2549 -------
2550 `.BarContainer`
2551 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars.
2552
2553 Other Parameters
2554 ----------------
2555 color : color or list of color, optional
2556 The colors of the bar faces.
2557
2558 edgecolor : color or list of color, optional
2559 The colors of the bar edges.
2560
2561 linewidth : float or array-like, optional
2562 Width of the bar edge(s). If 0, don't draw edges.
2563
2564 tick_label : str or list of str, optional
2565 The tick labels of the bars.
2566 Default: None (Use default numeric labels.)
2567
2568 label : str or list of str, optional
2569 A single label is attached to the resulting `.BarContainer` as a
2570 label for the whole dataset.
2571 If a list is provided, it must be the same length as *y* and
2572 labels the individual bars. Repeated labels are not de-duplicated
