6829 self.set_yscale('log', nonpositive='clip')
6830
6831 if align == 'left':
6832 x -= 0.5*(bins[1]-bins[0])
6833 elif align == 'right':
6834 x += 0.5*(bins[1]-bins[0])
6835
6836 # If fill kwarg is set, it will be passed to the patch collection,
6837 # overriding this
6838 fill = (histtype == 'stepfilled')
6839
6840 xvals, yvals = [], []
6841 for m in tops:
6842 if stacked:
6843 # top of the previous polygon becomes the bottom
6844 y[2*len(bins)-1:] = y[1:2*len(bins)-1][::-1]
6845 # set the top of this polygon
6846 y[1:2*len(bins)-1:2] = y[2:2*len(bins):2] = m + bottom
6847
6848 # The starting point of the polygon has not yet been
6849 # updated. So far only the endpoint was adjusted. This
6850 # assignment closes the polygon. The redundant endpoint is
6851 # later discarded (for step and stepfilled).
6852 y[0] = y[-1]
6853
6854 if orientation == 'horizontal':
6855 xvals.append(y.copy())
6856 yvals.append(x.copy())
6857 else:
6858 xvals.append(x.copy())
6859 yvals.append(y.copy())
6860
6861 # stepfill is closed, step is not
6862 split = -1 if fill else 2 * len(bins)
6863 # add patches in reverse order so that when stacking,
6864 # items lower in the stack are plotted on top of
6865 # items higher in the stack
6866 for x, y, c in reversed(list(zip(xvals, yvals, color))):
6867 patches.append(self.fill(
6868 x[:split], y[:split],
6869 closed=True if fill else None,
6870 facecolor=c,
6871 edgecolor=None if fill else c,
6872 fill=fill if fill else None,
6873 zorder=None if fill else mlines.Line2D.zorder))
6874 for patch_list in patches:
6875 for patch in patch_list:
6876 if orientation == 'vertical':
6877 patch.sticky_edges.y.append(0)
6878 elif orientation == 'horizontal':
6879 patch.sticky_edges.x.append(0)
6880
6881 # we return patches, so put it back in the expected order
6882 patches.reverse()
6883
6884 # If None, make all labels None (via zip_longest below); otherwise,
6885 # cast each element to str, but keep a single str as it.
6886 labels = [] if label is None else np.atleast_1d(np.asarray(label, str))
6887 for patch, lbl in itertools.zip_longest(patches, labels):
6888 if patch:
6889 p = patch[0]
6890 p._internal_update(kwargs)
6891 if lbl is not None:
6892 p.set_label(lbl)
6893 for p in patch[1:]:
6894 p._internal_update(kwargs)
6895 p.set_label('_nolegend_')
6896
6897 if nx == 1:
6898 return tops[0], bins, patches[0]
6899 else:
6900 patch_type = ("BarContainer" if histtype.startswith("bar")
6901 else "list[Polygon]")
6902 return tops, bins, cbook.silent_list(patch_type, patches)
6903

◆ hist2d()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.hist2d (   self,
  x,
  y,
  bins = 10,
  range = None,
  density = False,
  weights = None,
  cmin = None,
  cmax = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Make a 2D histogram plot.

Parameters
----------
x, y : array-like, shape (n, )
    Input values

bins : None or int or [int, int] or array-like or [array, array]

    The bin specification:

    - If int, the number of bins for the two dimensions
      (nx=ny=bins).
    - If ``[int, int]``, the number of bins in each dimension
      (nx, ny = bins).
    - If array-like, the bin edges for the two dimensions
      (x_edges=y_edges=bins).
    - If ``[array, array]``, the bin edges in each dimension
      (x_edges, y_edges = bins).

    The default value is 10.

range : array-like shape(2, 2), optional
    The leftmost and rightmost edges of the bins along each dimension
    (if not specified explicitly in the bins parameters): ``[[xmin,
    xmax], [ymin, ymax]]``. All values outside of this range will be
    considered outliers and not tallied in the histogram.

density : bool, default: False
    Normalize histogram.  See the documentation for the *density*
    parameter of `~.Axes.hist` for more details.

weights : array-like, shape (n, ), optional
    An array of values w_i weighing each sample (x_i, y_i).

cmin, cmax : float, default: None
    All bins that has count less than *cmin* or more than *cmax* will
    not be displayed (set to NaN before passing to imshow) and these
    count values in the return value count histogram will also be set
    to nan upon return.

Returns
-------
h : 2D array
    The bi-dimensional histogram of samples x and y. Values in x are
    histogrammed along the first dimension and values in y are
    histogrammed along the second dimension.
xedges : 1D array
    The bin edges along the x axis.
yedges : 1D array
    The bin edges along the y axis.
image : `~.matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh`

Other Parameters
----------------
%(cmap_doc)s

%(norm_doc)s

%(vmin_vmax_doc)s

alpha : ``0 <= scalar <= 1`` or ``None``, optional
    The alpha blending value.

data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    Additional parameters are passed along to the
    `~.Axes.pcolormesh` method and `~matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh`
    constructor.

See Also
--------
hist : 1D histogram plotting
hexbin : 2D histogram with hexagonal bins

Notes
-----
- Currently ``hist2d`` calculates its own axis limits, and any limits
  previously set are ignored.
- Rendering the histogram with a logarithmic color scale is
  accomplished by passing a `.colors.LogNorm` instance to the *norm*
  keyword argument. Likewise, power-law normalization (similar
  in effect to gamma correction) can be accomplished with
  `.colors.PowerNorm`.
6984 cmin=None, cmax=None, **kwargs):
6985 """
6986 Make a 2D histogram plot.
6987
6988 Parameters
6989 ----------
6990 x, y : array-like, shape (n, )
6991 Input values
6992
6993 bins : None or int or [int, int] or array-like or [array, array]
6994
6995 The bin specification:
6996
6997 - If int, the number of bins for the two dimensions
6998 (nx=ny=bins).
6999 - If ``[int, int]``, the number of bins in each dimension
7000 (nx, ny = bins).
7001 - If array-like, the bin edges for the two dimensions
7002 (x_edges=y_edges=bins).
7003 - If ``[array, array]``, the bin edges in each dimension
7004 (x_edges, y_edges = bins).
7005
7006 The default value is 10.
7007
7008 range : array-like shape(2, 2), optional
7009 The leftmost and rightmost edges of the bins along each dimension
7010 (if not specified explicitly in the bins parameters): ``[[xmin,
7011 xmax], [ymin, ymax]]``. All values outside of this range will be
7012 considered outliers and not tallied in the histogram.
7013
7014 density : bool, default: False
7015 Normalize histogram. See the documentation for the *density*
7016 parameter of `~.Axes.hist` for more details.
7017
7018 weights : array-like, shape (n, ), optional
7019 An array of values w_i weighing each sample (x_i, y_i).
7020
7021 cmin, cmax : float, default: None
7022 All bins that has count less than *cmin* or more than *cmax* will
7023 not be displayed (set to NaN before passing to imshow) and these
7024 count values in the return value count histogram will also be set
7025 to nan upon return.
7026
7027 Returns
7028 -------
7029 h : 2D array
7030 The bi-dimensional histogram of samples x and y. Values in x are
7031 histogrammed along the first dimension and values in y are
7032 histogrammed along the second dimension.
7033 xedges : 1D array
7034 The bin edges along the x axis.
7035 yedges : 1D array
7036 The bin edges along the y axis.
7037 image : `~.matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh`
7038
7039 Other Parameters
7040 ----------------
7041 %(cmap_doc)s
7042
7043 %(norm_doc)s
7044
7045 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
7046
7047 alpha : ``0 <= scalar <= 1`` or ``None``, optional
7048 The alpha blending value.
7049
7050 data : indexable object, optional
7051 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
7052
7053 **kwargs
7054 Additional parameters are passed along to the
7055 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` method and `~matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh`
7056 constructor.
7057
7058 See Also
7059 --------
7060 hist : 1D histogram plotting
7061 hexbin : 2D histogram with hexagonal bins
7062
7063 Notes
7064 -----
7065 - Currently ``hist2d`` calculates its own axis limits, and any limits
7066 previously set are ignored.
7067 - Rendering the histogram with a logarithmic color scale is
7068 accomplished by passing a `.colors.LogNorm` instance to the *norm*
7069 keyword argument. Likewise, power-law normalization (similar
7070 in effect to gamma correction) can be accomplished with
7071 `.colors.PowerNorm`.
7072 """
7073
7074 h, xedges, yedges = np.histogram2d(x, y, bins=bins, range=range,
7075 density=density, weights=weights)
7076
7077 if cmin is not None:
7078 h[h < cmin] = None
7079 if cmax is not None:
7080 h[h > cmax] = None
7081
7082 pc = self.pcolormesh(xedges, yedges, h.T, **kwargs)
7083 self.set_xlim(xedges[0], xedges[-1])
7084 self.set_ylim(yedges[0], yedges[-1])
7085
7086 return h, xedges, yedges, pc
7087

◆ hlines()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.hlines (   self,
  y,
  xmin,
  xmax,
  colors = None,
  linestyles = 'solid',
  label = '',
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot horizontal lines at each *y* from *xmin* to *xmax*.

Parameters
----------
y : float or array-like
    y-indexes where to plot the lines.

xmin, xmax : float or array-like
    Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are
    provided, all lines will have the same length.

colors : list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color`

linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, optional

label : str, default: ''

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection`

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
**kwargs :  `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties.

See Also
--------
vlines : vertical lines
axhline : horizontal line across the Axes
1025 label='', **kwargs):
1026 """
1027 Plot horizontal lines at each *y* from *xmin* to *xmax*.
1028
1029 Parameters
1030 ----------
1031 y : float or array-like
1032 y-indexes where to plot the lines.
1033
1034 xmin, xmax : float or array-like
1035 Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are
1036 provided, all lines will have the same length.
1037
1038 colors : list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color`
1039
1040 linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, optional
1041
1042 label : str, default: ''
1043
1044 Returns
1045 -------
1046 `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection`
1047
1048 Other Parameters
1049 ----------------
1050 data : indexable object, optional
1051 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
1052 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties.
1053
1054 See Also
1055 --------
1056 vlines : vertical lines
1057 axhline : horizontal line across the Axes
1058 """
1059
1060 # We do the conversion first since not all unitized data is uniform
1061 xmin, xmax, y = self._process_unit_info(
1062 [("x", xmin), ("x", xmax), ("y", y)], kwargs)
1063
1064 if not np.iterable(y):
1065 y = [y]
1066 if not np.iterable(xmin):
1067 xmin = [xmin]
1068 if not np.iterable(xmax):
1069 xmax = [xmax]
1070
1071 # Create and combine masked_arrays from input
1072 y, xmin, xmax = cbook._combine_masks(y, xmin, xmax)
1073 y = np.ravel(y)
1074 xmin = np.ravel(xmin)
1075 xmax = np.ravel(xmax)
1076
1077 masked_verts = np.ma.empty((len(y), 2, 2))
1078 masked_verts[:, 0, 0] = xmin
1079 masked_verts[:, 0, 1] = y
1080 masked_verts[:, 1, 0] = xmax
1081 masked_verts[:, 1, 1] = y
1082
1083 lines = mcoll.LineCollection(masked_verts, colors=colors,
1084 linestyles=linestyles, label=label)
1085 self.add_collection(lines, autolim=False)
1086 lines._internal_update(kwargs)
1087
1088 if len(y) > 0:
1089 # Extreme values of xmin/xmax/y. Using masked_verts here handles
1090 # the case of y being a masked *object* array (as can be generated
1091 # e.g. by errorbar()), which would make nanmin/nanmax stumble.
1092 minx = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 0])
1093 maxx = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 0])
1094 miny = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 1])
1095 maxy = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 1])
1096 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy)
1097 self.update_datalim(corners)
1098 self._request_autoscale_view()
1099
1100 return lines
1101

◆ imshow()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.imshow (   self,
  X,
  cmap = None,
  norm = None,
  aspect = None,
  interpolation = None,
  alpha = None,
  vmin = None,
  vmax = None,
  origin = None,
  extent = None,
*  interpolation_stage = None,
  filternorm = True,
  filterrad = 4.0,
  resample = None,
  url = None,
**  kwargs 
)

plotting z(x, y): imshow, pcolor and relatives, contour 

Display data as an image, i.e., on a 2D regular raster.

The input may either be actual RGB(A) data, or 2D scalar data, which
will be rendered as a pseudocolor image. For displaying a grayscale
image set up the colormapping using the parameters
``cmap='gray', vmin=0, vmax=255``.

The number of pixels used to render an image is set by the Axes size
and the *dpi* of the figure. This can lead to aliasing artifacts when
the image is resampled because the displayed image size will usually
not match the size of *X* (see
:doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/image_antialiasing`).
The resampling can be controlled via the *interpolation* parameter
and/or :rc:`image.interpolation`.

Parameters
----------
X : array-like or PIL image
    The image data. Supported array shapes are:

    - (M, N): an image with scalar data. The values are mapped to
      colors using normalization and a colormap. See parameters *norm*,
      *cmap*, *vmin*, *vmax*.
    - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int).
    - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int),
      i.e. including transparency.

    The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of
    the image.

    Out-of-range RGB(A) values are clipped.

%(cmap_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).

%(norm_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).

%(vmin_vmax_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).

aspect : {'equal', 'auto'} or float, default: :rc:`image.aspect`
    The aspect ratio of the Axes.  This parameter is particularly
    relevant for images since it determines whether data pixels are
    square.

    This parameter is a shortcut for explicitly calling
    `.Axes.set_aspect`. See there for further details.

    - 'equal': Ensures an aspect ratio of 1. Pixels will be square
      (unless pixel sizes are explicitly made non-square in data
      coordinates using *extent*).
    - 'auto': The Axes is kept fixed and the aspect is adjusted so
      that the data fit in the Axes. In general, this will result in
      non-square pixels.

interpolation : str, default: :rc:`image.interpolation`
    The interpolation method used.

    Supported values are 'none', 'antialiased', 'nearest', 'bilinear',
    'bicubic', 'spline16', 'spline36', 'hanning', 'hamming', 'hermite',
    'kaiser', 'quadric', 'catrom', 'gaussian', 'bessel', 'mitchell',
    'sinc', 'lanczos', 'blackman'.

    If *interpolation* is 'none', then no interpolation is performed
    on the Agg, ps, pdf and svg backends. Other backends will fall back
    to 'nearest'. Note that most SVG renderers perform interpolation at
    rendering and that the default interpolation method they implement
    may differ.

    If *interpolation* is the default 'antialiased', then 'nearest'
    interpolation is used if the image is upsampled by more than a
    factor of three (i.e. the number of display pixels is at least
    three times the size of the data array).  If the upsampling rate is
    smaller than 3, or the image is downsampled, then 'hanning'
    interpolation is used to act as an anti-aliasing filter, unless the
    image happens to be upsampled by exactly a factor of two or one.

    See
    :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/interpolation_methods`
    for an overview of the supported interpolation methods, and
    :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/image_antialiasing` for
    a discussion of image antialiasing.

    Some interpolation methods require an additional radius parameter,
    which can be set by *filterrad*. Additionally, the antigrain image
    resize filter is controlled by the parameter *filternorm*.

interpolation_stage : {'data', 'rgba'}, default: 'data'
    If 'data', interpolation
    is carried out on the data provided by the user.  If 'rgba', the
    interpolation is carried out after the colormapping has been
    applied (visual interpolation).

alpha : float or array-like, optional
    The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
    If *alpha* is an array, the alpha blending values are applied pixel
    by pixel, and *alpha* must have the same shape as *X*.

origin : {'upper', 'lower'}, default: :rc:`image.origin`
    Place the [0, 0] index of the array in the upper left or lower
    left corner of the Axes. The convention (the default) 'upper' is
    typically used for matrices and images.

    Note that the vertical axis points upward for 'lower'
    but downward for 'upper'.

    See the :doc:`/tutorials/intermediate/imshow_extent` tutorial for
    examples and a more detailed description.

extent : floats (left, right, bottom, top), optional
    The bounding box in data coordinates that the image will fill.
    The image is stretched individually along x and y to fill the box.

    The default extent is determined by the following conditions.
    Pixels have unit size in data coordinates. Their centers are on
    integer coordinates, and their center coordinates range from 0 to
    columns-1 horizontally and from 0 to rows-1 vertically.

    Note that the direction of the vertical axis and thus the default
    values for top and bottom depend on *origin*:

    - For ``origin == 'upper'`` the default is
      ``(-0.5, numcols-0.5, numrows-0.5, -0.5)``.
    - For ``origin == 'lower'`` the default is
      ``(-0.5, numcols-0.5, -0.5, numrows-0.5)``.

    See the :doc:`/tutorials/intermediate/imshow_extent` tutorial for
    examples and a more detailed description.

filternorm : bool, default: True
    A parameter for the antigrain image resize filter (see the
    antigrain documentation).  If *filternorm* is set, the filter
    normalizes integer values and corrects the rounding errors. It
    doesn't do anything with the source floating point values, it
    corrects only integers according to the rule of 1.0 which means
    that any sum of pixel weights must be equal to 1.0.  So, the
    filter function must produce a graph of the proper shape.

filterrad : float > 0, default: 4.0
    The filter radius for filters that have a radius parameter, i.e.
    when interpolation is one of: 'sinc', 'lanczos' or 'blackman'.

resample : bool, default: :rc:`image.resample`
    When *True*, use a full resampling method.  When *False*, only
    resample when the output image is larger than the input image.

url : str, optional
    Set the url of the created `.AxesImage`. See `.Artist.set_url`.

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.image.AxesImage`

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs : `~matplotlib.artist.Artist` properties
    These parameters are passed on to the constructor of the
    `.AxesImage` artist.

See Also
--------
matshow : Plot a matrix or an array as an image.

Notes
-----
Unless *extent* is used, pixel centers will be located at integer
coordinates. In other words: the origin will coincide with the center
of pixel (0, 0).

There are two common representations for RGB images with an alpha
channel:

-   Straight (unassociated) alpha: R, G, and B channels represent the
    color of the pixel, disregarding its opacity.
-   Premultiplied (associated) alpha: R, G, and B channels represent
    the color of the pixel, adjusted for its opacity by multiplication.

`~matplotlib.pyplot.imshow` expects RGB images adopting the straight
(unassociated) alpha representation.
5405 resample=None, url=None, **kwargs):
5406 """
5407 Display data as an image, i.e., on a 2D regular raster.
5408
5409 The input may either be actual RGB(A) data, or 2D scalar data, which
5410 will be rendered as a pseudocolor image. For displaying a grayscale
5411 image set up the colormapping using the parameters
5412 ``cmap='gray', vmin=0, vmax=255``.
5413
5414 The number of pixels used to render an image is set by the Axes size
5415 and the *dpi* of the figure. This can lead to aliasing artifacts when
5416 the image is resampled because the displayed image size will usually
5417 not match the size of *X* (see
5418 :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/image_antialiasing`).
5419 The resampling can be controlled via the *interpolation* parameter
5420 and/or :rc:`image.interpolation`.
5421
5422 Parameters
5423 ----------
5424 X : array-like or PIL image
5425 The image data. Supported array shapes are:
5426
5427 - (M, N): an image with scalar data. The values are mapped to
5428 colors using normalization and a colormap. See parameters *norm*,
5429 *cmap*, *vmin*, *vmax*.
5430 - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int).
5431 - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int),
5432 i.e. including transparency.
5433
5434 The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of
5435 the image.
5436
5437 Out-of-range RGB(A) values are clipped.
5438
5439 %(cmap_doc)s
5440
5441 This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).
5442
5443 %(norm_doc)s
5444
5445 This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).
5446
5447 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
5448
5449 This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).
5450
5451 aspect : {'equal', 'auto'} or float, default: :rc:`image.aspect`
5452 The aspect ratio of the Axes. This parameter is particularly
5453 relevant for images since it determines whether data pixels are
5454 square.
5455
5456 This parameter is a shortcut for explicitly calling
5457 `.Axes.set_aspect`. See there for further details.
5458
5459 - 'equal': Ensures an aspect ratio of 1. Pixels will be square
5460 (unless pixel sizes are explicitly made non-square in data
5461 coordinates using *extent*).
5462 - 'auto': The Axes is kept fixed and the aspect is adjusted so
5463 that the data fit in the Axes. In general, this will result in
5464 non-square pixels.
5465
5466 interpolation : str, default: :rc:`image.interpolation`
5467 The interpolation method used.
5468
5469 Supported values are 'none', 'antialiased', 'nearest', 'bilinear',
5470 'bicubic', 'spline16', 'spline36', 'hanning', 'hamming', 'hermite',
5471 'kaiser', 'quadric', 'catrom', 'gaussian', 'bessel', 'mitchell',
5472 'sinc', 'lanczos', 'blackman'.
5473
5474 If *interpolation* is 'none', then no interpolation is performed
5475 on the Agg, ps, pdf and svg backends. Other backends will fall back
5476 to 'nearest'. Note that most SVG renderers perform interpolation at
5477 rendering and that the default interpolation method they implement
5478 may differ.
5479
5480 If *interpolation* is the default 'antialiased', then 'nearest'
5481 interpolation is used if the image is upsampled by more than a
5482 factor of three (i.e. the number of display pixels is at least
5483 three times the size of the data array). If the upsampling rate is
5484 smaller than 3, or the image is downsampled, then 'hanning'
5485 interpolation is used to act as an anti-aliasing filter, unless the
5486 image happens to be upsampled by exactly a factor of two or one.
5487
5488 See
5489 :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/interpolation_methods`
5490 for an overview of the supported interpolation methods, and
5491 :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/image_antialiasing` for
5492 a discussion of image antialiasing.
5493
5494 Some interpolation methods require an additional radius parameter,
5495 which can be set by *filterrad*. Additionally, the antigrain image
5496 resize filter is controlled by the parameter *filternorm*.
5497
5498 interpolation_stage : {'data', 'rgba'}, default: 'data'
5499 If 'data', interpolation
5500 is carried out on the data provided by the user. If 'rgba', the
5501 interpolation is carried out after the colormapping has been
5502 applied (visual interpolation).
5503
5504 alpha : float or array-like, optional
5505 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
5506 If *alpha* is an array, the alpha blending values are applied pixel
5507 by pixel, and *alpha* must have the same shape as *X*.
5508
5509 origin : {'upper', 'lower'}, default: :rc:`image.origin`
5510 Place the [0, 0] index of the array in the upper left or lower
5511 left corner of the Axes. The convention (the default) 'upper' is
5512 typically used for matrices and images.
5513
5514 Note that the vertical axis points upward for 'lower'
5515 but downward for 'upper'.
5516
5517 See the :doc:`/tutorials/intermediate/imshow_extent` tutorial for
5518 examples and a more detailed description.
5519
5520 extent : floats (left, right, bottom, top), optional
5521 The bounding box in data coordinates that the image will fill.
5522 The image is stretched individually along x and y to fill the box.
5523
5524 The default extent is determined by the following conditions.
5525 Pixels have unit size in data coordinates. Their centers are on
5526 integer coordinates, and their center coordinates range from 0 to
5527 columns-1 horizontally and from 0 to rows-1 vertically.
5528
5529 Note that the direction of the vertical axis and thus the default
5530 values for top and bottom depend on *origin*:
5531
5532 - For ``origin == 'upper'`` the default is
5533 ``(-0.5, numcols-0.5, numrows-0.5, -0.5)``.
5534 - For ``origin == 'lower'`` the default is
5535 ``(-0.5, numcols-0.5, -0.5, numrows-0.5)``.
5536
5537 See the :doc:`/tutorials/intermediate/imshow_extent` tutorial for
5538 examples and a more detailed description.
5539
5540 filternorm : bool, default: True
5541 A parameter for the antigrain image resize filter (see the
5542 antigrain documentation). If *filternorm* is set, the filter
5543 normalizes integer values and corrects the rounding errors. It
5544 doesn't do anything with the source floating point values, it
5545 corrects only integers according to the rule of 1.0 which means
5546 that any sum of pixel weights must be equal to 1.0. So, the
5547 filter function must produce a graph of the proper shape.
5548
5549 filterrad : float > 0, default: 4.0
5550 The filter radius for filters that have a radius parameter, i.e.
5551 when interpolation is one of: 'sinc', 'lanczos' or 'blackman'.
5552
5553 resample : bool, default: :rc:`image.resample`
5554 When *True*, use a full resampling method. When *False*, only
5555 resample when the output image is larger than the input image.
5556
5557 url : str, optional
5558 Set the url of the created `.AxesImage`. See `.Artist.set_url`.
5559
5560 Returns
5561 -------
5562 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage`
5563
5564 Other Parameters
5565 ----------------
5566 data : indexable object, optional
5567 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
5568
5569 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.artist.Artist` properties
5570 These parameters are passed on to the constructor of the
5571 `.AxesImage` artist.
5572
5573 See Also
5574 --------
5575 matshow : Plot a matrix or an array as an image.
5576
5577 Notes
5578 -----
5579 Unless *extent* is used, pixel centers will be located at integer
5580 coordinates. In other words: the origin will coincide with the center
5581 of pixel (0, 0).
5582
5583 There are two common representations for RGB images with an alpha
5584 channel:
5585
5586 - Straight (unassociated) alpha: R, G, and B channels represent the
5587 color of the pixel, disregarding its opacity.
5588 - Premultiplied (associated) alpha: R, G, and B channels represent
5589 the color of the pixel, adjusted for its opacity by multiplication.
5590
5591 `~matplotlib.pyplot.imshow` expects RGB images adopting the straight
5592 (unassociated) alpha representation.
5593 """
5594 if aspect is None:
5595 aspect = mpl.rcParams['image.aspect']
5596 self.set_aspect(aspect)
5597 im = mimage.AxesImage(self, cmap=cmap, norm=norm,
5598 interpolation=interpolation, origin=origin,
5599 extent=extent, filternorm=filternorm,
5600 filterrad=filterrad, resample=resample,
5601 interpolation_stage=interpolation_stage,
5602 **kwargs)
5603
5604 im.set_data(X)
5605 im.set_alpha(alpha)
5606 if im.get_clip_path() is None:
5607 # image does not already have clipping set, clip to axes patch
5608 im.set_clip_path(self.patch)
5609 im._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
5610 im.set_url(url)
5611
5612 # update ax.dataLim, and, if autoscaling, set viewLim
5613 # to tightly fit the image, regardless of dataLim.
5614 im.set_extent(im.get_extent())
5615
5616 self.add_image(im)
5617 return im
5618

◆ indicate_inset()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.indicate_inset (   self,
  bounds,
  inset_ax = None,
*  transform = None,
  facecolor = 'none',
  edgecolor = '0.5',
  alpha = 0.5,
  zorder = 4.99,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add an inset indicator to the Axes.  This is a rectangle on the plot
at the position indicated by *bounds* that optionally has lines that
connect the rectangle to an inset Axes (`.Axes.inset_axes`).

Warnings
--------
This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.

Parameters
----------
bounds : [x0, y0, width, height]
    Lower-left corner of rectangle to be marked, and its width
    and height.

inset_ax : `.Axes`
    An optional inset Axes to draw connecting lines to.  Two lines are
    drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners
    chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box.

transform : `.Transform`
    Transform for the rectangle coordinates. Defaults to
    `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in Axes-relative
    coordinates.

facecolor : color, default: 'none'
    Facecolor of the rectangle.

edgecolor : color, default: '0.5'
    Color of the rectangle and color of the connecting lines.

alpha : float, default: 0.5
    Transparency of the rectangle and connector lines.

zorder : float, default: 4.99
    Drawing order of the rectangle and connector lines.  The default,
    4.99, is just below the default level of inset Axes.

**kwargs
    Other keyword arguments are passed on to the `.Rectangle` patch:

    %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s

Returns
-------
rectangle_patch : `.patches.Rectangle`
     The indicator frame.

connector_lines : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch`
    The four connector lines connecting to (lower_left, upper_left,
    lower_right upper_right) corners of *inset_ax*. Two lines are
    set with visibility to *False*,  but the user can set the
    visibility to True if the automatic choice is not deemed correct.
392 zorder=4.99, **kwargs):
393 """
394 Add an inset indicator to the Axes. This is a rectangle on the plot
395 at the position indicated by *bounds* that optionally has lines that
396 connect the rectangle to an inset Axes (`.Axes.inset_axes`).
397
398 Warnings
399 --------
400 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.
401
402 Parameters
403 ----------
404 bounds : [x0, y0, width, height]
405 Lower-left corner of rectangle to be marked, and its width
406 and height.
407
408 inset_ax : `.Axes`
409 An optional inset Axes to draw connecting lines to. Two lines are
410 drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners
411 chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box.
412
413 transform : `.Transform`
414 Transform for the rectangle coordinates. Defaults to
415 `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in Axes-relative
416 coordinates.
417
418 facecolor : color, default: 'none'
419 Facecolor of the rectangle.
420
421 edgecolor : color, default: '0.5'
422 Color of the rectangle and color of the connecting lines.
423
424 alpha : float, default: 0.5
425 Transparency of the rectangle and connector lines.
426
427 zorder : float, default: 4.99
428 Drawing order of the rectangle and connector lines. The default,
429 4.99, is just below the default level of inset Axes.
430
431 **kwargs
432 Other keyword arguments are passed on to the `.Rectangle` patch:
433
434 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s
435
436 Returns
437 -------
438 rectangle_patch : `.patches.Rectangle`
439 The indicator frame.
440
441 connector_lines : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch`
442 The four connector lines connecting to (lower_left, upper_left,
443 lower_right upper_right) corners of *inset_ax*. Two lines are
444 set with visibility to *False*, but the user can set the
445 visibility to True if the automatic choice is not deemed correct.
446
447 """
448 # to make the axes connectors work, we need to apply the aspect to
449 # the parent axes.
450 self.apply_aspect()
451
452 if transform is None:
453 transform = self.transData
454 kwargs.setdefault('label', '_indicate_inset')
455
456 x, y, width, height = bounds
457 rectangle_patch = mpatches.Rectangle(
458 (x, y), width, height,
459 facecolor=facecolor, edgecolor=edgecolor, alpha=alpha,
460 zorder=zorder, transform=transform, **kwargs)
461 self.add_patch(rectangle_patch)
462
463 connects = []
464
465 if inset_ax is not None:
466 # connect the inset_axes to the rectangle
467 for xy_inset_ax in [(0, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 1)]:
468 # inset_ax positions are in axes coordinates
469 # The 0, 1 values define the four edges if the inset_ax
470 # lower_left, upper_left, lower_right upper_right.
471 ex, ey = xy_inset_ax
472 if self.xaxis.get_inverted():
473 ex = 1 - ex
474 if self.yaxis.get_inverted():
475 ey = 1 - ey
476 xy_data = x + ex * width, y + ey * height
477 p = mpatches.ConnectionPatch(
478 xyA=xy_inset_ax, coordsA=inset_ax.transAxes,
479 xyB=xy_data, coordsB=self.transData,
480 arrowstyle="-", zorder=zorder,
481 edgecolor=edgecolor, alpha=alpha)
482 connects.append(p)
483 self.add_patch(p)
484
485 # decide which two of the lines to keep visible....
486 pos = inset_ax.get_position()
487 bboxins = pos.transformed(self.figure.transSubfigure)
488 rectbbox = mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds(
489 *bounds
490 ).transformed(transform)
491 x0 = rectbbox.x0 < bboxins.x0
492 x1 = rectbbox.x1 < bboxins.x1
493 y0 = rectbbox.y0 < bboxins.y0
494 y1 = rectbbox.y1 < bboxins.y1
495 connects[0].set_visible(x0 ^ y0)
496 connects[1].set_visible(x0 == y1)
497 connects[2].set_visible(x1 == y0)
498 connects[3].set_visible(x1 ^ y1)
499
500 return rectangle_patch, tuple(connects) if connects else None
501

◆ indicate_inset_zoom()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.indicate_inset_zoom (   self,
  inset_ax,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add an inset indicator rectangle to the Axes based on the axis
limits for an *inset_ax* and draw connectors between *inset_ax*
and the rectangle.

Warnings
--------
This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.

Parameters
----------
inset_ax : `.Axes`
    Inset Axes to draw connecting lines to.  Two lines are
    drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners
    chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box.

**kwargs
    Other keyword arguments are passed on to `.Axes.indicate_inset`

Returns
-------
rectangle_patch : `.patches.Rectangle`
     Rectangle artist.

connector_lines : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch`
    Each of four connector lines coming from the rectangle drawn on
    this axis, in the order lower left, upper left, lower right,
    upper right.
    Two are set with visibility to *False*,  but the user can
    set the visibility to *True* if the automatic choice is not deemed
    correct.
502 def indicate_inset_zoom(self, inset_ax, **kwargs):
503 """
504 Add an inset indicator rectangle to the Axes based on the axis
505 limits for an *inset_ax* and draw connectors between *inset_ax*
506 and the rectangle.
507
508 Warnings
509 --------
510 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.
511
512 Parameters
513 ----------
514 inset_ax : `.Axes`
515 Inset Axes to draw connecting lines to. Two lines are
516 drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners
517 chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box.
518
519 **kwargs
520 Other keyword arguments are passed on to `.Axes.indicate_inset`
521
522 Returns
523 -------
524 rectangle_patch : `.patches.Rectangle`
525 Rectangle artist.
526
527 connector_lines : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch`
528 Each of four connector lines coming from the rectangle drawn on
529 this axis, in the order lower left, upper left, lower right,
530 upper right.
531 Two are set with visibility to *False*, but the user can
532 set the visibility to *True* if the automatic choice is not deemed
533 correct.
534 """
535
536 xlim = inset_ax.get_xlim()
537 ylim = inset_ax.get_ylim()
538 rect = (xlim[0], ylim[0], xlim[1] - xlim[0], ylim[1] - ylim[0])
539 return self.indicate_inset(rect, inset_ax, **kwargs)
540

◆ inset_axes()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.inset_axes (   self,
  bounds,
*  transform = None,
  zorder = 5,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add a child inset Axes to this existing Axes.

Warnings
--------
This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.

Parameters
----------
bounds : [x0, y0, width, height]
    Lower-left corner of inset Axes, and its width and height.

transform : `.Transform`
    Defaults to `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in
    Axes-relative coordinates.

projection : {None, 'aitoff', 'hammer', 'lambert', 'mollweide', \
'polar', 'rectilinear', str}, optional
    The projection type of the inset `~.axes.Axes`. *str* is the name
    of a custom projection, see `~matplotlib.projections`. The default
    None results in a 'rectilinear' projection.

polar : bool, default: False
    If True, equivalent to projection='polar'.

axes_class : subclass type of `~.axes.Axes`, optional
    The `.axes.Axes` subclass that is instantiated.  This parameter
    is incompatible with *projection* and *polar*.  See
    :ref:`axisartist_users-guide-index` for examples.

zorder : number
    Defaults to 5 (same as `.Axes.legend`).  Adjust higher or lower
    to change whether it is above or below data plotted on the
    parent Axes.

**kwargs
    Other keyword arguments are passed on to the inset Axes class.

Returns
-------
ax
    The created `~.axes.Axes` instance.

Examples
--------
This example makes two inset Axes, the first is in Axes-relative
coordinates, and the second in data-coordinates::

    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    ax.plot(range(10))
    axin1 = ax.inset_axes([0.8, 0.1, 0.15, 0.15])
    axin2 = ax.inset_axes(
            [5, 7, 2.3, 2.3], transform=ax.transData)
314 def inset_axes(self, bounds, *, transform=None, zorder=5, **kwargs):
315 """
316 Add a child inset Axes to this existing Axes.
317
318 Warnings
319 --------
320 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.
321
322 Parameters
323 ----------
324 bounds : [x0, y0, width, height]
325 Lower-left corner of inset Axes, and its width and height.
326
327 transform : `.Transform`
328 Defaults to `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in
329 Axes-relative coordinates.
330
331 projection : {None, 'aitoff', 'hammer', 'lambert', 'mollweide', \
332'polar', 'rectilinear', str}, optional
333 The projection type of the inset `~.axes.Axes`. *str* is the name
334 of a custom projection, see `~matplotlib.projections`. The default
335 None results in a 'rectilinear' projection.
336
337 polar : bool, default: False
338 If True, equivalent to projection='polar'.
339
340 axes_class : subclass type of `~.axes.Axes`, optional
341 The `.axes.Axes` subclass that is instantiated. This parameter
342 is incompatible with *projection* and *polar*. See
343 :ref:`axisartist_users-guide-index` for examples.
344
345 zorder : number
346 Defaults to 5 (same as `.Axes.legend`). Adjust higher or lower
347 to change whether it is above or below data plotted on the
348 parent Axes.
349
350 **kwargs
351 Other keyword arguments are passed on to the inset Axes class.
352
353 Returns
354 -------
355 ax
356 The created `~.axes.Axes` instance.
357
358 Examples
359 --------
360 This example makes two inset Axes, the first is in Axes-relative
361 coordinates, and the second in data-coordinates::
362
363 fig, ax = plt.subplots()
364 ax.plot(range(10))
365 axin1 = ax.inset_axes([0.8, 0.1, 0.15, 0.15])
366 axin2 = ax.inset_axes(
367 [5, 7, 2.3, 2.3], transform=ax.transData)
368
369 """
370 if transform is None:
371 transform = self.transAxes
372 kwargs.setdefault('label', 'inset_axes')
373
374 # This puts the rectangle into figure-relative coordinates.
375 inset_locator = _TransformedBoundsLocator(bounds, transform)
376 bounds = inset_locator(self, None).bounds
377 projection_class, pkw = self.figure._process_projection_requirements(
378 bounds, **kwargs)
379 inset_ax = projection_class(self.figure, bounds, zorder=zorder, **pkw)
380
381 # this locator lets the axes move if in data coordinates.
382 # it gets called in `ax.apply_aspect() (of all places)
383 inset_ax.set_axes_locator(inset_locator)
384
385 self.add_child_axes(inset_ax)
386
387 return inset_ax
388

◆ legend()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.legend (   self,
*  args,
**  kwargs 
) 
Place a legend on the Axes.

Call signatures::

    legend()
    legend(handles, labels)
    legend(handles=handles)
    legend(labels)

The call signatures correspond to the following different ways to use
this method:

**1. Automatic detection of elements to be shown in the legend**

The elements to be added to the legend are automatically determined,
when you do not pass in any extra arguments.

In this case, the labels are taken from the artist. You can specify
them either at artist creation or by calling the
:meth:`~.Artist.set_label` method on the artist::

    ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='Inline label')
    ax.legend()

or::

    line, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3])
    line.set_label('Label via method')
    ax.legend()

.. note::
    Specific artists can be excluded from the automatic legend element
    selection by using a label starting with an underscore, "_".
    A string starting with an underscore is the default label for all
    artists, so calling `.Axes.legend` without any arguments and
    without setting the labels manually will result in no legend being
    drawn.


**2. Explicitly listing the artists and labels in the legend**

For full control of which artists have a legend entry, it is possible
to pass an iterable of legend artists followed by an iterable of
legend labels respectively::

    ax.legend([line1, line2, line3], ['label1', 'label2', 'label3'])


**3. Explicitly listing the artists in the legend**

This is similar to 2, but the labels are taken from the artists'
label properties. Example::

    line1, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label1')
    line2, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label2')
    ax.legend(handles=[line1, line2])


**4. Labeling existing plot elements**

.. admonition:: Discouraged

    This call signature is discouraged, because the relation between
    plot elements and labels is only implicit by their order and can
    easily be mixed up.

To make a legend for all artists on an Axes, call this function with
an iterable of strings, one for each legend item. For example::

    ax.plot([1, 2, 3])
    ax.plot([5, 6, 7])
    ax.legend(['First line', 'Second line'])


Parameters
----------
handles : sequence of `.Artist`, optional
    A list of Artists (lines, patches) to be added to the legend.
    Use this together with *labels*, if you need full control on what
    is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above
    is not sufficient.

    The length of handles and labels should be the same in this
    case. If they are not, they are truncated to the smaller length.

labels : list of str, optional
    A list of labels to show next to the artists.
    Use this together with *handles*, if you need full control on what
    is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above
    is not sufficient.

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.legend.Legend`

Other Parameters
----------------
%(_legend_kw_doc)s

See Also
--------
.Figure.legend

Notes
-----
Some artists are not supported by this function.  See
:doc:`/tutorials/intermediate/legend_guide` for details.

Examples
--------
.. plot:: gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/legend.py
187 def legend(self, *args, **kwargs):
188 """
189 Place a legend on the Axes.
190
191 Call signatures::
192
193 legend()
194 legend(handles, labels)
195 legend(handles=handles)
196 legend(labels)
197
198 The call signatures correspond to the following different ways to use
199 this method:
200
201 **1. Automatic detection of elements to be shown in the legend**
202
203 The elements to be added to the legend are automatically determined,
204 when you do not pass in any extra arguments.
205
206 In this case, the labels are taken from the artist. You can specify
207 them either at artist creation or by calling the
208 :meth:`~.Artist.set_label` method on the artist::
209
210 ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='Inline label')
211 ax.legend()
212
213 or::
214
215 line, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3])
216 line.set_label('Label via method')
217 ax.legend()
218
219 .. note::
220 Specific artists can be excluded from the automatic legend element
221 selection by using a label starting with an underscore, "_".
222 A string starting with an underscore is the default label for all
223 artists, so calling `.Axes.legend` without any arguments and
224 without setting the labels manually will result in no legend being
225 drawn.
226
227
228 **2. Explicitly listing the artists and labels in the legend**
229
230 For full control of which artists have a legend entry, it is possible
231 to pass an iterable of legend artists followed by an iterable of
232 legend labels respectively::
233
234 ax.legend([line1, line2, line3], ['label1', 'label2', 'label3'])
235
236
237 **3. Explicitly listing the artists in the legend**
238
239 This is similar to 2, but the labels are taken from the artists'
240 label properties. Example::
241
242 line1, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label1')
243 line2, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label2')
244 ax.legend(handles=[line1, line2])
245
246
247 **4. Labeling existing plot elements**
248
249 .. admonition:: Discouraged
250
251 This call signature is discouraged, because the relation between
252 plot elements and labels is only implicit by their order and can
253 easily be mixed up.
254
255 To make a legend for all artists on an Axes, call this function with
256 an iterable of strings, one for each legend item. For example::
257
258 ax.plot([1, 2, 3])
259 ax.plot([5, 6, 7])
260 ax.legend(['First line', 'Second line'])
261
262
263 Parameters
264 ----------
265 handles : sequence of `.Artist`, optional
266 A list of Artists (lines, patches) to be added to the legend.
267 Use this together with *labels*, if you need full control on what
268 is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above
269 is not sufficient.
270
271 The length of handles and labels should be the same in this
272 case. If they are not, they are truncated to the smaller length.
273
274 labels : list of str, optional
275 A list of labels to show next to the artists.
276 Use this together with *handles*, if you need full control on what
277 is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above
278 is not sufficient.
279
280 Returns
281 -------
282 `~matplotlib.legend.Legend`
283
284 Other Parameters
285 ----------------
286 %(_legend_kw_doc)s
287
288 See Also
289 --------
290 .Figure.legend
291
292 Notes
293 -----
294 Some artists are not supported by this function. See
295 :doc:`/tutorials/intermediate/legend_guide` for details.
296
297 Examples
298 --------
299 .. plot:: gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/legend.py
300 """
301 handles, labels, extra_args, kwargs = mlegend._parse_legend_args(
302 [self],
303 *args,
304 **kwargs)
305 if len(extra_args):
306 raise TypeError('legend only accepts two non-keyword arguments')
307 self.legend_ = mlegend.Legend(self, handles, labels, **kwargs)
308 self.legend_._remove_method = self._remove_legend
309 return self.legend_
310

◆ loglog()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.loglog (   self,
*  args,
**  kwargs 
) 
Make a plot with log scaling on both the x and y axis.

Call signatures::

    loglog([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs)
    loglog([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)

This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes
both the x-axis and the y-axis to log scaling. All of the concepts and
parameters of plot can be used here as well.

The additional parameters *base*, *subs* and *nonpositive* control the
x/y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale` and
`.Axes.set_yscale`. To use different properties on the x-axis and the
y-axis, use e.g.
``ax.set_xscale("log", base=10); ax.set_yscale("log", base=2)``.

Parameters
----------
base : float, default: 10
    Base of the logarithm.

subs : sequence, optional
    The location of the minor ticks. If *None*, reasonable locations
    are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
    plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale`/`.Axes.set_yscale` for details.

nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask'
    Non-positive values can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a very
    small positive number.

**kwargs
    All parameters supported by `.plot`.

Returns
-------
list of `.Line2D`
    Objects representing the plotted data.
1754 def loglog(self, *args, **kwargs):
1755 """
1756 Make a plot with log scaling on both the x and y axis.
1757
1758 Call signatures::
1759
1760 loglog([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs)
1761 loglog([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)
1762
1763 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes
1764 both the x-axis and the y-axis to log scaling. All of the concepts and
1765 parameters of plot can be used here as well.
1766
1767 The additional parameters *base*, *subs* and *nonpositive* control the
1768 x/y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale` and
1769 `.Axes.set_yscale`. To use different properties on the x-axis and the
1770 y-axis, use e.g.
1771 ``ax.set_xscale("log", base=10); ax.set_yscale("log", base=2)``.
1772
1773 Parameters
1774 ----------
1775 base : float, default: 10
1776 Base of the logarithm.
1777
1778 subs : sequence, optional
1779 The location of the minor ticks. If *None*, reasonable locations
1780 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
1781 plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale`/`.Axes.set_yscale` for details.
1782
1783 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask'
1784 Non-positive values can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a very
1785 small positive number.
1786
1787 **kwargs
1788 All parameters supported by `.plot`.
1789
1790 Returns
1791 -------
1792 list of `.Line2D`
1793 Objects representing the plotted data.
1794 """
1795 dx = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items()
1796 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive',
1797 'basex', 'subsx', 'nonposx']}
1798 self.set_xscale('log', **dx)
1799 dy = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items()
1800 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive',
1801 'basey', 'subsy', 'nonposy']}
1802 self.set_yscale('log', **dy)
1803 return self.plot(
1804 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in {*dx, *dy}})
1805

◆ magnitude_spectrum()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.magnitude_spectrum (   self,
  x,
  Fs = None,
  Fc = None,
  window = None,
  pad_to = None,
  sides = None,
  scale = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot the magnitude spectrum.

Compute the magnitude spectrum of *x*.  Data is padded to a
length of *pad_to* and the windowing function *window* is applied to
the signal.

Parameters
----------
x : 1-D array or sequence
    Array or sequence containing the data.

%(Spectral)s

%(Single_Spectrum)s

scale : {'default', 'linear', 'dB'}
    The scaling of the values in the *spec*.  'linear' is no scaling.
    'dB' returns the values in dB scale, i.e., the dB amplitude
    (20 * log10). 'default' is 'linear'.

Fc : int, default: 0
    The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
    plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
    and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.

Returns
-------
spectrum : 1-D array
    The values for the magnitude spectrum before scaling (real valued).

freqs : 1-D array
    The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*.

line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
    The line created by this function.

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
psd
    Plots the power spectral density.
angle_spectrum
    Plots the angles of the corresponding frequencies.
phase_spectrum
    Plots the phase (unwrapped angle) of the corresponding frequencies.
specgram
    Can plot the magnitude spectrum of segments within the signal in a
    colormap.
7305 **kwargs):
7306 """
7307 Plot the magnitude spectrum.
7308
7309 Compute the magnitude spectrum of *x*. Data is padded to a
7310 length of *pad_to* and the windowing function *window* is applied to
7311 the signal.
7312
7313 Parameters
7314 ----------
7315 x : 1-D array or sequence
7316 Array or sequence containing the data.
7317
7318 %(Spectral)s
7319
7320 %(Single_Spectrum)s
7321
7322 scale : {'default', 'linear', 'dB'}
7323 The scaling of the values in the *spec*. 'linear' is no scaling.
7324 'dB' returns the values in dB scale, i.e., the dB amplitude
7325 (20 * log10). 'default' is 'linear'.
7326
7327 Fc : int, default: 0
7328 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
7329 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
7330 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.
7331
7332 Returns
7333 -------
7334 spectrum : 1-D array
7335 The values for the magnitude spectrum before scaling (real valued).
7336
7337 freqs : 1-D array
7338 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*.
7339
7340 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
7341 The line created by this function.
7342
7343 Other Parameters
7344 ----------------
7345 data : indexable object, optional
7346 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
7347
7348 **kwargs
7349 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:
7350
7351 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
7352
7353 See Also
7354 --------
7355 psd
7356 Plots the power spectral density.
7357 angle_spectrum
7358 Plots the angles of the corresponding frequencies.
7359 phase_spectrum
7360 Plots the phase (unwrapped angle) of the corresponding frequencies.
7361 specgram
7362 Can plot the magnitude spectrum of segments within the signal in a
7363 colormap.
7364 """
7365 if Fc is None:
7366 Fc = 0
7367
7368 spec, freqs = mlab.magnitude_spectrum(x=x, Fs=Fs, window=window,
7369 pad_to=pad_to, sides=sides)
7370 freqs += Fc
7371
7372 yunits = _api.check_getitem(
7373 {None: 'energy', 'default': 'energy', 'linear': 'energy',
7374 'dB': 'dB'},
7375 scale=scale)
7376 if yunits == 'energy':
7377 Z = spec
7378 else: # yunits == 'dB'
7379 Z = 20. * np.log10(spec)
7380
7381 line, = self.plot(freqs, Z, **kwargs)
7382 self.set_xlabel('Frequency')
7383 self.set_ylabel('Magnitude (%s)' % yunits)
7384
7385 return spec, freqs, line
7386

◆ matshow()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.matshow (   self,
  Z,
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot the values of a 2D matrix or array as color-coded image.

The matrix will be shown the way it would be printed, with the first
row at the top.  Row and column numbering is zero-based.

Parameters
----------
Z : (M, N) array-like
    The matrix to be displayed.

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.image.AxesImage`

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.imshow` arguments

See Also
--------
imshow : More general function to plot data on a 2D regular raster.

Notes
-----
This is just a convenience function wrapping `.imshow` to set useful
defaults for displaying a matrix. In particular:

- Set ``origin='upper'``.
- Set ``interpolation='nearest'``.
- Set ``aspect='equal'``.
- Ticks are placed to the left and above.
- Ticks are formatted to show integer indices.
7887 def matshow(self, Z, **kwargs):
7888 """
7889 Plot the values of a 2D matrix or array as color-coded image.
7890
7891 The matrix will be shown the way it would be printed, with the first
7892 row at the top. Row and column numbering is zero-based.
7893
7894 Parameters
7895 ----------
7896 Z : (M, N) array-like
7897 The matrix to be displayed.
7898
7899 Returns
7900 -------
7901 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage`
7902
7903 Other Parameters
7904 ----------------
7905 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.imshow` arguments
7906
7907 See Also
7908 --------
7909 imshow : More general function to plot data on a 2D regular raster.
7910
7911 Notes
7912 -----
7913 This is just a convenience function wrapping `.imshow` to set useful
7914 defaults for displaying a matrix. In particular:
7915
7916 - Set ``origin='upper'``.
7917 - Set ``interpolation='nearest'``.
7918 - Set ``aspect='equal'``.
7919 - Ticks are placed to the left and above.
7920 - Ticks are formatted to show integer indices.
7921
7922 """
7923 Z = np.asanyarray(Z)
7924 kw = {'origin': 'upper',
7925 'interpolation': 'nearest',
7926 'aspect': 'equal', # (already the imshow default)
7927 **kwargs}
7928 im = self.imshow(Z, **kw)
7929 self.title.set_y(1.05)
7930 self.xaxis.tick_top()
7931 self.xaxis.set_ticks_position('both')
7932 self.xaxis.set_major_locator(
7933 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True))
7934 self.yaxis.set_major_locator(
7935 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True))
7936 return im
7937

◆ pcolor()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.pcolor (   self,
*  args,
  shading = None,
  alpha = None,
  norm = None,
  cmap = None,
  vmin = None,
  vmax = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
    Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.

    Call signature::

        pcolor([X, Y,] C, **kwargs)

    *X* and *Y* can be used to specify the corners of the quadrilaterals.

    .. hint::

        ``pcolor()`` can be very slow for large arrays. In most
        cases you should use the similar but much faster
        `~.Axes.pcolormesh` instead. See
        :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
        <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>` for a discussion of the
        differences.

    Parameters
    ----------
    C : 2D array-like
        The color-mapped values.  Color-mapping is controlled by *cmap*,
        *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*.

    X, Y : array-like, optional
        The coordinates of the corners of quadrilaterals of a pcolormesh::

            (X[i+1, j], Y[i+1, j])       (X[i+1, j+1], Y[i+1, j+1])
                                  +-----+
                                  |     |
                                  +-----+
                (X[i, j], Y[i, j])       (X[i, j+1], Y[i, j+1])

        Note that the column index corresponds to the x-coordinate, and
        the row index corresponds to y. For details, see the
        :ref:`Notes <axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation>` section below.

        If ``shading='flat'`` the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be one
        greater than those of *C*, and the quadrilateral is colored due
        to the value at ``C[i, j]``.  If *X*, *Y* and *C* have equal
        dimensions, a warning will be raised and the last row and column
        of *C* will be ignored.

        If ``shading='nearest'``, the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
        the same as those of *C* (if not, a ValueError will be raised). The
        color ``C[i, j]`` will be centered on ``(X[i, j], Y[i, j])``.

        If *X* and/or *Y* are 1-D arrays or column vectors they will be
        expanded as needed into the appropriate 2D arrays, making a
        rectangular grid.

    shading : {'flat', 'nearest', 'auto'}, default: :rc:`pcolor.shading`
        The fill style for the quadrilateral. Possible values:

        - 'flat': A solid color is used for each quad. The color of the
          quad (i, j), (i+1, j), (i, j+1), (i+1, j+1) is given by
          ``C[i, j]``. The dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
          one greater than those of *C*; if they are the same as *C*,
          then a deprecation warning is raised, and the last row
          and column of *C* are dropped.
        - 'nearest': Each grid point will have a color centered on it,
          extending halfway between the adjacent grid centers.  The
          dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*.
        - 'auto': Choose 'flat' if dimensions of *X* and *Y* are one
          larger than *C*.  Choose 'nearest' if dimensions are the same.

        See :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/pcolormesh_grids`
        for more description.

    %(cmap_doc)s

    %(norm_doc)s

    %(vmin_vmax_doc)s

    edgecolors : {'none', None, 'face', color, color sequence}, optional
        The color of the edges. Defaults to 'none'. Possible values:

        - 'none' or '': No edge.
        - *None*: :rc:`patch.edgecolor` will be used. Note that currently
          :rc:`patch.force_edgecolor` has to be True for this to work.
        - 'face': Use the adjacent face color.
        - A color or sequence of colors will set the edge color.

        The singular form *edgecolor* works as an alias.

    alpha : float, default: None
        The alpha blending value of the face color, between 0 (transparent)
        and 1 (opaque). Note: The edgecolor is currently not affected by
        this.

    snap : bool, default: False
        Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.

    Returns
    -------
    `matplotlib.collections.Collection`

    Other Parameters
    ----------------
    antialiaseds : bool, default: False
        The default *antialiaseds* is False if the default
        *edgecolors*\ ="none" is used.  This eliminates artificial lines
        at patch boundaries, and works regardless of the value of alpha.
        If *edgecolors* is not "none", then the default *antialiaseds*
        is taken from :rc:`patch.antialiased`.
        Stroking the edges may be preferred if *alpha* is 1, but will
        cause artifacts otherwise.

    data : indexable object, optional
        DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

    **kwargs
        Additionally, the following arguments are allowed. They are passed
        along to the `~matplotlib.collections.PolyCollection` constructor:

    %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s

    See Also
    --------
    pcolormesh : for an explanation of the differences between
        pcolor and pcolormesh.
    imshow : If *X* and *Y* are each equidistant, `~.Axes.imshow` can be a
        faster alternative.

    Notes
    -----
    **Masked arrays**

    *X*, *Y* and *C* may be masked arrays. If either ``C[i, j]``, or one
    of the vertices surrounding ``C[i, j]`` (*X* or *Y* at
    ``[i, j], [i+1, j], [i, j+1], [i+1, j+1]``) is masked, nothing is
    plotted.

    .. _axes-pcolor-grid-orientation:

    **Grid orientation**

    The grid orientation follows the standard matrix convention: An array
    *C* with shape (nrows, ncolumns) is plotted with the column number as
    *X* and the row number as *Y*.
5750 vmin=None, vmax=None, **kwargs):
5751 r"""
5752 Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.
5753
5754 Call signature::
5755
5756 pcolor([X, Y,] C, **kwargs)
5757
5758 *X* and *Y* can be used to specify the corners of the quadrilaterals.
5759
5760 .. hint::
5761
5762 ``pcolor()`` can be very slow for large arrays. In most
5763 cases you should use the similar but much faster
5764 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` instead. See
5765 :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
5766 <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>` for a discussion of the
5767 differences.
5768
5769 Parameters
5770 ----------
5771 C : 2D array-like
5772 The color-mapped values. Color-mapping is controlled by *cmap*,
5773 *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*.
5774
5775 X, Y : array-like, optional
5776 The coordinates of the corners of quadrilaterals of a pcolormesh::
5777
5778 (X[i+1, j], Y[i+1, j]) (X[i+1, j+1], Y[i+1, j+1])
5779 +-----+
5780 | |
5781 +-----+
5782 (X[i, j], Y[i, j]) (X[i, j+1], Y[i, j+1])
5783
5784 Note that the column index corresponds to the x-coordinate, and
5785 the row index corresponds to y. For details, see the
5786 :ref:`Notes <axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation>` section below.
5787
5788 If ``shading='flat'`` the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be one
5789 greater than those of *C*, and the quadrilateral is colored due
5790 to the value at ``C[i, j]``. If *X*, *Y* and *C* have equal
5791 dimensions, a warning will be raised and the last row and column
5792 of *C* will be ignored.
5793
5794 If ``shading='nearest'``, the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
5795 the same as those of *C* (if not, a ValueError will be raised). The
5796 color ``C[i, j]`` will be centered on ``(X[i, j], Y[i, j])``.
5797
5798 If *X* and/or *Y* are 1-D arrays or column vectors they will be
5799 expanded as needed into the appropriate 2D arrays, making a
5800 rectangular grid.
5801
5802 shading : {'flat', 'nearest', 'auto'}, default: :rc:`pcolor.shading`
5803 The fill style for the quadrilateral. Possible values:
5804
5805 - 'flat': A solid color is used for each quad. The color of the
5806 quad (i, j), (i+1, j), (i, j+1), (i+1, j+1) is given by
5807 ``C[i, j]``. The dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
5808 one greater than those of *C*; if they are the same as *C*,
5809 then a deprecation warning is raised, and the last row
5810 and column of *C* are dropped.
5811 - 'nearest': Each grid point will have a color centered on it,
5812 extending halfway between the adjacent grid centers. The
5813 dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*.
5814 - 'auto': Choose 'flat' if dimensions of *X* and *Y* are one
5815 larger than *C*. Choose 'nearest' if dimensions are the same.
5816
5817 See :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/pcolormesh_grids`
5818 for more description.
5819
5820 %(cmap_doc)s
5821
5822 %(norm_doc)s
5823
5824 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
5825
5826 edgecolors : {'none', None, 'face', color, color sequence}, optional
5827 The color of the edges. Defaults to 'none'. Possible values:
5828
5829 - 'none' or '': No edge.
5830 - *None*: :rc:`patch.edgecolor` will be used. Note that currently
5831 :rc:`patch.force_edgecolor` has to be True for this to work.
5832 - 'face': Use the adjacent face color.
5833 - A color or sequence of colors will set the edge color.
5834
5835 The singular form *edgecolor* works as an alias.
5836
5837 alpha : float, default: None
5838 The alpha blending value of the face color, between 0 (transparent)
5839 and 1 (opaque). Note: The edgecolor is currently not affected by
5840 this.
5841
5842 snap : bool, default: False
5843 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.
5844
5845 Returns
5846 -------
5847 `matplotlib.collections.Collection`
5848
5849 Other Parameters
5850 ----------------
5851 antialiaseds : bool, default: False
5852 The default *antialiaseds* is False if the default
5853 *edgecolors*\ ="none" is used. This eliminates artificial lines
5854 at patch boundaries, and works regardless of the value of alpha.
5855 If *edgecolors* is not "none", then the default *antialiaseds*
5856 is taken from :rc:`patch.antialiased`.
5857 Stroking the edges may be preferred if *alpha* is 1, but will
5858 cause artifacts otherwise.
5859
5860 data : indexable object, optional
5861 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
5862
5863 **kwargs
5864 Additionally, the following arguments are allowed. They are passed
5865 along to the `~matplotlib.collections.PolyCollection` constructor:
5866
5867 %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s
5868
5869 See Also
5870 --------
5871 pcolormesh : for an explanation of the differences between
5872 pcolor and pcolormesh.
5873 imshow : If *X* and *Y* are each equidistant, `~.Axes.imshow` can be a
5874 faster alternative.
5875
5876 Notes
5877 -----
5878 **Masked arrays**
5879
5880 *X*, *Y* and *C* may be masked arrays. If either ``C[i, j]``, or one
5881 of the vertices surrounding ``C[i, j]`` (*X* or *Y* at
5882 ``[i, j], [i+1, j], [i, j+1], [i+1, j+1]``) is masked, nothing is
5883 plotted.
5884
5885 .. _axes-pcolor-grid-orientation:
5886
5887 **Grid orientation**
5888
5889 The grid orientation follows the standard matrix convention: An array
5890 *C* with shape (nrows, ncolumns) is plotted with the column number as
5891 *X* and the row number as *Y*.
5892 """
5893
5894 if shading is None:
5895 shading = mpl.rcParams['pcolor.shading']
5896 shading = shading.lower()
5897 X, Y, C, shading = self._pcolorargs('pcolor', *args, shading=shading,
5898 kwargs=kwargs)
5899 Ny, Nx = X.shape
5900
5901 # convert to MA, if necessary.
5902 C = ma.asarray(C)
5903 X = ma.asarray(X)
5904 Y = ma.asarray(Y)
5905
5906 mask = ma.getmaskarray(X) + ma.getmaskarray(Y)
5907 xymask = (mask[0:-1, 0:-1] + mask[1:, 1:] +
5908 mask[0:-1, 1:] + mask[1:, 0:-1])
5909 # don't plot if C or any of the surrounding vertices are masked.
5910 mask = ma.getmaskarray(C) + xymask
5911
5912 unmask = ~mask
5913 X1 = ma.filled(X[:-1, :-1])[unmask]
5914 Y1 = ma.filled(Y[:-1, :-1])[unmask]
5915 X2 = ma.filled(X[1:, :-1])[unmask]
5916 Y2 = ma.filled(Y[1:, :-1])[unmask]
5917 X3 = ma.filled(X[1:, 1:])[unmask]
5918 Y3 = ma.filled(Y[1:, 1:])[unmask]
5919 X4 = ma.filled(X[:-1, 1:])[unmask]
5920 Y4 = ma.filled(Y[:-1, 1:])[unmask]
5921 npoly = len(X1)
5922
5923 xy = np.stack([X1, Y1, X2, Y2, X3, Y3, X4, Y4, X1, Y1], axis=-1)
5924 verts = xy.reshape((npoly, 5, 2))
5925
5926 C = ma.filled(C[:Ny - 1, :Nx - 1])[unmask]
5927
5928 linewidths = (0.25,)
5929 if 'linewidth' in kwargs:
5930 kwargs['linewidths'] = kwargs.pop('linewidth')
5931 kwargs.setdefault('linewidths', linewidths)
5932
5933 if 'edgecolor' in kwargs:
5934 kwargs['edgecolors'] = kwargs.pop('edgecolor')
5935 ec = kwargs.setdefault('edgecolors', 'none')
5936
5937 # aa setting will default via collections to patch.antialiased
5938 # unless the boundary is not stroked, in which case the
5939 # default will be False; with unstroked boundaries, aa
5940 # makes artifacts that are often disturbing.
5941 if 'antialiased' in kwargs:
5942 kwargs['antialiaseds'] = kwargs.pop('antialiased')
5943 if 'antialiaseds' not in kwargs and cbook._str_lower_equal(ec, "none"):
5944 kwargs['antialiaseds'] = False
5945
5946 kwargs.setdefault('snap', False)
5947
5948 collection = mcoll.PolyCollection(
5949 verts, array=C, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, alpha=alpha, **kwargs)
5950 collection._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
5951 self._pcolor_grid_deprecation_helper()
5952
5953 x = X.compressed()
5954 y = Y.compressed()
5955
5956 # Transform from native to data coordinates?
5957 t = collection._transform
5958 if (not isinstance(t, mtransforms.Transform) and
5959 hasattr(t, '_as_mpl_transform')):
5960 t = t._as_mpl_transform(self.axes)
5961
5962 if t and any(t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)):
5963 trans_to_data = t - self.transData
5964 pts = np.vstack([x, y]).T.astype(float)
5965 transformed_pts = trans_to_data.transform(pts)
5966 x = transformed_pts[..., 0]
5967 y = transformed_pts[..., 1]
5968
5969 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
5970
5971 minx = np.min(x)
5972 maxx = np.max(x)
5973 miny = np.min(y)
5974 maxy = np.max(y)
5975 collection.sticky_edges.x[:] = [minx, maxx]
5976 collection.sticky_edges.y[:] = [miny, maxy]
5977 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy)
5978 self.update_datalim(corners)
5979 self._request_autoscale_view()
5980 return collection
5981

◆ pcolorfast()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.pcolorfast (   self,
*  args,
  alpha = None,
  norm = None,
  cmap = None,
  vmin = None,
  vmax = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.

Call signature::

  ax.pcolorfast([X, Y], C, /, **kwargs)

This method is similar to `~.Axes.pcolor` and `~.Axes.pcolormesh`.
It's designed to provide the fastest pcolor-type plotting with the
Agg backend. To achieve this, it uses different algorithms internally
depending on the complexity of the input grid (regular rectangular,
non-regular rectangular or arbitrary quadrilateral).

.. warning::

   This method is experimental. Compared to `~.Axes.pcolor` or
   `~.Axes.pcolormesh` it has some limitations:

   - It supports only flat shading (no outlines)
   - It lacks support for log scaling of the axes.
   - It does not have a have a pyplot wrapper.

Parameters
----------
C : array-like
    The image data. Supported array shapes are:

    - (M, N): an image with scalar data.  Color-mapping is controlled
      by *cmap*, *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*.
    - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int).
    - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int),
      i.e. including transparency.

    The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of
    the image.

    This parameter can only be passed positionally.

X, Y : tuple or array-like, default: ``(0, N)``, ``(0, M)``
    *X* and *Y* are used to specify the coordinates of the
    quadrilaterals. There are different ways to do this:

    - Use tuples ``X=(xmin, xmax)`` and ``Y=(ymin, ymax)`` to define
      a *uniform rectangular grid*.

      The tuples define the outer edges of the grid. All individual
      quadrilaterals will be of the same size. This is the fastest
      version.

    - Use 1D arrays *X*, *Y* to specify a *non-uniform rectangular
      grid*.

      In this case *X* and *Y* have to be monotonic 1D arrays of length
      *N+1* and *M+1*, specifying the x and y boundaries of the cells.

      The speed is intermediate. Note: The grid is checked, and if
      found to be uniform the fast version is used.

    - Use 2D arrays *X*, *Y* if you need an *arbitrary quadrilateral
      grid* (i.e. if the quadrilaterals are not rectangular).

      In this case *X* and *Y* are 2D arrays with shape (M + 1, N + 1),
      specifying the x and y coordinates of the corners of the colored
      quadrilaterals.

      This is the most general, but the slowest to render.  It may
      produce faster and more compact output using ps, pdf, and
      svg backends, however.

    These arguments can only be passed positionally.

%(cmap_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).

%(norm_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).

%(vmin_vmax_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).

alpha : float, default: None
    The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).

snap : bool, default: False
    Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.

Returns
-------
`.AxesImage` or `.PcolorImage` or `.QuadMesh`
    The return type depends on the type of grid:

    - `.AxesImage` for a regular rectangular grid.
    - `.PcolorImage` for a non-regular rectangular grid.
    - `.QuadMesh` for a non-rectangular grid.

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    Supported additional parameters depend on the type of grid.
    See return types of *image* for further description.
6203 vmax=None, **kwargs):
6204 """
6205 Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.
6206
6207 Call signature::
6208
6209 ax.pcolorfast([X, Y], C, /, **kwargs)
6210
6211 This method is similar to `~.Axes.pcolor` and `~.Axes.pcolormesh`.
6212 It's designed to provide the fastest pcolor-type plotting with the
6213 Agg backend. To achieve this, it uses different algorithms internally
6214 depending on the complexity of the input grid (regular rectangular,
6215 non-regular rectangular or arbitrary quadrilateral).
6216
6217 .. warning::
6218
6219 This method is experimental. Compared to `~.Axes.pcolor` or
6220 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` it has some limitations:
6221
6222 - It supports only flat shading (no outlines)
6223 - It lacks support for log scaling of the axes.
6224 - It does not have a have a pyplot wrapper.
6225
6226 Parameters
6227 ----------
6228 C : array-like
6229 The image data. Supported array shapes are:
6230
6231 - (M, N): an image with scalar data. Color-mapping is controlled
6232 by *cmap*, *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*.
6233 - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int).
6234 - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int),
6235 i.e. including transparency.
6236
6237 The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of
6238 the image.
6239
6240 This parameter can only be passed positionally.
6241
6242 X, Y : tuple or array-like, default: ``(0, N)``, ``(0, M)``
6243 *X* and *Y* are used to specify the coordinates of the
6244 quadrilaterals. There are different ways to do this:
6245
6246 - Use tuples ``X=(xmin, xmax)`` and ``Y=(ymin, ymax)`` to define
6247 a *uniform rectangular grid*.
6248
6249 The tuples define the outer edges of the grid. All individual
6250 quadrilaterals will be of the same size. This is the fastest
6251 version.
6252
6253 - Use 1D arrays *X*, *Y* to specify a *non-uniform rectangular
6254 grid*.
6255
6256 In this case *X* and *Y* have to be monotonic 1D arrays of length
6257 *N+1* and *M+1*, specifying the x and y boundaries of the cells.
6258
6259 The speed is intermediate. Note: The grid is checked, and if
6260 found to be uniform the fast version is used.
6261
6262 - Use 2D arrays *X*, *Y* if you need an *arbitrary quadrilateral
6263 grid* (i.e. if the quadrilaterals are not rectangular).
6264
6265 In this case *X* and *Y* are 2D arrays with shape (M + 1, N + 1),
6266 specifying the x and y coordinates of the corners of the colored
6267 quadrilaterals.
6268
6269 This is the most general, but the slowest to render. It may
6270 produce faster and more compact output using ps, pdf, and
6271 svg backends, however.
6272
6273 These arguments can only be passed positionally.
6274
6275 %(cmap_doc)s
6276
6277 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).
6278
6279 %(norm_doc)s
6280
6281 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).
6282
6283 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
6284
6285 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).
6286
6287 alpha : float, default: None
6288 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
6289
6290 snap : bool, default: False
6291 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.
6292
6293 Returns
6294 -------
6295 `.AxesImage` or `.PcolorImage` or `.QuadMesh`
6296 The return type depends on the type of grid:
6297
6298 - `.AxesImage` for a regular rectangular grid.
6299 - `.PcolorImage` for a non-regular rectangular grid.
6300 - `.QuadMesh` for a non-rectangular grid.
6301
6302 Other Parameters
6303 ----------------
6304 data : indexable object, optional
6305 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
6306
6307 **kwargs
6308 Supported additional parameters depend on the type of grid.
6309 See return types of *image* for further description.
6310 """
6311
6312 C = args[-1]
6313 nr, nc = np.shape(C)[:2]
6314 if len(args) == 1:
6315 style = "image"
6316 x = [0, nc]
6317 y = [0, nr]
6318 elif len(args) == 3:
6319 x, y = args[:2]
6320 x = np.asarray(x)
6321 y = np.asarray(y)
6322 if x.ndim == 1 and y.ndim == 1:
6323 if x.size == 2 and y.size == 2:
6324 style = "image"
6325 else:
6326 dx = np.diff(x)
6327 dy = np.diff(y)
6328 if (np.ptp(dx) < 0.01 * abs(dx.mean()) and
6329 np.ptp(dy) < 0.01 * abs(dy.mean())):
6330 style = "image"
6331 else:
6332 style = "pcolorimage"
6333 elif x.ndim == 2 and y.ndim == 2:
6334 style = "quadmesh"
6335 else:
6336 raise TypeError("arguments do not match valid signatures")
6337 else:
6338 raise TypeError("need 1 argument or 3 arguments")
6339
6340 if style == "quadmesh":
6341 # data point in each cell is value at lower left corner
6342 coords = np.stack([x, y], axis=-1)
6343 if np.ndim(C) == 2:
6344 qm_kwargs = {"array": np.ma.ravel(C)}
6345 elif np.ndim(C) == 3:
6346 qm_kwargs = {"color": np.ma.reshape(C, (-1, C.shape[-1]))}
6347 else:
6348 raise ValueError("C must be 2D or 3D")
6349 collection = mcoll.QuadMesh(
6350 coords, **qm_kwargs,
6351 alpha=alpha, cmap=cmap, norm=norm,
6352 antialiased=False, edgecolors="none")
6353 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
6354 xl, xr, yb, yt = x.min(), x.max(), y.min(), y.max()
6355 ret = collection
6356
6357 else: # It's one of the two image styles.
6358 extent = xl, xr, yb, yt = x[0], x[-1], y[0], y[-1]
6359 if style == "image":
6360 im = mimage.AxesImage(
6361 self, cmap=cmap, norm=norm,
6362 data=C, alpha=alpha, extent=extent,
6363 interpolation='nearest', origin='lower',
6364 **kwargs)
6365 elif style == "pcolorimage":
6366 im = mimage.PcolorImage(
