6367 self, x, y, C,
6368 cmap=cmap, norm=norm, alpha=alpha, extent=extent,
6369 **kwargs)
6370 self.add_image(im)
6371 ret = im
6372
6373 if np.ndim(C) == 2: # C.ndim == 3 is RGB(A) so doesn't need scaling.
6374 ret._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
6375
6376 if ret.get_clip_path() is None:
6377 # image does not already have clipping set, clip to axes patch
6378 ret.set_clip_path(self.patch)
6379
6380 ret.sticky_edges.x[:] = [xl, xr]
6381 ret.sticky_edges.y[:] = [yb, yt]
6382 self.update_datalim(np.array([[xl, yb], [xr, yt]]))
6383 self._request_autoscale_view(tight=True)
6384 return ret
6385

◆ pcolormesh()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.pcolormesh (   self,
*  args,
  alpha = None,
  norm = None,
  cmap = None,
  vmin = None,
  vmax = None,
  shading = None,
  antialiased = False,
**  kwargs 
) 
Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.

Call signature::

    pcolormesh([X, Y,] C, **kwargs)

*X* and *Y* can be used to specify the corners of the quadrilaterals.

.. hint::

   `~.Axes.pcolormesh` is similar to `~.Axes.pcolor`. It is much faster
   and preferred in most cases. For a detailed discussion on the
   differences see :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
   <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>`.

Parameters
----------
C : 2D array-like
    The color-mapped values.  Color-mapping is controlled by *cmap*,
    *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*.

X, Y : array-like, optional
    The coordinates of the corners of quadrilaterals of a pcolormesh::

        (X[i+1, j], Y[i+1, j])       (X[i+1, j+1], Y[i+1, j+1])
                              +-----+
                              |     |
                              +-----+
            (X[i, j], Y[i, j])       (X[i, j+1], Y[i, j+1])

    Note that the column index corresponds to the x-coordinate, and
    the row index corresponds to y. For details, see the
    :ref:`Notes <axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation>` section below.

    If ``shading='flat'`` the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be one
    greater than those of *C*, and the quadrilateral is colored due
    to the value at ``C[i, j]``.  If *X*, *Y* and *C* have equal
    dimensions, a warning will be raised and the last row and column
    of *C* will be ignored.

    If ``shading='nearest'`` or ``'gouraud'``, the dimensions of *X*
    and *Y* should be the same as those of *C* (if not, a ValueError
    will be raised).  For ``'nearest'`` the color ``C[i, j]`` is
    centered on ``(X[i, j], Y[i, j])``.  For ``'gouraud'``, a smooth
    interpolation is caried out between the quadrilateral corners.

    If *X* and/or *Y* are 1-D arrays or column vectors they will be
    expanded as needed into the appropriate 2D arrays, making a
    rectangular grid.

%(cmap_doc)s

%(norm_doc)s

%(vmin_vmax_doc)s

edgecolors : {'none', None, 'face', color, color sequence}, optional
    The color of the edges. Defaults to 'none'. Possible values:

    - 'none' or '': No edge.
    - *None*: :rc:`patch.edgecolor` will be used. Note that currently
      :rc:`patch.force_edgecolor` has to be True for this to work.
    - 'face': Use the adjacent face color.
    - A color or sequence of colors will set the edge color.

    The singular form *edgecolor* works as an alias.

alpha : float, default: None
    The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).

shading : {'flat', 'nearest', 'gouraud', 'auto'}, optional
    The fill style for the quadrilateral; defaults to
    'flat' or :rc:`pcolor.shading`. Possible values:

    - 'flat': A solid color is used for each quad. The color of the
      quad (i, j), (i+1, j), (i, j+1), (i+1, j+1) is given by
      ``C[i, j]``. The dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
      one greater than those of *C*; if they are the same as *C*,
      then a deprecation warning is raised, and the last row
      and column of *C* are dropped.
    - 'nearest': Each grid point will have a color centered on it,
      extending halfway between the adjacent grid centers.  The
      dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*.
    - 'gouraud': Each quad will be Gouraud shaded: The color of the
      corners (i', j') are given by ``C[i', j']``. The color values of
      the area in between is interpolated from the corner values.
      The dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*. When
      Gouraud shading is used, *edgecolors* is ignored.
    - 'auto': Choose 'flat' if dimensions of *X* and *Y* are one
      larger than *C*.  Choose 'nearest' if dimensions are the same.

    See :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/pcolormesh_grids`
    for more description.

snap : bool, default: False
    Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.

rasterized : bool, optional
    Rasterize the pcolormesh when drawing vector graphics.  This can
    speed up rendering and produce smaller files for large data sets.
    See also :doc:`/gallery/misc/rasterization_demo`.

Returns
-------
`matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh`

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    Additionally, the following arguments are allowed. They are passed
    along to the `~matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` constructor:

%(QuadMesh:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
pcolor : An alternative implementation with slightly different
    features. For a detailed discussion on the differences see
    :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
    <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>`.
imshow : If *X* and *Y* are each equidistant, `~.Axes.imshow` can be a
    faster alternative.

Notes
-----
**Masked arrays**

*C* may be a masked array. If ``C[i, j]`` is masked, the corresponding
quadrilateral will be transparent. Masking of *X* and *Y* is not
supported. Use `~.Axes.pcolor` if you need this functionality.

.. _axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation:

**Grid orientation**

The grid orientation follows the standard matrix convention: An array
*C* with shape (nrows, ncolumns) is plotted with the column number as
*X* and the row number as *Y*.

.. _differences-pcolor-pcolormesh:

**Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()**

Both methods are used to create a pseudocolor plot of a 2D array
using quadrilaterals.

The main difference lies in the created object and internal data
handling:
While `~.Axes.pcolor` returns a `.PolyCollection`, `~.Axes.pcolormesh`
returns a `.QuadMesh`. The latter is more specialized for the given
purpose and thus is faster. It should almost always be preferred.

There is also a slight difference in the handling of masked arrays.
Both `~.Axes.pcolor` and `~.Axes.pcolormesh` support masked arrays
for *C*. However, only `~.Axes.pcolor` supports masked arrays for *X*
and *Y*. The reason lies in the internal handling of the masked values.
`~.Axes.pcolor` leaves out the respective polygons from the
PolyCollection. `~.Axes.pcolormesh` sets the facecolor of the masked
elements to transparent. You can see the difference when using
edgecolors. While all edges are drawn irrespective of masking in a
QuadMesh, the edge between two adjacent masked quadrilaterals in
`~.Axes.pcolor` is not drawn as the corresponding polygons do not
exist in the PolyCollection.

Another difference is the support of Gouraud shading in
`~.Axes.pcolormesh`, which is not available with `~.Axes.pcolor`.
5985 vmax=None, shading=None, antialiased=False, **kwargs):
5986 """
5987 Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.
5988
5989 Call signature::
5990
5991 pcolormesh([X, Y,] C, **kwargs)
5992
5993 *X* and *Y* can be used to specify the corners of the quadrilaterals.
5994
5995 .. hint::
5996
5997 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` is similar to `~.Axes.pcolor`. It is much faster
5998 and preferred in most cases. For a detailed discussion on the
5999 differences see :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
6000 <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>`.
6001
6002 Parameters
6003 ----------
6004 C : 2D array-like
6005 The color-mapped values. Color-mapping is controlled by *cmap*,
6006 *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*.
6007
6008 X, Y : array-like, optional
6009 The coordinates of the corners of quadrilaterals of a pcolormesh::
6010
6011 (X[i+1, j], Y[i+1, j]) (X[i+1, j+1], Y[i+1, j+1])
6012 +-----+
6013 | |
6014 +-----+
6015 (X[i, j], Y[i, j]) (X[i, j+1], Y[i, j+1])
6016
6017 Note that the column index corresponds to the x-coordinate, and
6018 the row index corresponds to y. For details, see the
6019 :ref:`Notes <axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation>` section below.
6020
6021 If ``shading='flat'`` the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be one
6022 greater than those of *C*, and the quadrilateral is colored due
6023 to the value at ``C[i, j]``. If *X*, *Y* and *C* have equal
6024 dimensions, a warning will be raised and the last row and column
6025 of *C* will be ignored.
6026
6027 If ``shading='nearest'`` or ``'gouraud'``, the dimensions of *X*
6028 and *Y* should be the same as those of *C* (if not, a ValueError
6029 will be raised). For ``'nearest'`` the color ``C[i, j]`` is
6030 centered on ``(X[i, j], Y[i, j])``. For ``'gouraud'``, a smooth
6031 interpolation is caried out between the quadrilateral corners.
6032
6033 If *X* and/or *Y* are 1-D arrays or column vectors they will be
6034 expanded as needed into the appropriate 2D arrays, making a
6035 rectangular grid.
6036
6037 %(cmap_doc)s
6038
6039 %(norm_doc)s
6040
6041 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
6042
6043 edgecolors : {'none', None, 'face', color, color sequence}, optional
6044 The color of the edges. Defaults to 'none'. Possible values:
6045
6046 - 'none' or '': No edge.
6047 - *None*: :rc:`patch.edgecolor` will be used. Note that currently
6048 :rc:`patch.force_edgecolor` has to be True for this to work.
6049 - 'face': Use the adjacent face color.
6050 - A color or sequence of colors will set the edge color.
6051
6052 The singular form *edgecolor* works as an alias.
6053
6054 alpha : float, default: None
6055 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
6056
6057 shading : {'flat', 'nearest', 'gouraud', 'auto'}, optional
6058 The fill style for the quadrilateral; defaults to
6059 'flat' or :rc:`pcolor.shading`. Possible values:
6060
6061 - 'flat': A solid color is used for each quad. The color of the
6062 quad (i, j), (i+1, j), (i, j+1), (i+1, j+1) is given by
6063 ``C[i, j]``. The dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
6064 one greater than those of *C*; if they are the same as *C*,
6065 then a deprecation warning is raised, and the last row
6066 and column of *C* are dropped.
6067 - 'nearest': Each grid point will have a color centered on it,
6068 extending halfway between the adjacent grid centers. The
6069 dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*.
6070 - 'gouraud': Each quad will be Gouraud shaded: The color of the
6071 corners (i', j') are given by ``C[i', j']``. The color values of
6072 the area in between is interpolated from the corner values.
6073 The dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*. When
6074 Gouraud shading is used, *edgecolors* is ignored.
6075 - 'auto': Choose 'flat' if dimensions of *X* and *Y* are one
6076 larger than *C*. Choose 'nearest' if dimensions are the same.
6077
6078 See :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/pcolormesh_grids`
6079 for more description.
6080
6081 snap : bool, default: False
6082 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.
6083
6084 rasterized : bool, optional
6085 Rasterize the pcolormesh when drawing vector graphics. This can
6086 speed up rendering and produce smaller files for large data sets.
6087 See also :doc:`/gallery/misc/rasterization_demo`.
6088
6089 Returns
6090 -------
6091 `matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh`
6092
6093 Other Parameters
6094 ----------------
6095 data : indexable object, optional
6096 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
6097
6098 **kwargs
6099 Additionally, the following arguments are allowed. They are passed
6100 along to the `~matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` constructor:
6101
6102 %(QuadMesh:kwdoc)s
6103
6104 See Also
6105 --------
6106 pcolor : An alternative implementation with slightly different
6107 features. For a detailed discussion on the differences see
6108 :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
6109 <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>`.
6110 imshow : If *X* and *Y* are each equidistant, `~.Axes.imshow` can be a
6111 faster alternative.
6112
6113 Notes
6114 -----
6115 **Masked arrays**
6116
6117 *C* may be a masked array. If ``C[i, j]`` is masked, the corresponding
6118 quadrilateral will be transparent. Masking of *X* and *Y* is not
6119 supported. Use `~.Axes.pcolor` if you need this functionality.
6120
6121 .. _axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation:
6122
6123 **Grid orientation**
6124
6125 The grid orientation follows the standard matrix convention: An array
6126 *C* with shape (nrows, ncolumns) is plotted with the column number as
6127 *X* and the row number as *Y*.
6128
6129 .. _differences-pcolor-pcolormesh:
6130
6131 **Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()**
6132
6133 Both methods are used to create a pseudocolor plot of a 2D array
6134 using quadrilaterals.
6135
6136 The main difference lies in the created object and internal data
6137 handling:
6138 While `~.Axes.pcolor` returns a `.PolyCollection`, `~.Axes.pcolormesh`
6139 returns a `.QuadMesh`. The latter is more specialized for the given
6140 purpose and thus is faster. It should almost always be preferred.
6141
6142 There is also a slight difference in the handling of masked arrays.
6143 Both `~.Axes.pcolor` and `~.Axes.pcolormesh` support masked arrays
6144 for *C*. However, only `~.Axes.pcolor` supports masked arrays for *X*
6145 and *Y*. The reason lies in the internal handling of the masked values.
6146 `~.Axes.pcolor` leaves out the respective polygons from the
6147 PolyCollection. `~.Axes.pcolormesh` sets the facecolor of the masked
6148 elements to transparent. You can see the difference when using
6149 edgecolors. While all edges are drawn irrespective of masking in a
6150 QuadMesh, the edge between two adjacent masked quadrilaterals in
6151 `~.Axes.pcolor` is not drawn as the corresponding polygons do not
6152 exist in the PolyCollection.
6153
6154 Another difference is the support of Gouraud shading in
6155 `~.Axes.pcolormesh`, which is not available with `~.Axes.pcolor`.
6156
6157 """
6158 if shading is None:
6159 shading = mpl.rcParams['pcolor.shading']
6160 shading = shading.lower()
6161 kwargs.setdefault('edgecolors', 'none')
6162
6163 X, Y, C, shading = self._pcolorargs('pcolormesh', *args,
6164 shading=shading, kwargs=kwargs)
6165 coords = np.stack([X, Y], axis=-1)
6166 # convert to one dimensional array
6167 C = C.ravel()
6168
6169 kwargs.setdefault('snap', mpl.rcParams['pcolormesh.snap'])
6170
6171 collection = mcoll.QuadMesh(
6172 coords, antialiased=antialiased, shading=shading,
6173 array=C, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, alpha=alpha, **kwargs)
6174 collection._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
6175 self._pcolor_grid_deprecation_helper()
6176
6177 coords = coords.reshape(-1, 2) # flatten the grid structure; keep x, y
6178
6179 # Transform from native to data coordinates?
6180 t = collection._transform
6181 if (not isinstance(t, mtransforms.Transform) and
6182 hasattr(t, '_as_mpl_transform')):
6183 t = t._as_mpl_transform(self.axes)
6184
6185 if t and any(t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)):
6186 trans_to_data = t - self.transData
6187 coords = trans_to_data.transform(coords)
6188
6189 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
6190
6191 minx, miny = np.min(coords, axis=0)
6192 maxx, maxy = np.max(coords, axis=0)
6193 collection.sticky_edges.x[:] = [minx, maxx]
6194 collection.sticky_edges.y[:] = [miny, maxy]
6195 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy)
6196 self.update_datalim(corners)
6197 self._request_autoscale_view()
6198 return collection
6199

◆ phase_spectrum()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.phase_spectrum (   self,
  x,
  Fs = None,
  Fc = None,
  window = None,
  pad_to = None,
  sides = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot the phase spectrum.

Compute the phase spectrum (unwrapped angle spectrum) of *x*.
Data is padded to a length of *pad_to* and the windowing function
*window* is applied to the signal.

Parameters
----------
x : 1-D array or sequence
    Array or sequence containing the data

%(Spectral)s

%(Single_Spectrum)s

Fc : int, default: 0
    The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
    plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
    and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.

Returns
-------
spectrum : 1-D array
    The values for the phase spectrum in radians (real valued).

freqs : 1-D array
    The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*.

line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
    The line created by this function.

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
magnitude_spectrum
    Plots the magnitudes of the corresponding frequencies.
angle_spectrum
    Plots the wrapped version of this function.
specgram
    Can plot the phase spectrum of segments within the signal in a
    colormap.
7459 pad_to=None, sides=None, **kwargs):
7460 """
7461 Plot the phase spectrum.
7462
7463 Compute the phase spectrum (unwrapped angle spectrum) of *x*.
7464 Data is padded to a length of *pad_to* and the windowing function
7465 *window* is applied to the signal.
7466
7467 Parameters
7468 ----------
7469 x : 1-D array or sequence
7470 Array or sequence containing the data
7471
7472 %(Spectral)s
7473
7474 %(Single_Spectrum)s
7475
7476 Fc : int, default: 0
7477 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
7478 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
7479 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.
7480
7481 Returns
7482 -------
7483 spectrum : 1-D array
7484 The values for the phase spectrum in radians (real valued).
7485
7486 freqs : 1-D array
7487 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*.
7488
7489 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
7490 The line created by this function.
7491
7492 Other Parameters
7493 ----------------
7494 data : indexable object, optional
7495 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
7496
7497 **kwargs
7498 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:
7499
7500 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
7501
7502 See Also
7503 --------
7504 magnitude_spectrum
7505 Plots the magnitudes of the corresponding frequencies.
7506 angle_spectrum
7507 Plots the wrapped version of this function.
7508 specgram
7509 Can plot the phase spectrum of segments within the signal in a
7510 colormap.
7511 """
7512 if Fc is None:
7513 Fc = 0
7514
7515 spec, freqs = mlab.phase_spectrum(x=x, Fs=Fs, window=window,
7516 pad_to=pad_to, sides=sides)
7517 freqs += Fc
7518
7519 lines = self.plot(freqs, spec, **kwargs)
7520 self.set_xlabel('Frequency')
7521 self.set_ylabel('Phase (radians)')
7522
7523 return spec, freqs, lines[0]
7524

◆ pie()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.pie (   self,
  x,
  explode = None,
  labels = None,
  colors = None,
  autopct = None,
  pctdistance = 0.6,
  shadow = False,
  labeldistance = 1.1,
  startangle = 0,
  radius = 1,
  counterclock = True,
  wedgeprops = None,
  textprops = None,
  center = (0, 0),
  frame = False,
  rotatelabels = False,
*  normalize = True 
) 
Plot a pie chart.

Make a pie chart of array *x*.  The fractional area of each wedge is
given by ``x/sum(x)``.

The wedges are plotted counterclockwise, by default starting from the
x-axis.

Parameters
----------
x : 1D array-like
    The wedge sizes.

explode : array-like, default: None
    If not *None*, is a ``len(x)`` array which specifies the fraction
    of the radius with which to offset each wedge.

labels : list, default: None
    A sequence of strings providing the labels for each wedge

colors : array-like, default: None
    A sequence of colors through which the pie chart will cycle.  If
    *None*, will use the colors in the currently active cycle.

autopct : None or str or callable, default: None
    If not *None*, is a string or function used to label the wedges
    with their numeric value.  The label will be placed inside the
    wedge.  If it is a format string, the label will be ``fmt % pct``.
    If it is a function, it will be called.

pctdistance : float, default: 0.6
    The ratio between the center of each pie slice and the start of
    the text generated by *autopct*.  Ignored if *autopct* is *None*.

shadow : bool, default: False
    Draw a shadow beneath the pie.

normalize : bool, default: True
    When *True*, always make a full pie by normalizing x so that
    ``sum(x) == 1``. *False* makes a partial pie if ``sum(x) <= 1``
    and raises a `ValueError` for ``sum(x) > 1``.

labeldistance : float or None, default: 1.1
    The radial distance at which the pie labels are drawn.
    If set to ``None``, label are not drawn, but are stored for use in
    ``legend()``

startangle : float, default: 0 degrees
    The angle by which the start of the pie is rotated,
    counterclockwise from the x-axis.

radius : float, default: 1
    The radius of the pie.

counterclock : bool, default: True
    Specify fractions direction, clockwise or counterclockwise.

wedgeprops : dict, default: None
    Dict of arguments passed to the wedge objects making the pie.
    For example, you can pass in ``wedgeprops = {'linewidth': 3}``
    to set the width of the wedge border lines equal to 3.
    For more details, look at the doc/arguments of the wedge object.
    By default ``clip_on=False``.

textprops : dict, default: None
    Dict of arguments to pass to the text objects.

center : (float, float), default: (0, 0)
    The coordinates of the center of the chart.

frame : bool, default: False
    Plot Axes frame with the chart if true.

rotatelabels : bool, default: False
    Rotate each label to the angle of the corresponding slice if true.

data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

Returns
-------
patches : list
    A sequence of `matplotlib.patches.Wedge` instances

texts : list
    A list of the label `.Text` instances.

autotexts : list
    A list of `.Text` instances for the numeric labels. This will only
    be returned if the parameter *autopct* is not *None*.

Notes
-----
The pie chart will probably look best if the figure and Axes are
square, or the Axes aspect is equal.
This method sets the aspect ratio of the axis to "equal".
The Axes aspect ratio can be controlled with `.Axes.set_aspect`.
3049 frame=False, rotatelabels=False, *, normalize=True):
3050 """
3051 Plot a pie chart.
3052
3053 Make a pie chart of array *x*. The fractional area of each wedge is
3054 given by ``x/sum(x)``.
3055
3056 The wedges are plotted counterclockwise, by default starting from the
3057 x-axis.
3058
3059 Parameters
3060 ----------
3061 x : 1D array-like
3062 The wedge sizes.
3063
3064 explode : array-like, default: None
3065 If not *None*, is a ``len(x)`` array which specifies the fraction
3066 of the radius with which to offset each wedge.
3067
3068 labels : list, default: None
3069 A sequence of strings providing the labels for each wedge
3070
3071 colors : array-like, default: None
3072 A sequence of colors through which the pie chart will cycle. If
3073 *None*, will use the colors in the currently active cycle.
3074
3075 autopct : None or str or callable, default: None
3076 If not *None*, is a string or function used to label the wedges
3077 with their numeric value. The label will be placed inside the
3078 wedge. If it is a format string, the label will be ``fmt % pct``.
3079 If it is a function, it will be called.
3080
3081 pctdistance : float, default: 0.6
3082 The ratio between the center of each pie slice and the start of
3083 the text generated by *autopct*. Ignored if *autopct* is *None*.
3084
3085 shadow : bool, default: False
3086 Draw a shadow beneath the pie.
3087
3088 normalize : bool, default: True
3089 When *True*, always make a full pie by normalizing x so that
3090 ``sum(x) == 1``. *False* makes a partial pie if ``sum(x) <= 1``
3091 and raises a `ValueError` for ``sum(x) > 1``.
3092
3093 labeldistance : float or None, default: 1.1
3094 The radial distance at which the pie labels are drawn.
3095 If set to ``None``, label are not drawn, but are stored for use in
3096 ``legend()``
3097
3098 startangle : float, default: 0 degrees
3099 The angle by which the start of the pie is rotated,
3100 counterclockwise from the x-axis.
3101
3102 radius : float, default: 1
3103 The radius of the pie.
3104
3105 counterclock : bool, default: True
3106 Specify fractions direction, clockwise or counterclockwise.
3107
3108 wedgeprops : dict, default: None
3109 Dict of arguments passed to the wedge objects making the pie.
3110 For example, you can pass in ``wedgeprops = {'linewidth': 3}``
3111 to set the width of the wedge border lines equal to 3.
3112 For more details, look at the doc/arguments of the wedge object.
3113 By default ``clip_on=False``.
3114
3115 textprops : dict, default: None
3116 Dict of arguments to pass to the text objects.
3117
3118 center : (float, float), default: (0, 0)
3119 The coordinates of the center of the chart.
3120
3121 frame : bool, default: False
3122 Plot Axes frame with the chart if true.
3123
3124 rotatelabels : bool, default: False
3125 Rotate each label to the angle of the corresponding slice if true.
3126
3127 data : indexable object, optional
3128 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
3129
3130 Returns
3131 -------
3132 patches : list
3133 A sequence of `matplotlib.patches.Wedge` instances
3134
3135 texts : list
3136 A list of the label `.Text` instances.
3137
3138 autotexts : list
3139 A list of `.Text` instances for the numeric labels. This will only
3140 be returned if the parameter *autopct* is not *None*.
3141
3142 Notes
3143 -----
3144 The pie chart will probably look best if the figure and Axes are
3145 square, or the Axes aspect is equal.
3146 This method sets the aspect ratio of the axis to "equal".
3147 The Axes aspect ratio can be controlled with `.Axes.set_aspect`.
3148 """
3149 self.set_aspect('equal')
3150 # The use of float32 is "historical", but can't be changed without
3151 # regenerating the test baselines.
3152 x = np.asarray(x, np.float32)
3153 if x.ndim > 1:
3154 raise ValueError("x must be 1D")
3155
3156 if np.any(x < 0):
3157 raise ValueError("Wedge sizes 'x' must be non negative values")
3158
3159 sx = x.sum()
3160
3161 if normalize:
3162 x = x / sx
3163 elif sx > 1:
3164 raise ValueError('Cannot plot an unnormalized pie with sum(x) > 1')
3165 if labels is None:
3166 labels = [''] * len(x)
3167 if explode is None:
3168 explode = [0] * len(x)
3169 if len(x) != len(labels):
3170 raise ValueError("'label' must be of length 'x'")
3171 if len(x) != len(explode):
3172 raise ValueError("'explode' must be of length 'x'")
3173 if colors is None:
3174 get_next_color = self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color
3175 else:
3176 color_cycle = itertools.cycle(colors)
3177
3178 def get_next_color():
3179 return next(color_cycle)
3180
3181 _api.check_isinstance(Number, radius=radius, startangle=startangle)
3182 if radius <= 0:
3183 raise ValueError(f'radius must be a positive number, not {radius}')
3184
3185 # Starting theta1 is the start fraction of the circle
3186 theta1 = startangle / 360
3187
3188 if wedgeprops is None:
3189 wedgeprops = {}
3190 if textprops is None:
3191 textprops = {}
3192
3193 texts = []
3194 slices = []
3195 autotexts = []
3196
3197 for frac, label, expl in zip(x, labels, explode):
3198 x, y = center
3199 theta2 = (theta1 + frac) if counterclock else (theta1 - frac)
3200 thetam = 2 * np.pi * 0.5 * (theta1 + theta2)
3201 x += expl * math.cos(thetam)
3202 y += expl * math.sin(thetam)
3203
3204 w = mpatches.Wedge((x, y), radius, 360. * min(theta1, theta2),
3205 360. * max(theta1, theta2),
3206 facecolor=get_next_color(),
3207 clip_on=False,
3208 label=label)
3209 w.set(**wedgeprops)
3210 slices.append(w)
3211 self.add_patch(w)
3212
3213 if shadow:
3214 # Make sure to add a shadow after the call to add_patch so the
3215 # figure and transform props will be set.
3216 shad = mpatches.Shadow(w, -0.02, -0.02, label='_nolegend_')
3217 self.add_patch(shad)
3218
3219 if labeldistance is not None:
3220 xt = x + labeldistance * radius * math.cos(thetam)
3221 yt = y + labeldistance * radius * math.sin(thetam)
3222 label_alignment_h = 'left' if xt > 0 else 'right'
3223 label_alignment_v = 'center'
3224 label_rotation = 'horizontal'
3225 if rotatelabels:
3226 label_alignment_v = 'bottom' if yt > 0 else 'top'
3227 label_rotation = (np.rad2deg(thetam)
3228 + (0 if xt > 0 else 180))
3229 t = self.text(xt, yt, label,
3230 clip_on=False,
3231 horizontalalignment=label_alignment_h,
3232 verticalalignment=label_alignment_v,
3233 rotation=label_rotation,
3234 size=mpl.rcParams['xtick.labelsize'])
3235 t.set(**textprops)
3236 texts.append(t)
3237
3238 if autopct is not None:
3239 xt = x + pctdistance * radius * math.cos(thetam)
3240 yt = y + pctdistance * radius * math.sin(thetam)
3241 if isinstance(autopct, str):
3242 s = autopct % (100. * frac)
3243 elif callable(autopct):
3244 s = autopct(100. * frac)
3245 else:
3246 raise TypeError(
3247 'autopct must be callable or a format string')
3248 t = self.text(xt, yt, s,
3249 clip_on=False,
3250 horizontalalignment='center',
3251 verticalalignment='center')
3252 t.set(**textprops)
3253 autotexts.append(t)
3254
3255 theta1 = theta2
3256
3257 if frame:
3258 self._request_autoscale_view()
3259 else:
3260 self.set(frame_on=False, xticks=[], yticks=[],
3261 xlim=(-1.25 + center[0], 1.25 + center[0]),
3262 ylim=(-1.25 + center[1], 1.25 + center[1]))
3263
3264 if autopct is None:
3265 return slices, texts
3266 else:
3267 return slices, texts, autotexts
3268

◆ plot()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.plot (   self,
*  args,
  scalex = True,
  scaley = True,
  data = None,
**  kwargs 
)

Basic plotting. 

Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers.

Call signatures::

    plot([x], y, [fmt], *, data=None, **kwargs)
    plot([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)

The coordinates of the points or line nodes are given by *x*, *y*.

The optional parameter *fmt* is a convenient way for defining basic
formatting like color, marker and linestyle. It's a shortcut string
notation described in the *Notes* section below.

>>> plot(x, y)        # plot x and y using default line style and color
>>> plot(x, y, 'bo')  # plot x and y using blue circle markers
>>> plot(y)           # plot y using x as index array 0..N-1
>>> plot(y, 'r+')     # ditto, but with red plusses

You can use `.Line2D` properties as keyword arguments for more
control on the appearance. Line properties and *fmt* can be mixed.
The following two calls yield identical results:

>>> plot(x, y, 'go--', linewidth=2, markersize=12)
>>> plot(x, y, color='green', marker='o', linestyle='dashed',
...      linewidth=2, markersize=12)

When conflicting with *fmt*, keyword arguments take precedence.


**Plotting labelled data**

There's a convenient way for plotting objects with labelled data (i.e.
data that can be accessed by index ``obj['y']``). Instead of giving
the data in *x* and *y*, you can provide the object in the *data*
parameter and just give the labels for *x* and *y*::

>>> plot('xlabel', 'ylabel', data=obj)

All indexable objects are supported. This could e.g. be a `dict`, a
`pandas.DataFrame` or a structured numpy array.


**Plotting multiple sets of data**

There are various ways to plot multiple sets of data.

- The most straight forward way is just to call `plot` multiple times.
  Example:

  >>> plot(x1, y1, 'bo')
  >>> plot(x2, y2, 'go')

- If *x* and/or *y* are 2D arrays a separate data set will be drawn
  for every column. If both *x* and *y* are 2D, they must have the
  same shape. If only one of them is 2D with shape (N, m) the other
  must have length N and will be used for every data set m.

  Example:

  >>> x = [1, 2, 3]
  >>> y = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]])
  >>> plot(x, y)

  is equivalent to:

  >>> for col in range(y.shape[1]):
  ...     plot(x, y[:, col])

- The third way is to specify multiple sets of *[x]*, *y*, *[fmt]*
  groups::

  >>> plot(x1, y1, 'g^', x2, y2, 'g-')

  In this case, any additional keyword argument applies to all
  datasets. Also this syntax cannot be combined with the *data*
  parameter.

By default, each line is assigned a different style specified by a
'style cycle'. The *fmt* and line property parameters are only
necessary if you want explicit deviations from these defaults.
Alternatively, you can also change the style cycle using
:rc:`axes.prop_cycle`.


Parameters
----------
x, y : array-like or scalar
    The horizontal / vertical coordinates of the data points.
    *x* values are optional and default to ``range(len(y))``.

    Commonly, these parameters are 1D arrays.

    They can also be scalars, or two-dimensional (in that case, the
    columns represent separate data sets).

    These arguments cannot be passed as keywords.

fmt : str, optional
    A format string, e.g. 'ro' for red circles. See the *Notes*
    section for a full description of the format strings.

    Format strings are just an abbreviation for quickly setting
    basic line properties. All of these and more can also be
    controlled by keyword arguments.

    This argument cannot be passed as keyword.

data : indexable object, optional
    An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to
    plot in *x* and *y*.

    .. note::
        Technically there's a slight ambiguity in calls where the
        second label is a valid *fmt*. ``plot('n', 'o', data=obj)``
        could be ``plt(x, y)`` or ``plt(y, fmt)``. In such cases,
        the former interpretation is chosen, but a warning is issued.
        You may suppress the warning by adding an empty format string
        ``plot('n', 'o', '', data=obj)``.

Returns
-------
list of `.Line2D`
    A list of lines representing the plotted data.

Other Parameters
----------------
scalex, scaley : bool, default: True
    These parameters determine if the view limits are adapted to the
    data limits. The values are passed on to
    `~.axes.Axes.autoscale_view`.

**kwargs : `.Line2D` properties, optional
    *kwargs* are used to specify properties like a line label (for
    auto legends), linewidth, antialiasing, marker face color.
    Example::

    >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 3], 'go-', label='line 1', linewidth=2)
    >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 4, 9], 'rs', label='line 2')

    If you specify multiple lines with one plot call, the kwargs apply
    to all those lines. In case the label object is iterable, each
    element is used as labels for each set of data.

    Here is a list of available `.Line2D` properties:

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
scatter : XY scatter plot with markers of varying size and/or color (
    sometimes also called bubble chart).

Notes
-----
**Format Strings**

A format string consists of a part for color, marker and line::

    fmt = '[marker][line][color]'

Each of them is optional. If not provided, the value from the style
cycle is used. Exception: If ``line`` is given, but no ``marker``,
the data will be a line without markers.

Other combinations such as ``[color][marker][line]`` are also
supported, but note that their parsing may be ambiguous.

**Markers**

=============   ===============================
character       description
=============   ===============================
``'.'``         point marker
``','``         pixel marker
``'o'``         circle marker
``'v'``         triangle_down marker
``'^'``         triangle_up marker
``'<'``         triangle_left marker
``'>'``         triangle_right marker
``'1'``         tri_down marker
``'2'``         tri_up marker
``'3'``         tri_left marker
``'4'``         tri_right marker
``'8'``         octagon marker
``'s'``         square marker
``'p'``         pentagon marker
``'P'``         plus (filled) marker
``'*'``         star marker
``'h'``         hexagon1 marker
``'H'``         hexagon2 marker
``'+'``         plus marker
``'x'``         x marker
``'X'``         x (filled) marker
``'D'``         diamond marker
``'d'``         thin_diamond marker
``'|'``         vline marker
``'_'``         hline marker
=============   ===============================

**Line Styles**

=============    ===============================
character        description
=============    ===============================
``'-'``          solid line style
``'--'``         dashed line style
``'-.'``         dash-dot line style
``':'``          dotted line style
=============    ===============================

Example format strings::

    'b'    # blue markers with default shape
    'or'   # red circles
    '-g'   # green solid line
    '--'   # dashed line with default color
    '^k:'  # black triangle_up markers connected by a dotted line

**Colors**

The supported color abbreviations are the single letter codes

=============    ===============================
character        color
=============    ===============================
``'b'``          blue
``'g'``          green
``'r'``          red
``'c'``          cyan
``'m'``          magenta
``'y'``          yellow
``'k'``          black
``'w'``          white
=============    ===============================

and the ``'CN'`` colors that index into the default property cycle.

If the color is the only part of the format string, you can
additionally use any  `matplotlib.colors` spec, e.g. full names
(``'green'``) or hex strings (``'#008000'``).

Reimplemented in mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.

1418 def plot(self, *args, scalex=True, scaley=True, data=None, **kwargs):
1419 """
1420 Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers.
1421
1422 Call signatures::
1423
1424 plot([x], y, [fmt], *, data=None, **kwargs)
1425 plot([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)
1426
1427 The coordinates of the points or line nodes are given by *x*, *y*.
1428
1429 The optional parameter *fmt* is a convenient way for defining basic
1430 formatting like color, marker and linestyle. It's a shortcut string
1431 notation described in the *Notes* section below.
1432
1433 >>> plot(x, y) # plot x and y using default line style and color
1434 >>> plot(x, y, 'bo') # plot x and y using blue circle markers
1435 >>> plot(y) # plot y using x as index array 0..N-1
1436 >>> plot(y, 'r+') # ditto, but with red plusses
1437
1438 You can use `.Line2D` properties as keyword arguments for more
1439 control on the appearance. Line properties and *fmt* can be mixed.
1440 The following two calls yield identical results:
1441
1442 >>> plot(x, y, 'go--', linewidth=2, markersize=12)
1443 >>> plot(x, y, color='green', marker='o', linestyle='dashed',
1444 ... linewidth=2, markersize=12)
1445
1446 When conflicting with *fmt*, keyword arguments take precedence.
1447
1448
1449 **Plotting labelled data**
1450
1451 There's a convenient way for plotting objects with labelled data (i.e.
1452 data that can be accessed by index ``obj['y']``). Instead of giving
1453 the data in *x* and *y*, you can provide the object in the *data*
1454 parameter and just give the labels for *x* and *y*::
1455
1456 >>> plot('xlabel', 'ylabel', data=obj)
1457
1458 All indexable objects are supported. This could e.g. be a `dict`, a
1459 `pandas.DataFrame` or a structured numpy array.
1460
1461
1462 **Plotting multiple sets of data**
1463
1464 There are various ways to plot multiple sets of data.
1465
1466 - The most straight forward way is just to call `plot` multiple times.
1467 Example:
1468
1469 >>> plot(x1, y1, 'bo')
1470 >>> plot(x2, y2, 'go')
1471
1472 - If *x* and/or *y* are 2D arrays a separate data set will be drawn
1473 for every column. If both *x* and *y* are 2D, they must have the
1474 same shape. If only one of them is 2D with shape (N, m) the other
1475 must have length N and will be used for every data set m.
1476
1477 Example:
1478
1479 >>> x = [1, 2, 3]
1480 >>> y = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]])
1481 >>> plot(x, y)
1482
1483 is equivalent to:
1484
1485 >>> for col in range(y.shape[1]):
1486 ... plot(x, y[:, col])
1487
1488 - The third way is to specify multiple sets of *[x]*, *y*, *[fmt]*
1489 groups::
1490
1491 >>> plot(x1, y1, 'g^', x2, y2, 'g-')
1492
1493 In this case, any additional keyword argument applies to all
1494 datasets. Also this syntax cannot be combined with the *data*
1495 parameter.
1496
1497 By default, each line is assigned a different style specified by a
1498 'style cycle'. The *fmt* and line property parameters are only
1499 necessary if you want explicit deviations from these defaults.
1500 Alternatively, you can also change the style cycle using
1501 :rc:`axes.prop_cycle`.
1502
1503
1504 Parameters
1505 ----------
1506 x, y : array-like or scalar
1507 The horizontal / vertical coordinates of the data points.
1508 *x* values are optional and default to ``range(len(y))``.
1509
1510 Commonly, these parameters are 1D arrays.
1511
1512 They can also be scalars, or two-dimensional (in that case, the
1513 columns represent separate data sets).
1514
1515 These arguments cannot be passed as keywords.
1516
1517 fmt : str, optional
1518 A format string, e.g. 'ro' for red circles. See the *Notes*
1519 section for a full description of the format strings.
1520
1521 Format strings are just an abbreviation for quickly setting
1522 basic line properties. All of these and more can also be
1523 controlled by keyword arguments.
1524
1525 This argument cannot be passed as keyword.
1526
1527 data : indexable object, optional
1528 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to
1529 plot in *x* and *y*.
1530
1531 .. note::
1532 Technically there's a slight ambiguity in calls where the
1533 second label is a valid *fmt*. ``plot('n', 'o', data=obj)``
1534 could be ``plt(x, y)`` or ``plt(y, fmt)``. In such cases,
1535 the former interpretation is chosen, but a warning is issued.
1536 You may suppress the warning by adding an empty format string
1537 ``plot('n', 'o', '', data=obj)``.
1538
1539 Returns
1540 -------
1541 list of `.Line2D`
1542 A list of lines representing the plotted data.
1543
1544 Other Parameters
1545 ----------------
1546 scalex, scaley : bool, default: True
1547 These parameters determine if the view limits are adapted to the
1548 data limits. The values are passed on to
1549 `~.axes.Axes.autoscale_view`.
1550
1551 **kwargs : `.Line2D` properties, optional
1552 *kwargs* are used to specify properties like a line label (for
1553 auto legends), linewidth, antialiasing, marker face color.
1554 Example::
1555
1556 >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 3], 'go-', label='line 1', linewidth=2)
1557 >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 4, 9], 'rs', label='line 2')
1558
1559 If you specify multiple lines with one plot call, the kwargs apply
1560 to all those lines. In case the label object is iterable, each
1561 element is used as labels for each set of data.
1562
1563 Here is a list of available `.Line2D` properties:
1564
1565 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
1566
1567 See Also
1568 --------
1569 scatter : XY scatter plot with markers of varying size and/or color (
1570 sometimes also called bubble chart).
1571
1572 Notes
1573 -----
1574 **Format Strings**
1575
1576 A format string consists of a part for color, marker and line::
1577
1578 fmt = '[marker][line][color]'
1579
1580 Each of them is optional. If not provided, the value from the style
1581 cycle is used. Exception: If ``line`` is given, but no ``marker``,
1582 the data will be a line without markers.
1583
1584 Other combinations such as ``[color][marker][line]`` are also
1585 supported, but note that their parsing may be ambiguous.
1586
1587 **Markers**
1588
1589 ============= ===============================
1590 character description
1591 ============= ===============================
1592 ``'.'`` point marker
1593 ``','`` pixel marker
1594 ``'o'`` circle marker
1595 ``'v'`` triangle_down marker
1596 ``'^'`` triangle_up marker
1597 ``'<'`` triangle_left marker
1598 ``'>'`` triangle_right marker
1599 ``'1'`` tri_down marker
1600 ``'2'`` tri_up marker
1601 ``'3'`` tri_left marker
1602 ``'4'`` tri_right marker
1603 ``'8'`` octagon marker
1604 ``'s'`` square marker
1605 ``'p'`` pentagon marker
1606 ``'P'`` plus (filled) marker
1607 ``'*'`` star marker
1608 ``'h'`` hexagon1 marker
1609 ``'H'`` hexagon2 marker
1610 ``'+'`` plus marker
1611 ``'x'`` x marker
1612 ``'X'`` x (filled) marker
1613 ``'D'`` diamond marker
1614 ``'d'`` thin_diamond marker
1615 ``'|'`` vline marker
1616 ``'_'`` hline marker
1617 ============= ===============================
1618
1619 **Line Styles**
1620
1621 ============= ===============================
1622 character description
1623 ============= ===============================
1624 ``'-'`` solid line style
1625 ``'--'`` dashed line style
1626 ``'-.'`` dash-dot line style
1627 ``':'`` dotted line style
1628 ============= ===============================
1629
1630 Example format strings::
1631
1632 'b' # blue markers with default shape
1633 'or' # red circles
1634 '-g' # green solid line
1635 '--' # dashed line with default color
1636 '^k:' # black triangle_up markers connected by a dotted line
1637
1638 **Colors**
1639
1640 The supported color abbreviations are the single letter codes
1641
1642 ============= ===============================
1643 character color
1644 ============= ===============================
1645 ``'b'`` blue
1646 ``'g'`` green
1647 ``'r'`` red
1648 ``'c'`` cyan
1649 ``'m'`` magenta
1650 ``'y'`` yellow
1651 ``'k'`` black
1652 ``'w'`` white
1653 ============= ===============================
1654
1655 and the ``'CN'`` colors that index into the default property cycle.
1656
1657 If the color is the only part of the format string, you can
1658 additionally use any `matplotlib.colors` spec, e.g. full names
1659 (``'green'``) or hex strings (``'#008000'``).
1660 """
1661 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mlines.Line2D)
1662 lines = [*self._get_lines(*args, data=data, **kwargs)]
1663 for line in lines:
1664 self.add_line(line)
1665 if scalex:
1666 self._request_autoscale_view("x")
1667 if scaley:
1668 self._request_autoscale_view("y")
1669 return lines
1670

◆ plot_date()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.plot_date (   self,
  x,
  y,
  fmt = 'o',
  tz = None,
  xdate = True,
  ydate = False,
**  kwargs 
) 
[*Discouraged*] Plot coercing the axis to treat floats as dates.

.. admonition:: Discouraged

    This method exists for historic reasons and will be deprecated in
    the future.

    - ``datetime``-like data should directly be plotted using
      `~.Axes.plot`.
    -  If you need to plot plain numeric data as :ref:`date-format` or
       need to set a timezone, call ``ax.xaxis.axis_date`` /
       ``ax.yaxis.axis_date`` before `~.Axes.plot`. See
       `.Axis.axis_date`.

Similar to `.plot`, this plots *y* vs. *x* as lines or markers.
However, the axis labels are formatted as dates depending on *xdate*
and *ydate*.  Note that `.plot` will work with `datetime` and
`numpy.datetime64` objects without resorting to this method.

Parameters
----------
x, y : array-like
    The coordinates of the data points. If *xdate* or *ydate* is
    *True*, the respective values *x* or *y* are interpreted as
    :ref:`Matplotlib dates <date-format>`.

fmt : str, optional
    The plot format string. For details, see the corresponding
    parameter in `.plot`.

tz : timezone string or `datetime.tzinfo`, default: :rc:`timezone`
    The time zone to use in labeling dates.

xdate : bool, default: True
    If *True*, the *x*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates.

ydate : bool, default: False
    If *True*, the *y*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates.

Returns
-------
list of `.Line2D`
    Objects representing the plotted data.

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
**kwargs
    Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

See Also
--------
matplotlib.dates : Helper functions on dates.
matplotlib.dates.date2num : Convert dates to num.
matplotlib.dates.num2date : Convert num to dates.
matplotlib.dates.drange : Create an equally spaced sequence of dates.

Notes
-----
If you are using custom date tickers and formatters, it may be
necessary to set the formatters/locators after the call to
`.plot_date`. `.plot_date` will set the default tick locator to
`.AutoDateLocator` (if the tick locator is not already set to a
`.DateLocator` instance) and the default tick formatter to
`.AutoDateFormatter` (if the tick formatter is not already set to a
`.DateFormatter` instance).
1674 **kwargs):
1675 """
1676 [*Discouraged*] Plot coercing the axis to treat floats as dates.
1677
1678 .. admonition:: Discouraged
1679
1680 This method exists for historic reasons and will be deprecated in
1681 the future.
1682
1683 - ``datetime``-like data should directly be plotted using
1684 `~.Axes.plot`.
1685 - If you need to plot plain numeric data as :ref:`date-format` or
1686 need to set a timezone, call ``ax.xaxis.axis_date`` /
1687 ``ax.yaxis.axis_date`` before `~.Axes.plot`. See
1688 `.Axis.axis_date`.
1689
1690 Similar to `.plot`, this plots *y* vs. *x* as lines or markers.
1691 However, the axis labels are formatted as dates depending on *xdate*
1692 and *ydate*. Note that `.plot` will work with `datetime` and
1693 `numpy.datetime64` objects without resorting to this method.
1694
1695 Parameters
1696 ----------
1697 x, y : array-like
1698 The coordinates of the data points. If *xdate* or *ydate* is
1699 *True*, the respective values *x* or *y* are interpreted as
1700 :ref:`Matplotlib dates <date-format>`.
1701
1702 fmt : str, optional
1703 The plot format string. For details, see the corresponding
1704 parameter in `.plot`.
1705
1706 tz : timezone string or `datetime.tzinfo`, default: :rc:`timezone`
1707 The time zone to use in labeling dates.
1708
1709 xdate : bool, default: True
1710 If *True*, the *x*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates.
1711
1712 ydate : bool, default: False
1713 If *True*, the *y*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates.
1714
1715 Returns
1716 -------
1717 list of `.Line2D`
1718 Objects representing the plotted data.
1719
1720 Other Parameters
1721 ----------------
1722 data : indexable object, optional
1723 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
1724 **kwargs
1725 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:
1726
1727 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
1728
1729 See Also
1730 --------
1731 matplotlib.dates : Helper functions on dates.
1732 matplotlib.dates.date2num : Convert dates to num.
1733 matplotlib.dates.num2date : Convert num to dates.
1734 matplotlib.dates.drange : Create an equally spaced sequence of dates.
1735
1736 Notes
1737 -----
1738 If you are using custom date tickers and formatters, it may be
1739 necessary to set the formatters/locators after the call to
1740 `.plot_date`. `.plot_date` will set the default tick locator to
1741 `.AutoDateLocator` (if the tick locator is not already set to a
1742 `.DateLocator` instance) and the default tick formatter to
1743 `.AutoDateFormatter` (if the tick formatter is not already set to a
1744 `.DateFormatter` instance).
1745 """
1746 if xdate:
1747 self.xaxis_date(tz)
1748 if ydate:
1749 self.yaxis_date(tz)
1750 return self.plot(x, y, fmt, **kwargs)
1751

◆ psd()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.psd (   self,
  x,
  NFFT = None,
  Fs = None,
  Fc = None,
  detrend = None,
  window = None,
  noverlap = None,
  pad_to = None,
  sides = None,
  scale_by_freq = None,
  return_line = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
    Plot the power spectral density.

    The power spectral density :math:`P_{xx}` by Welch's average
    periodogram method.  The vector *x* is divided into *NFFT* length
    segments.  Each segment is detrended by function *detrend* and
    windowed by function *window*.  *noverlap* gives the length of
    the overlap between segments.  The :math:`|\mathrm{fft}(i)|^2`
    of each segment :math:`i` are averaged to compute :math:`P_{xx}`,
    with a scaling to correct for power loss due to windowing.

    If len(*x*) < *NFFT*, it will be zero padded to *NFFT*.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x : 1-D array or sequence
        Array or sequence containing the data

    %(Spectral)s

    %(PSD)s

    noverlap : int, default: 0 (no overlap)
        The number of points of overlap between segments.

    Fc : int, default: 0
        The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
        plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
        and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.

    return_line : bool, default: False
        Whether to include the line object plotted in the returned values.

    Returns
    -------
    Pxx : 1-D array
        The values for the power spectrum :math:`P_{xx}` before scaling
        (real valued).

    freqs : 1-D array
        The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *Pxx*.

    line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
        The line created by this function.
        Only returned if *return_line* is True.

    Other Parameters
    ----------------
    data : indexable object, optional
        DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

    **kwargs
        Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:

        %(Line2D:kwdoc)s

    See Also
    --------
    specgram
        Differs in the default overlap; in not returning the mean of the
        segment periodograms; in returning the times of the segments; and
        in plotting a colormap instead of a line.
    magnitude_spectrum
        Plots the magnitude spectrum.
    csd
        Plots the spectral density between two signals.

    Notes
    -----
    For plotting, the power is plotted as
    :math:`10\log_{10}(P_{xx})` for decibels, though *Pxx* itself
    is returned.

    References
    ----------
    Bendat & Piersol -- Random Data: Analysis and Measurement Procedures,
    John Wiley & Sons (1986)
7092 sides=None, scale_by_freq=None, return_line=None, **kwargs):
7093 r"""
7094 Plot the power spectral density.
7095
7096 The power spectral density :math:`P_{xx}` by Welch's average
7097 periodogram method. The vector *x* is divided into *NFFT* length
7098 segments. Each segment is detrended by function *detrend* and
7099 windowed by function *window*. *noverlap* gives the length of
7100 the overlap between segments. The :math:`|\mathrm{fft}(i)|^2`
7101 of each segment :math:`i` are averaged to compute :math:`P_{xx}`,
7102 with a scaling to correct for power loss due to windowing.
7103
7104 If len(*x*) < *NFFT*, it will be zero padded to *NFFT*.
7105
7106 Parameters
7107 ----------
7108 x : 1-D array or sequence
7109 Array or sequence containing the data
7110
7111 %(Spectral)s
7112
7113 %(PSD)s
7114
7115 noverlap : int, default: 0 (no overlap)
7116 The number of points of overlap between segments.
7117
7118 Fc : int, default: 0
7119 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
7120 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
7121 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.
7122
7123 return_line : bool, default: False
7124 Whether to include the line object plotted in the returned values.
7125
7126 Returns
7127 -------
7128 Pxx : 1-D array
7129 The values for the power spectrum :math:`P_{xx}` before scaling
7130 (real valued).
7131
7132 freqs : 1-D array
7133 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *Pxx*.
7134
7135 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
7136 The line created by this function.
7137 Only returned if *return_line* is True.
7138
7139 Other Parameters
7140 ----------------
7141 data : indexable object, optional
7142 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
7143
7144 **kwargs
7145 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:
7146
7147 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
7148
7149 See Also
7150 --------
7151 specgram
7152 Differs in the default overlap; in not returning the mean of the
7153 segment periodograms; in returning the times of the segments; and
7154 in plotting a colormap instead of a line.
7155 magnitude_spectrum
7156 Plots the magnitude spectrum.
7157 csd
7158 Plots the spectral density between two signals.
7159
7160 Notes
7161 -----
7162 For plotting, the power is plotted as
7163 :math:`10\log_{10}(P_{xx})` for decibels, though *Pxx* itself
7164 is returned.
7165
7166 References
7167 ----------
7168 Bendat & Piersol -- Random Data: Analysis and Measurement Procedures,
7169 John Wiley & Sons (1986)
7170 """
7171 if Fc is None:
7172 Fc = 0
7173
7174 pxx, freqs = mlab.psd(x=x, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, detrend=detrend,
7175 window=window, noverlap=noverlap, pad_to=pad_to,
7176 sides=sides, scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq)
7177 freqs += Fc
7178
7179 if scale_by_freq in (None, True):
7180 psd_units = 'dB/Hz'
7181 else:
7182 psd_units = 'dB'
7183
7184 line = self.plot(freqs, 10 * np.log10(pxx), **kwargs)
7185 self.set_xlabel('Frequency')
7186 self.set_ylabel('Power Spectral Density (%s)' % psd_units)
7187 self.grid(True)
7188
7189 vmin, vmax = self.get_ybound()
7190 step = max(10 * int(np.log10(vmax - vmin)), 1)
7191 ticks = np.arange(math.floor(vmin), math.ceil(vmax) + 1, step)
7192 self.set_yticks(ticks)
7193
7194 if return_line is None or not return_line:
7195 return pxx, freqs
7196 else:
7197 return pxx, freqs, line
7198

◆ quiver()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.quiver (   self,
*  args,
**  kwargs 
) 
%(quiver_doc)s

Reimplemented in mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.

5099 def quiver(self, *args, **kwargs):
5100 """%(quiver_doc)s"""
5101 # Make sure units are handled for x and y values
5102 args = self._quiver_units(args, kwargs)
5103 q = mquiver.Quiver(self, *args, **kwargs)
5104 self.add_collection(q, autolim=True)
5105 self._request_autoscale_view()
5106 return q
5107

  U,

5085 self.add_artist(qk)

5087

◆ scatter()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.scatter (   self,
  x,
  y,
  s = None,
  c = None,
  marker = None,
  cmap = None,
  norm = None,
  vmin = None,
  vmax = None,
  alpha = None,
  linewidths = None,
*  edgecolors = None,
  plotnonfinite = False,
**  kwargs 
) 
A scatter plot of *y* vs. *x* with varying marker size and/or color.

Parameters
----------
x, y : float or array-like, shape (n, )
    The data positions.

s : float or array-like, shape (n, ), optional
    The marker size in points**2 (typographic points are 1/72 in.).
    Default is ``rcParams['lines.markersize'] ** 2``.

c : array-like or list of colors or color, optional
    The marker colors. Possible values:

    - A scalar or sequence of n numbers to be mapped to colors using
      *cmap* and *norm*.
    - A 2D array in which the rows are RGB or RGBA.
    - A sequence of colors of length n.
    - A single color format string.

    Note that *c* should not be a single numeric RGB or RGBA sequence
    because that is indistinguishable from an array of values to be
    colormapped. If you want to specify the same RGB or RGBA value for
    all points, use a 2D array with a single row.  Otherwise, value-
    matching will have precedence in case of a size matching with *x*
    and *y*.

    If you wish to specify a single color for all points
    prefer the *color* keyword argument.

    Defaults to `None`. In that case the marker color is determined
    by the value of *color*, *facecolor* or *facecolors*. In case
    those are not specified or `None`, the marker color is determined
    by the next color of the ``Axes``' current "shape and fill" color
    cycle. This cycle defaults to :rc:`axes.prop_cycle`.

marker : `~.markers.MarkerStyle`, default: :rc:`scatter.marker`
    The marker style. *marker* can be either an instance of the class
    or the text shorthand for a particular marker.
    See :mod:`matplotlib.markers` for more information about marker
    styles.

%(cmap_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).

%(norm_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).

%(vmin_vmax_doc)s

    This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).

alpha : float, default: None
    The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).

linewidths : float or array-like, default: :rc:`lines.linewidth`
    The linewidth of the marker edges. Note: The default *edgecolors*
    is 'face'. You may want to change this as well.

edgecolors : {'face', 'none', *None*} or color or sequence of color, \
default: :rc:`scatter.edgecolors`
    The edge color of the marker. Possible values:

    - 'face': The edge color will always be the same as the face color.
    - 'none': No patch boundary will be drawn.
    - A color or sequence of colors.

    For non-filled markers, *edgecolors* is ignored. Instead, the color
    is determined like with 'face', i.e. from *c*, *colors*, or
    *facecolors*.

plotnonfinite : bool, default: False
    Whether to plot points with nonfinite *c* (i.e. ``inf``, ``-inf``
    or ``nan``). If ``True`` the points are drawn with the *bad*
    colormap color (see `.Colormap.set_bad`).

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.collections.PathCollection`

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
**kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.Collection` properties

See Also
--------
plot : To plot scatter plots when markers are identical in size and
    color.

Notes
-----
* The `.plot` function will be faster for scatterplots where markers
  don't vary in size or color.

* Any or all of *x*, *y*, *s*, and *c* may be masked arrays, in which
  case all masks will be combined and only unmasked points will be
  plotted.

* Fundamentally, scatter works with 1D arrays; *x*, *y*, *s*, and *c*
  may be input as N-D arrays, but within scatter they will be
  flattened. The exception is *c*, which will be flattened only if its
  size matches the size of *x* and *y*.

Reimplemented in mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.

4403 edgecolors=None, plotnonfinite=False, **kwargs):
4404 """
4405 A scatter plot of *y* vs. *x* with varying marker size and/or color.
4406
4407 Parameters
4408 ----------
4409 x, y : float or array-like, shape (n, )
4410 The data positions.
4411
4412 s : float or array-like, shape (n, ), optional
4413 The marker size in points**2 (typographic points are 1/72 in.).
4414 Default is ``rcParams['lines.markersize'] ** 2``.
4415
4416 c : array-like or list of colors or color, optional
4417 The marker colors. Possible values:
4418
4419 - A scalar or sequence of n numbers to be mapped to colors using
4420 *cmap* and *norm*.
4421 - A 2D array in which the rows are RGB or RGBA.
4422 - A sequence of colors of length n.
4423 - A single color format string.
4424
4425 Note that *c* should not be a single numeric RGB or RGBA sequence
4426 because that is indistinguishable from an array of values to be
4427 colormapped. If you want to specify the same RGB or RGBA value for
4428 all points, use a 2D array with a single row. Otherwise, value-
4429 matching will have precedence in case of a size matching with *x*
4430 and *y*.
4431
4432 If you wish to specify a single color for all points
4433 prefer the *color* keyword argument.
4434
4435 Defaults to `None`. In that case the marker color is determined
4436 by the value of *color*, *facecolor* or *facecolors*. In case
4437 those are not specified or `None`, the marker color is determined
4438 by the next color of the ``Axes``' current "shape and fill" color
4439 cycle. This cycle defaults to :rc:`axes.prop_cycle`.
4440
4441 marker : `~.markers.MarkerStyle`, default: :rc:`scatter.marker`
4442 The marker style. *marker* can be either an instance of the class
4443 or the text shorthand for a particular marker.
4444 See :mod:`matplotlib.markers` for more information about marker
4445 styles.
4446
4447 %(cmap_doc)s
4448
4449 This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).
4450
4451 %(norm_doc)s
4452
4453 This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).
4454
4455 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
4456
4457 This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).
4458
4459 alpha : float, default: None
4460 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
4461
4462 linewidths : float or array-like, default: :rc:`lines.linewidth`
4463 The linewidth of the marker edges. Note: The default *edgecolors*
4464 is 'face'. You may want to change this as well.
4465
4466 edgecolors : {'face', 'none', *None*} or color or sequence of color, \
4467default: :rc:`scatter.edgecolors`
4468 The edge color of the marker. Possible values:
4469
4470 - 'face': The edge color will always be the same as the face color.
4471 - 'none': No patch boundary will be drawn.
4472 - A color or sequence of colors.
4473
4474 For non-filled markers, *edgecolors* is ignored. Instead, the color
4475 is determined like with 'face', i.e. from *c*, *colors*, or
4476 *facecolors*.
4477
4478 plotnonfinite : bool, default: False
4479 Whether to plot points with nonfinite *c* (i.e. ``inf``, ``-inf``
4480 or ``nan``). If ``True`` the points are drawn with the *bad*
4481 colormap color (see `.Colormap.set_bad`).
4482
4483 Returns
4484 -------
4485 `~matplotlib.collections.PathCollection`
4486
4487 Other Parameters
4488 ----------------
4489 data : indexable object, optional
4490 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
4491 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.Collection` properties
4492
4493 See Also
4494 --------
4495 plot : To plot scatter plots when markers are identical in size and
4496 color.
4497
4498 Notes
4499 -----
4500 * The `.plot` function will be faster for scatterplots where markers
4501 don't vary in size or color.
4502
4503 * Any or all of *x*, *y*, *s*, and *c* may be masked arrays, in which
4504 case all masks will be combined and only unmasked points will be
4505 plotted.
4506
4507 * Fundamentally, scatter works with 1D arrays; *x*, *y*, *s*, and *c*
4508 may be input as N-D arrays, but within scatter they will be
4509 flattened. The exception is *c*, which will be flattened only if its
4510 size matches the size of *x* and *y*.
4511
4512 """
4513 # Process **kwargs to handle aliases, conflicts with explicit kwargs:
4514 x, y = self._process_unit_info([("x", x), ("y", y)], kwargs)
4515 # np.ma.ravel yields an ndarray, not a masked array,
4516 # unless its argument is a masked array.
4517 x = np.ma.ravel(x)
4518 y = np.ma.ravel(y)
4519 if x.size != y.size:
4520 raise ValueError("x and y must be the same size")
4521
4522 if s is None:
4523 s = (20 if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode'] else
4524 mpl.rcParams['lines.markersize'] ** 2.0)
4525 s = np.ma.ravel(s)
4526 if (len(s) not in (1, x.size) or
4527 (not np.issubdtype(s.dtype, np.floating) and
4528 not np.issubdtype(s.dtype, np.integer))):
4529 raise ValueError(
4530 "s must be a scalar, "
4531 "or float array-like with the same size as x and y")
4532
4533 # get the original edgecolor the user passed before we normalize
4534 orig_edgecolor = edgecolors
4535 if edgecolors is None:
4536 orig_edgecolor = kwargs.get('edgecolor', None)
4537 c, colors, edgecolors = \
4538 self._parse_scatter_color_args(
4539 c, edgecolors, kwargs, x.size,
4540 get_next_color_func=self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color)
4541
4542 if plotnonfinite and colors is None:
4543 c = np.ma.masked_invalid(c)
4544 x, y, s, edgecolors, linewidths = \
4545 cbook._combine_masks(x, y, s, edgecolors, linewidths)
4546 else:
4547 x, y, s, c, colors, edgecolors, linewidths = \
4548 cbook._combine_masks(
4549 x, y, s, c, colors, edgecolors, linewidths)
4550 # Unmask edgecolors if it was actually a single RGB or RGBA.
4551 if (x.size in (3, 4)
4552 and np.ma.is_masked(edgecolors)
4553 and not np.ma.is_masked(orig_edgecolor)):
4554 edgecolors = edgecolors.data
4555
4556 scales = s # Renamed for readability below.
4557
4558 # load default marker from rcParams
4559 if marker is None:
4560 marker = mpl.rcParams['scatter.marker']
4561
4562 if isinstance(marker, mmarkers.MarkerStyle):
4563 marker_obj = marker
4564 else:
4565 marker_obj = mmarkers.MarkerStyle(marker)
4566
4567 path = marker_obj.get_path().transformed(
4568 marker_obj.get_transform())
4569 if not marker_obj.is_filled():
4570 if orig_edgecolor is not None:
4571 _api.warn_external(
4572 f"You passed a edgecolor/edgecolors ({orig_edgecolor!r}) "
4573 f"for an unfilled marker ({marker!r}). Matplotlib is "
4574 "ignoring the edgecolor in favor of the facecolor. This "
4575 "behavior may change in the future."
4576 )
4577 # We need to handle markers that can not be filled (like
4578 # '+' and 'x') differently than markers that can be
4579 # filled, but have their fillstyle set to 'none'. This is
4580 # to get:
4581 #
4582 # - respecting the fillestyle if set
4583 # - maintaining back-compatibility for querying the facecolor of
4584 # the un-fillable markers.
4585 #
4586 # While not an ideal situation, but is better than the
4587 # alternatives.
4588 if marker_obj.get_fillstyle() == 'none':
4589 # promote the facecolor to be the edgecolor
4590 edgecolors = colors
4591 # set the facecolor to 'none' (at the last chance) because
4592 # we can not fill a path if the facecolor is non-null
4593 # (which is defendable at the renderer level).
4594 colors = 'none'
4595 else:
4596 # if we are not nulling the face color we can do this
4597 # simpler
4598 edgecolors = 'face'
4599
4600 if linewidths is None:
4601 linewidths = mpl.rcParams['lines.linewidth']
4602 elif np.iterable(linewidths):
4603 linewidths = [
4604 lw if lw is not None else mpl.rcParams['lines.linewidth']
4605 for lw in linewidths]
4606
4607 offsets = np.ma.column_stack([x, y])
4608
4609 collection = mcoll.PathCollection(
4610 (path,), scales,
4611 facecolors=colors,
4612 edgecolors=edgecolors,
4613 linewidths=linewidths,
4614 offsets=offsets,
4615 offset_transform=kwargs.pop('transform', self.transData),
4616 alpha=alpha,
4617 )
4618 collection.set_transform(mtransforms.IdentityTransform())
4619 if colors is None:
4620 collection.set_array(c)
4621 collection.set_cmap(cmap)
4622 collection.set_norm(norm)
4623 collection._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
4624 else:
4625 extra_kwargs = {
4626 'cmap': cmap, 'norm': norm, 'vmin': vmin, 'vmax': vmax
4627 }
4628 extra_keys = [k for k, v in extra_kwargs.items() if v is not None]
4629 if any(extra_keys):
4630 keys_str = ", ".join(f"'{k}'" for k in extra_keys)
4631 _api.warn_external(
4632 "No data for colormapping provided via 'c'. "
4633 f"Parameters {keys_str} will be ignored")
4634 collection._internal_update(kwargs)
4635
4636 # Classic mode only:
4637 # ensure there are margins to allow for the
4638 # finite size of the symbols. In v2.x, margins
4639 # are present by default, so we disable this
4640 # scatter-specific override.
4641 if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']:
4642 if self._xmargin < 0.05 and x.size > 0:
4643 self.set_xmargin(0.05)
4644 if self._ymargin < 0.05 and x.size > 0:
4645 self.set_ymargin(0.05)
4646
4647 self.add_collection(collection)
4648 self._request_autoscale_view()
4649
4650 return collection
4651

◆ secondary_xaxis()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.secondary_xaxis (   self,
  location,
*  functions = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add a second x-axis to this Axes.

For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on
the xaxis.

%(_secax_docstring)s

Examples
--------
The main axis shows frequency, and the secondary axis shows period.

.. plot::

    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    ax.loglog(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5))
    ax.set_xlabel('frequency [Hz]')

    def invert(x):
        # 1/x with special treatment of x == 0
        x = np.array(x).astype(float)
        near_zero = np.isclose(x, 0)
        x[near_zero] = np.inf
        x[~near_zero] = 1 / x[~near_zero]
        return x

    # the inverse of 1/x is itself
    secax = ax.secondary_xaxis('top', functions=(invert, invert))
    secax.set_xlabel('Period [s]')
    plt.show()
542 def secondary_xaxis(self, location, *, functions=None, **kwargs):
543 """
544 Add a second x-axis to this Axes.
545
546 For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on
547 the xaxis.
548
549 %(_secax_docstring)s
550
551 Examples
552 --------
553 The main axis shows frequency, and the secondary axis shows period.
554
555 .. plot::
556
557 fig, ax = plt.subplots()
558 ax.loglog(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5))
559 ax.set_xlabel('frequency [Hz]')
560
561 def invert(x):
562 # 1/x with special treatment of x == 0
563 x = np.array(x).astype(float)
564 near_zero = np.isclose(x, 0)
565 x[near_zero] = np.inf
566 x[~near_zero] = 1 / x[~near_zero]
567 return x
568
569 # the inverse of 1/x is itself
570 secax = ax.secondary_xaxis('top', functions=(invert, invert))
571 secax.set_xlabel('Period [s]')
572 plt.show()
573 """
574 if location in ['top', 'bottom'] or isinstance(location, Number):
575 secondary_ax = SecondaryAxis(self, 'x', location, functions,
576 **kwargs)
577 self.add_child_axes(secondary_ax)
578 return secondary_ax
579 else:
580 raise ValueError('secondary_xaxis location must be either '
581 'a float or "top"/"bottom"')
582

◆ secondary_yaxis()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.secondary_yaxis (   self,
  location,
*  functions = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add a second y-axis to this Axes.

For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on
the yaxis.

%(_secax_docstring)s

Examples
--------
Add a secondary Axes that converts from radians to degrees

.. plot::

    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    ax.plot(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5))
    ax.set_ylabel('degrees')
    secax = ax.secondary_yaxis('right', functions=(np.deg2rad,
                                                   np.rad2deg))
    secax.set_ylabel('radians')
584 def secondary_yaxis(self, location, *, functions=None, **kwargs):
585 """
586 Add a second y-axis to this Axes.
587
588 For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on
589 the yaxis.
590
591 %(_secax_docstring)s
592
593 Examples
594 --------
595 Add a secondary Axes that converts from radians to degrees
596
597 .. plot::
598
599 fig, ax = plt.subplots()
600 ax.plot(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5))
601 ax.set_ylabel('degrees')
602 secax = ax.secondary_yaxis('right', functions=(np.deg2rad,
603 np.rad2deg))
604 secax.set_ylabel('radians')
605 """
606 if location in ['left', 'right'] or isinstance(location, Number):
607 secondary_ax = SecondaryAxis(self, 'y', location,
608 functions, **kwargs)
609 self.add_child_axes(secondary_ax)
610 return secondary_ax
611 else:
612 raise ValueError('secondary_yaxis location must be either '
613 'a float or "left"/"right"')
614

◆ semilogx()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.semilogx (   self,
*  args,
**  kwargs 
) 
Make a plot with log scaling on the x axis.

Call signatures::

    semilogx([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs)
    semilogx([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)

This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes
the x-axis to log scaling. All of the concepts and parameters of plot
can be used here as well.

The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the
x-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale`.

Parameters
----------
base : float, default: 10
    Base of the x logarithm.

subs : array-like, optional
    The location of the minor xticks. If *None*, reasonable locations
    are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
    plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale` for details.

nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask'
    Non-positive values in x can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a
    very small positive number.

**kwargs
    All parameters supported by `.plot`.

Returns
-------
list of `.Line2D`
    Objects representing the plotted data.
1808 def semilogx(self, *args, **kwargs):
1809 """
1810 Make a plot with log scaling on the x axis.
1811
1812 Call signatures::
1813
1814 semilogx([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs)
1815 semilogx([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)
1816
1817 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes
1818 the x-axis to log scaling. All of the concepts and parameters of plot
1819 can be used here as well.
1820
1821 The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the
1822 x-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale`.
1823
1824 Parameters
1825 ----------
1826 base : float, default: 10
1827 Base of the x logarithm.
1828
1829 subs : array-like, optional
1830 The location of the minor xticks. If *None*, reasonable locations
1831 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
1832 plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale` for details.
1833
1834 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask'
1835 Non-positive values in x can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a
1836 very small positive number.
1837
1838 **kwargs
1839 All parameters supported by `.plot`.
1840
1841 Returns
1842 -------
1843 list of `.Line2D`
1844 Objects representing the plotted data.
1845 """
1846 d = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items()
1847 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive',
1848 'basex', 'subsx', 'nonposx']}
1849 self.set_xscale('log', **d)
1850 return self.plot(
1851 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in d})
1852

◆ semilogy()

) 
Make a plot with log scaling on the y axis.

Call signatures::

    semilogy([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs)
    semilogy([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)

This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes
the y-axis to log scaling. All of the concepts and parameters of plot
can be used here as well.

The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the
y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_yscale`.

    Base of the y logarithm.

    are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
    plot. See `.Axes.set_yscale` for details.

nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask'
    Non-positive values in y can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a
    very small positive number.

    All parameters supported by `.plot`.

    Objects representing the plotted data.

1865 the y-axis to log scaling. All of the concepts and parameters of plot
1866 can be used here as well.
1867
1868 The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the
1869 y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_yscale`.
1870
1871 Parameters
1872 ----------
1873 base : float, default: 10
1874 Base of the y logarithm.
1875
1876 subs : array-like, optional
1877 The location of the minor yticks. If *None*, reasonable locations
1878 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
1879 plot. See `.Axes.set_yscale` for details.
1880
1881 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask'
1882 Non-positive values in y can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a
1883 very small positive number.
1884
1885 **kwargs
1886 All parameters supported by `.plot`.
1887
1888 Returns
1889 -------
1890 list of `.Line2D`
1891 Objects representing the plotted data.

1898 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in d})
