◆ set_title()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.set_title (   self,
  label,
  fontdict = None,
  loc = None,
  pad = None,
*  y = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Set a title for the Axes.

Set one of the three available Axes titles. The available titles
are positioned above the Axes in the center, flush with the left
edge, and flush with the right edge.

Parameters
----------
label : str
    Text to use for the title

fontdict : dict
    A dictionary controlling the appearance of the title text,
    the default *fontdict* is::

       {'fontsize': rcParams['axes.titlesize'],
        'fontweight': rcParams['axes.titleweight'],
        'color': rcParams['axes.titlecolor'],
        'verticalalignment': 'baseline',
        'horizontalalignment': loc}

loc : {'center', 'left', 'right'}, default: :rc:`axes.titlelocation`
    Which title to set.

y : float, default: :rc:`axes.titley`
    Vertical Axes location for the title (1.0 is the top).  If
    None (the default) and :rc:`axes.titley` is also None, y is
    determined automatically to avoid decorators on the Axes.

pad : float, default: :rc:`axes.titlepad`
    The offset of the title from the top of the Axes, in points.

Returns
-------
`.Text`
    The matplotlib text instance representing the title

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs : `.Text` properties
    Other keyword arguments are text properties, see `.Text` for a list
    of valid text properties.

Reimplemented in mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.

94 **kwargs):
95 """
96 Set a title for the Axes.
97
98 Set one of the three available Axes titles. The available titles
99 are positioned above the Axes in the center, flush with the left
100 edge, and flush with the right edge.
101
102 Parameters
103 ----------
104 label : str
105 Text to use for the title
106
107 fontdict : dict
108 A dictionary controlling the appearance of the title text,
109 the default *fontdict* is::
110
111 {'fontsize': rcParams['axes.titlesize'],
112 'fontweight': rcParams['axes.titleweight'],
113 'color': rcParams['axes.titlecolor'],
114 'verticalalignment': 'baseline',
115 'horizontalalignment': loc}
116
117 loc : {'center', 'left', 'right'}, default: :rc:`axes.titlelocation`
118 Which title to set.
119
120 y : float, default: :rc:`axes.titley`
121 Vertical Axes location for the title (1.0 is the top). If
122 None (the default) and :rc:`axes.titley` is also None, y is
123 determined automatically to avoid decorators on the Axes.
124
125 pad : float, default: :rc:`axes.titlepad`
126 The offset of the title from the top of the Axes, in points.
127
128 Returns
129 -------
130 `.Text`
131 The matplotlib text instance representing the title
132
133 Other Parameters
134 ----------------
135 **kwargs : `.Text` properties
136 Other keyword arguments are text properties, see `.Text` for a list
137 of valid text properties.
138 """
139 if loc is None:
140 loc = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlelocation']
141
142 if y is None:
143 y = mpl.rcParams['axes.titley']
144 if y is None:
145 y = 1.0
146 else:
147 self._autotitlepos = False
148 kwargs['y'] = y
149
150 titles = {'left': self._left_title,
151 'center': self.title,
152 'right': self._right_title}
153 title = _api.check_getitem(titles, loc=loc.lower())
154 default = {
155 'fontsize': mpl.rcParams['axes.titlesize'],
156 'fontweight': mpl.rcParams['axes.titleweight'],
157 'verticalalignment': 'baseline',
158 'horizontalalignment': loc.lower()}
159 titlecolor = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlecolor']
160 if not cbook._str_lower_equal(titlecolor, 'auto'):
161 default["color"] = titlecolor
162 if pad is None:
163 pad = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlepad']
164 self._set_title_offset_trans(float(pad))
165 title.set_text(label)
166 title.update(default)
167 if fontdict is not None:
168 title.update(fontdict)
169 title._internal_update(kwargs)
170 return title
171

◆ specgram()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.specgram (   self,
  x,
  NFFT = None,
  Fs = None,
  Fc = None,
  detrend = None,
  window = None,
  noverlap = None,
  cmap = None,
  xextent = None,
  pad_to = None,
  sides = None,
  scale_by_freq = None,
  mode = None,
  scale = None,
  vmin = None,
  vmax = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot a spectrogram.

Compute and plot a spectrogram of data in *x*.  Data are split into
*NFFT* length segments and the spectrum of each section is
computed.  The windowing function *window* is applied to each
segment, and the amount of overlap of each segment is
specified with *noverlap*. The spectrogram is plotted as a colormap
(using imshow).

Parameters
----------
x : 1-D array or sequence
    Array or sequence containing the data.

%(Spectral)s

%(PSD)s

mode : {'default', 'psd', 'magnitude', 'angle', 'phase'}
    What sort of spectrum to use.  Default is 'psd', which takes the
    power spectral density.  'magnitude' returns the magnitude
    spectrum.  'angle' returns the phase spectrum without unwrapping.
    'phase' returns the phase spectrum with unwrapping.

noverlap : int, default: 128
    The number of points of overlap between blocks.

scale : {'default', 'linear', 'dB'}
    The scaling of the values in the *spec*.  'linear' is no scaling.
    'dB' returns the values in dB scale.  When *mode* is 'psd',
    this is dB power (10 * log10).  Otherwise this is dB amplitude
    (20 * log10). 'default' is 'dB' if *mode* is 'psd' or
    'magnitude' and 'linear' otherwise.  This must be 'linear'
    if *mode* is 'angle' or 'phase'.

Fc : int, default: 0
    The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
    plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
    and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.

cmap : `.Colormap`, default: :rc:`image.cmap`

xextent : *None* or (xmin, xmax)
    The image extent along the x-axis. The default sets *xmin* to the
    left border of the first bin (*spectrum* column) and *xmax* to the
    right border of the last bin. Note that for *noverlap>0* the width
    of the bins is smaller than those of the segments.

data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    Additional keyword arguments are passed on to `~.axes.Axes.imshow`
    which makes the specgram image. The origin keyword argument
    is not supported.

Returns
-------
spectrum : 2D array
    Columns are the periodograms of successive segments.

freqs : 1-D array
    The frequencies corresponding to the rows in *spectrum*.

t : 1-D array
    The times corresponding to midpoints of segments (i.e., the columns
    in *spectrum*).

im : `.AxesImage`
    The image created by imshow containing the spectrogram.

See Also
--------
psd
    Differs in the default overlap; in returning the mean of the
    segment periodograms; in not returning times; and in generating a
    line plot instead of colormap.
magnitude_spectrum
    A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode*
    is 'magnitude'. Plots a line instead of a colormap.
angle_spectrum
    A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode*
    is 'angle'. Plots a line instead of a colormap.
phase_spectrum
    A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode*
    is 'phase'. Plots a line instead of a colormap.

Notes
-----
The parameters *detrend* and *scale_by_freq* do only apply when *mode*
is set to 'psd'.
7595 vmin=None, vmax=None, **kwargs):
7596 """
7597 Plot a spectrogram.
7598
7599 Compute and plot a spectrogram of data in *x*. Data are split into
7600 *NFFT* length segments and the spectrum of each section is
7601 computed. The windowing function *window* is applied to each
7602 segment, and the amount of overlap of each segment is
7603 specified with *noverlap*. The spectrogram is plotted as a colormap
7604 (using imshow).
7605
7606 Parameters
7607 ----------
7608 x : 1-D array or sequence
7609 Array or sequence containing the data.
7610
7611 %(Spectral)s
7612
7613 %(PSD)s
7614
7615 mode : {'default', 'psd', 'magnitude', 'angle', 'phase'}
7616 What sort of spectrum to use. Default is 'psd', which takes the
7617 power spectral density. 'magnitude' returns the magnitude
7618 spectrum. 'angle' returns the phase spectrum without unwrapping.
7619 'phase' returns the phase spectrum with unwrapping.
7620
7621 noverlap : int, default: 128
7622 The number of points of overlap between blocks.
7623
7624 scale : {'default', 'linear', 'dB'}
7625 The scaling of the values in the *spec*. 'linear' is no scaling.
7626 'dB' returns the values in dB scale. When *mode* is 'psd',
7627 this is dB power (10 * log10). Otherwise this is dB amplitude
7628 (20 * log10). 'default' is 'dB' if *mode* is 'psd' or
7629 'magnitude' and 'linear' otherwise. This must be 'linear'
7630 if *mode* is 'angle' or 'phase'.
7631
7632 Fc : int, default: 0
7633 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the
7634 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired
7635 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.
7636
7637 cmap : `.Colormap`, default: :rc:`image.cmap`
7638
7639 xextent : *None* or (xmin, xmax)
7640 The image extent along the x-axis. The default sets *xmin* to the
7641 left border of the first bin (*spectrum* column) and *xmax* to the
7642 right border of the last bin. Note that for *noverlap>0* the width
7643 of the bins is smaller than those of the segments.
7644
7645 data : indexable object, optional
7646 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
7647
7648 **kwargs
7649 Additional keyword arguments are passed on to `~.axes.Axes.imshow`
7650 which makes the specgram image. The origin keyword argument
7651 is not supported.
7652
7653 Returns
7654 -------
7655 spectrum : 2D array
7656 Columns are the periodograms of successive segments.
7657
7658 freqs : 1-D array
7659 The frequencies corresponding to the rows in *spectrum*.
7660
7661 t : 1-D array
7662 The times corresponding to midpoints of segments (i.e., the columns
7663 in *spectrum*).
7664
7665 im : `.AxesImage`
7666 The image created by imshow containing the spectrogram.
7667
7668 See Also
7669 --------
7670 psd
7671 Differs in the default overlap; in returning the mean of the
7672 segment periodograms; in not returning times; and in generating a
7673 line plot instead of colormap.
7674 magnitude_spectrum
7675 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode*
7676 is 'magnitude'. Plots a line instead of a colormap.
7677 angle_spectrum
7678 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode*
7679 is 'angle'. Plots a line instead of a colormap.
7680 phase_spectrum
7681 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode*
7682 is 'phase'. Plots a line instead of a colormap.
7683
7684 Notes
7685 -----
7686 The parameters *detrend* and *scale_by_freq* do only apply when *mode*
7687 is set to 'psd'.
7688 """
7689 if NFFT is None:
7690 NFFT = 256 # same default as in mlab.specgram()
7691 if Fc is None:
7692 Fc = 0 # same default as in mlab._spectral_helper()
7693 if noverlap is None:
7694 noverlap = 128 # same default as in mlab.specgram()
7695 if Fs is None:
7696 Fs = 2 # same default as in mlab._spectral_helper()
7697
7698 if mode == 'complex':
7699 raise ValueError('Cannot plot a complex specgram')
7700
7701 if scale is None or scale == 'default':
7702 if mode in ['angle', 'phase']:
7703 scale = 'linear'
7704 else:
7705 scale = 'dB'
7706 elif mode in ['angle', 'phase'] and scale == 'dB':
7707 raise ValueError('Cannot use dB scale with angle or phase mode')
7708
7709 spec, freqs, t = mlab.specgram(x=x, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs,
7710 detrend=detrend, window=window,
7711 noverlap=noverlap, pad_to=pad_to,
7712 sides=sides,
7713 scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq,
7714 mode=mode)
7715
7716 if scale == 'linear':
7717 Z = spec
7718 elif scale == 'dB':
7719 if mode is None or mode == 'default' or mode == 'psd':
7720 Z = 10. * np.log10(spec)
7721 else:
7722 Z = 20. * np.log10(spec)
7723 else:
7724 raise ValueError(f'Unknown scale {scale!r}')
7725
7726 Z = np.flipud(Z)
7727
7728 if xextent is None:
7729 # padding is needed for first and last segment:
7730 pad_xextent = (NFFT-noverlap) / Fs / 2
7731 xextent = np.min(t) - pad_xextent, np.max(t) + pad_xextent
7732 xmin, xmax = xextent
7733 freqs += Fc
7734 extent = xmin, xmax, freqs[0], freqs[-1]
7735
7736 if 'origin' in kwargs:
7737 raise TypeError("specgram() got an unexpected keyword argument "
7738 "'origin'")
7739
7740 im = self.imshow(Z, cmap, extent=extent, vmin=vmin, vmax=vmax,
7741 origin='upper', **kwargs)
7742 self.axis('auto')
7743
7744 return spec, freqs, t, im
7745

◆ spy()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.spy (   self,
  Z,
  precision = 0,
  marker = None,
  markersize = None,
  aspect = 'equal',
  origin = "upper",
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot the sparsity pattern of a 2D array.

This visualizes the non-zero values of the array.

Two plotting styles are available: image and marker. Both
are available for full arrays, but only the marker style
works for `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` instances.

**Image style**

If *marker* and *markersize* are *None*, `~.Axes.imshow` is used. Any
extra remaining keyword arguments are passed to this method.

**Marker style**

If *Z* is a `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` or *marker* or *markersize* are
*None*, a `.Line2D` object will be returned with the value of marker
determining the marker type, and any remaining keyword arguments
passed to `~.Axes.plot`.

Parameters
----------
Z : (M, N) array-like
    The array to be plotted.

precision : float or 'present', default: 0
    If *precision* is 0, any non-zero value will be plotted. Otherwise,
    values of :math:`|Z| > precision` will be plotted.

    For `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` instances, you can also
    pass 'present'. In this case any value present in the array
    will be plotted, even if it is identically zero.

aspect : {'equal', 'auto', None} or float, default: 'equal'
    The aspect ratio of the Axes.  This parameter is particularly
    relevant for images since it determines whether data pixels are
    square.

    This parameter is a shortcut for explicitly calling
    `.Axes.set_aspect`. See there for further details.

    - 'equal': Ensures an aspect ratio of 1. Pixels will be square.
    - 'auto': The Axes is kept fixed and the aspect is adjusted so
      that the data fit in the Axes. In general, this will result in
      non-square pixels.
    - *None*: Use :rc:`image.aspect`.

origin : {'upper', 'lower'}, default: :rc:`image.origin`
    Place the [0, 0] index of the array in the upper left or lower left
    corner of the Axes. The convention 'upper' is typically used for
    matrices and images.

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.image.AxesImage` or `.Line2D`
    The return type depends on the plotting style (see above).

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs
    The supported additional parameters depend on the plotting style.

    For the image style, you can pass the following additional
    parameters of `~.Axes.imshow`:

    - *cmap*
    - *alpha*
    - *url*
    - any `.Artist` properties (passed on to the `.AxesImage`)

    For the marker style, you can pass any `.Line2D` property except
    for *linestyle*:

    %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
7748 aspect='equal', origin="upper", **kwargs):
7749 """
7750 Plot the sparsity pattern of a 2D array.
7751
7752 This visualizes the non-zero values of the array.
7753
7754 Two plotting styles are available: image and marker. Both
7755 are available for full arrays, but only the marker style
7756 works for `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` instances.
7757
7758 **Image style**
7759
7760 If *marker* and *markersize* are *None*, `~.Axes.imshow` is used. Any
7761 extra remaining keyword arguments are passed to this method.
7762
7763 **Marker style**
7764
7765 If *Z* is a `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` or *marker* or *markersize* are
7766 *None*, a `.Line2D` object will be returned with the value of marker
7767 determining the marker type, and any remaining keyword arguments
7768 passed to `~.Axes.plot`.
7769
7770 Parameters
7771 ----------
7772 Z : (M, N) array-like
7773 The array to be plotted.
7774
7775 precision : float or 'present', default: 0
7776 If *precision* is 0, any non-zero value will be plotted. Otherwise,
7777 values of :math:`|Z| > precision` will be plotted.
7778
7779 For `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` instances, you can also
7780 pass 'present'. In this case any value present in the array
7781 will be plotted, even if it is identically zero.
7782
7783 aspect : {'equal', 'auto', None} or float, default: 'equal'
7784 The aspect ratio of the Axes. This parameter is particularly
7785 relevant for images since it determines whether data pixels are
7786 square.
7787
7788 This parameter is a shortcut for explicitly calling
7789 `.Axes.set_aspect`. See there for further details.
7790
7791 - 'equal': Ensures an aspect ratio of 1. Pixels will be square.
7792 - 'auto': The Axes is kept fixed and the aspect is adjusted so
7793 that the data fit in the Axes. In general, this will result in
7794 non-square pixels.
7795 - *None*: Use :rc:`image.aspect`.
7796
7797 origin : {'upper', 'lower'}, default: :rc:`image.origin`
7798 Place the [0, 0] index of the array in the upper left or lower left
7799 corner of the Axes. The convention 'upper' is typically used for
7800 matrices and images.
7801
7802 Returns
7803 -------
7804 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage` or `.Line2D`
7805 The return type depends on the plotting style (see above).
7806
7807 Other Parameters
7808 ----------------
7809 **kwargs
7810 The supported additional parameters depend on the plotting style.
7811
7812 For the image style, you can pass the following additional
7813 parameters of `~.Axes.imshow`:
7814
7815 - *cmap*
7816 - *alpha*
7817 - *url*
7818 - any `.Artist` properties (passed on to the `.AxesImage`)
7819
7820 For the marker style, you can pass any `.Line2D` property except
7821 for *linestyle*:
7822
7823 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
7824 """
7825 if marker is None and markersize is None and hasattr(Z, 'tocoo'):
7826 marker = 's'
7827 _api.check_in_list(["upper", "lower"], origin=origin)
7828 if marker is None and markersize is None:
7829 Z = np.asarray(Z)
7830 mask = np.abs(Z) > precision
7831
7832 if 'cmap' not in kwargs:
7833 kwargs['cmap'] = mcolors.ListedColormap(['w', 'k'],
7834 name='binary')
7835 if 'interpolation' in kwargs:
7836 raise TypeError(
7837 "spy() got an unexpected keyword argument 'interpolation'")
7838 if 'norm' not in kwargs:
7839 kwargs['norm'] = mcolors.NoNorm()
7840 ret = self.imshow(mask, interpolation='nearest',
7841 aspect=aspect, origin=origin,
7842 **kwargs)
7843 else:
7844 if hasattr(Z, 'tocoo'):
7845 c = Z.tocoo()
7846 if precision == 'present':
7847 y = c.row
7848 x = c.col
7849 else:
7850 nonzero = np.abs(c.data) > precision
7851 y = c.row[nonzero]
7852 x = c.col[nonzero]
7853 else:
7854 Z = np.asarray(Z)
7855 nonzero = np.abs(Z) > precision
7856 y, x = np.nonzero(nonzero)
7857 if marker is None:
7858 marker = 's'
7859 if markersize is None:
7860 markersize = 10
7861 if 'linestyle' in kwargs:
7862 raise TypeError(
7863 "spy() got an unexpected keyword argument 'linestyle'")
7864 ret = mlines.Line2D(
7865 x, y, linestyle='None', marker=marker, markersize=markersize,
7866 **kwargs)
7867 self.add_line(ret)
7868 nr, nc = Z.shape
7869 self.set_xlim(-0.5, nc - 0.5)
7870 if origin == "upper":
7871 self.set_ylim(nr - 0.5, -0.5)
7872 else:
7873 self.set_ylim(-0.5, nr - 0.5)
7874 self.set_aspect(aspect)
7875 self.title.set_y(1.05)
7876 if origin == "upper":
7877 self.xaxis.tick_top()
7878 else: # lower
7879 self.xaxis.tick_bottom()
7880 self.xaxis.set_ticks_position('both')
7881 self.xaxis.set_major_locator(
7882 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True))
7883 self.yaxis.set_major_locator(
7884 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True))
7885 return ret
7886

◆ stairs()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.stairs (   self,
  values,
  edges = None,
*  orientation = 'vertical',
  baseline = 0,
  fill = False,
**  kwargs 
) 
A stepwise constant function as a line with bounding edges
or a filled plot.

Parameters
----------
values : array-like
    The step heights.

edges : array-like
    The edge positions, with ``len(edges) == len(vals) + 1``,
    between which the curve takes on vals values.

orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical'
    The direction of the steps. Vertical means that *values* are along
    the y-axis, and edges are along the x-axis.

baseline : float, array-like or None, default: 0
    The bottom value of the bounding edges or when
    ``fill=True``, position of lower edge. If *fill* is
    True or an array is passed to *baseline*, a closed
    path is drawn.

fill : bool, default: False
    Whether the area under the step curve should be filled.

Returns
-------
StepPatch : `matplotlib.patches.StepPatch`

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

**kwargs
    `~matplotlib.patches.StepPatch` properties
6906 orientation='vertical', baseline=0, fill=False, **kwargs):
6907 """
6908 A stepwise constant function as a line with bounding edges
6909 or a filled plot.
6910
6911 Parameters
6912 ----------
6913 values : array-like
6914 The step heights.
6915
6916 edges : array-like
6917 The edge positions, with ``len(edges) == len(vals) + 1``,
6918 between which the curve takes on vals values.
6919
6920 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical'
6921 The direction of the steps. Vertical means that *values* are along
6922 the y-axis, and edges are along the x-axis.
6923
6924 baseline : float, array-like or None, default: 0
6925 The bottom value of the bounding edges or when
6926 ``fill=True``, position of lower edge. If *fill* is
6927 True or an array is passed to *baseline*, a closed
6928 path is drawn.
6929
6930 fill : bool, default: False
6931 Whether the area under the step curve should be filled.
6932
6933 Returns
6934 -------
6935 StepPatch : `matplotlib.patches.StepPatch`
6936
6937 Other Parameters
6938 ----------------
6939 data : indexable object, optional
6940 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
6941
6942 **kwargs
6943 `~matplotlib.patches.StepPatch` properties
6944
6945 """
6946
6947 if 'color' in kwargs:
6948 _color = kwargs.pop('color')
6949 else:
6950 _color = self._get_lines.get_next_color()
6951 if fill:
6952 kwargs.setdefault('linewidth', 0)
6953 kwargs.setdefault('facecolor', _color)
6954 else:
6955 kwargs.setdefault('edgecolor', _color)
6956
6957 if edges is None:
6958 edges = np.arange(len(values) + 1)
6959
6960 edges, values, baseline = self._process_unit_info(
6961 [("x", edges), ("y", values), ("y", baseline)], kwargs)
6962
6963 patch = mpatches.StepPatch(values,
6964 edges,
6965 baseline=baseline,
6966 orientation=orientation,
6967 fill=fill,
6968 **kwargs)
6969 self.add_patch(patch)
6970 if baseline is None:
6971 baseline = 0
6972 if orientation == 'vertical':
6973 patch.sticky_edges.y.append(np.min(baseline))
6974 self.update_datalim([(edges[0], np.min(baseline))])
6975 else:
6976 patch.sticky_edges.x.append(np.min(baseline))
6977 self.update_datalim([(np.min(baseline), edges[0])])
6978 self._request_autoscale_view()
6979 return patch
6980

◆ stem()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.stem (   self,
*  args,
  linefmt = None,
  markerfmt = None,
  basefmt = None,
  bottom = 0,
  label = None,
  use_line_collection = True,
  orientation = 'vertical' 
) 
Create a stem plot.

A stem plot draws lines perpendicular to a baseline at each location
*locs* from the baseline to *heads*, and places a marker there. For
vertical stem plots (the default), the *locs* are *x* positions, and
the *heads* are *y* values. For horizontal stem plots, the *locs* are
*y* positions, and the *heads* are *x* values.

Call signature::

  stem([locs,] heads, linefmt=None, markerfmt=None, basefmt=None)

The *locs*-positions are optional. The formats may be provided either
as positional or as keyword-arguments.
Passing *markerfmt* and *basefmt* positionally is deprecated since
Matplotlib 3.5.

Parameters
----------
locs : array-like, default: (0, 1, ..., len(heads) - 1)
    For vertical stem plots, the x-positions of the stems.
    For horizontal stem plots, the y-positions of the stems.

heads : array-like
    For vertical stem plots, the y-values of the stem heads.
    For horizontal stem plots, the x-values of the stem heads.

linefmt : str, optional
    A string defining the color and/or linestyle of the vertical lines:

    =========  =============
    Character  Line Style
    =========  =============
    ``'-'``    solid line
    ``'--'``   dashed line
    ``'-.'``   dash-dot line
    ``':'``    dotted line
    =========  =============

    Default: 'C0-', i.e. solid line with the first color of the color
    cycle.

    Note: Markers specified through this parameter (e.g. 'x') will be
    silently ignored (unless using ``use_line_collection=False``).
    Instead, markers should be specified using *markerfmt*.

markerfmt : str, optional
    A string defining the color and/or shape of the markers at the stem
    heads. If the marker is not given, use the marker 'o', i.e. filled
    circles. If the color is not given, use the color from *linefmt*.

basefmt : str, default: 'C3-' ('C2-' in classic mode)
    A format string defining the properties of the baseline.

orientation : str, default: 'vertical'
    If 'vertical', will produce a plot with stems oriented vertically,
    otherwise the stems will be oriented horizontally.

bottom : float, default: 0
    The y/x-position of the baseline (depending on orientation).

label : str, default: None
    The label to use for the stems in legends.

use_line_collection : bool, default: True
    *Deprecated since 3.6*

    If ``True``, store and plot the stem lines as a
    `~.collections.LineCollection` instead of individual lines, which
    significantly increases performance.  If ``False``, defaults to the
    old behavior of using a list of `.Line2D` objects.

data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

Returns
-------
`.StemContainer`
    The container may be treated like a tuple
    (*markerline*, *stemlines*, *baseline*)

Notes
-----
.. seealso::
    The MATLAB function
    `stem <https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/stem.html>`_
    which inspired this method.

Reimplemented in mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.

2854 label=None, use_line_collection=True, orientation='vertical'):
2855 """
2856 Create a stem plot.
2857
2858 A stem plot draws lines perpendicular to a baseline at each location
2859 *locs* from the baseline to *heads*, and places a marker there. For
2860 vertical stem plots (the default), the *locs* are *x* positions, and
2861 the *heads* are *y* values. For horizontal stem plots, the *locs* are
2862 *y* positions, and the *heads* are *x* values.
2863
2864 Call signature::
2865
2866 stem([locs,] heads, linefmt=None, markerfmt=None, basefmt=None)
2867
2868 The *locs*-positions are optional. The formats may be provided either
2869 as positional or as keyword-arguments.
2870 Passing *markerfmt* and *basefmt* positionally is deprecated since
2871 Matplotlib 3.5.
2872
2873 Parameters
2874 ----------
2875 locs : array-like, default: (0, 1, ..., len(heads) - 1)
2876 For vertical stem plots, the x-positions of the stems.
2877 For horizontal stem plots, the y-positions of the stems.
2878
2879 heads : array-like
2880 For vertical stem plots, the y-values of the stem heads.
2881 For horizontal stem plots, the x-values of the stem heads.
2882
2883 linefmt : str, optional
2884 A string defining the color and/or linestyle of the vertical lines:
2885
2886 ========= =============
2887 Character Line Style
2888 ========= =============
2889 ``'-'`` solid line
2890 ``'--'`` dashed line
2891 ``'-.'`` dash-dot line
2892 ``':'`` dotted line
2893 ========= =============
2894
2895 Default: 'C0-', i.e. solid line with the first color of the color
2896 cycle.
2897
2898 Note: Markers specified through this parameter (e.g. 'x') will be
2899 silently ignored (unless using ``use_line_collection=False``).
2900 Instead, markers should be specified using *markerfmt*.
2901
2902 markerfmt : str, optional
2903 A string defining the color and/or shape of the markers at the stem
2904 heads. If the marker is not given, use the marker 'o', i.e. filled
2905 circles. If the color is not given, use the color from *linefmt*.
2906
2907 basefmt : str, default: 'C3-' ('C2-' in classic mode)
2908 A format string defining the properties of the baseline.
2909
2910 orientation : str, default: 'vertical'
2911 If 'vertical', will produce a plot with stems oriented vertically,
2912 otherwise the stems will be oriented horizontally.
2913
2914 bottom : float, default: 0
2915 The y/x-position of the baseline (depending on orientation).
2916
2917 label : str, default: None
2918 The label to use for the stems in legends.
2919
2920 use_line_collection : bool, default: True
2921 *Deprecated since 3.6*
2922
2923 If ``True``, store and plot the stem lines as a
2924 `~.collections.LineCollection` instead of individual lines, which
2925 significantly increases performance. If ``False``, defaults to the
2926 old behavior of using a list of `.Line2D` objects.
2927
2928 data : indexable object, optional
2929 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
2930
2931 Returns
2932 -------
2933 `.StemContainer`
2934 The container may be treated like a tuple
2935 (*markerline*, *stemlines*, *baseline*)
2936
2937 Notes
2938 -----
2939 .. seealso::
2940 The MATLAB function
2941 `stem <https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/stem.html>`_
2942 which inspired this method.
2943 """
2944 if not 1 <= len(args) <= 5:
2945 raise TypeError('stem expected between 1 and 5 positional '
2946 'arguments, got {}'.format(args))
2947 _api.check_in_list(['horizontal', 'vertical'], orientation=orientation)
2948
2949 if len(args) == 1:
2950 heads, = args
2951 locs = np.arange(len(heads))
2952 args = ()
2953 elif isinstance(args[1], str):
2954 heads, *args = args
2955 locs = np.arange(len(heads))
2956 else:
2957 locs, heads, *args = args
2958 if len(args) > 1:
2959 _api.warn_deprecated(
2960 "3.5",
2961 message="Passing the markerfmt parameter positionally is "
2962 "deprecated since Matplotlib %(since)s; the "
2963 "parameter will become keyword-only %(removal)s.")
2964
2965 if orientation == 'vertical':
2966 locs, heads = self._process_unit_info([("x", locs), ("y", heads)])
2967 else: # horizontal
2968 heads, locs = self._process_unit_info([("x", heads), ("y", locs)])
2969
2970 # resolve line format
2971 if linefmt is None:
2972 linefmt = args[0] if len(args) > 0 else "C0-"
2973 linestyle, linemarker, linecolor = _process_plot_format(linefmt)
2974
2975 # resolve marker format
2976 if markerfmt is None:
2977 # if not given as kwarg, check for positional or fall back to 'o'
2978 markerfmt = args[1] if len(args) > 1 else "o"
2979 if markerfmt == '':
2980 markerfmt = ' ' # = empty line style; '' would resolve rcParams
2981 markerstyle, markermarker, markercolor = \
2982 _process_plot_format(markerfmt)
2983 if markermarker is None:
2984 markermarker = 'o'
2985 if markerstyle is None:
2986 markerstyle = 'None'
2987 if markercolor is None:
2988 markercolor = linecolor
2989
2990 # resolve baseline format
2991 if basefmt is None:
2992 basefmt = (args[2] if len(args) > 2 else
2993 "C2-" if mpl.rcParams["_internal.classic_mode"] else
2994 "C3-")
2995 basestyle, basemarker, basecolor = _process_plot_format(basefmt)
2996
2997 # New behaviour in 3.1 is to use a LineCollection for the stemlines
2998 if use_line_collection:
2999 if linestyle is None:
3000 linestyle = mpl.rcParams['lines.linestyle']
3001 xlines = self.vlines if orientation == "vertical" else self.hlines
3002 stemlines = xlines(
3003 locs, bottom, heads,
3004 colors=linecolor, linestyles=linestyle, label="_nolegend_")
3005 # Old behaviour is to plot each of the lines individually
3006 else:
3007 stemlines = []
3008 for loc, head in zip(locs, heads):
3009 if orientation == 'horizontal':
3010 xs = [bottom, head]
3011 ys = [loc, loc]
3012 else:
3013 xs = [loc, loc]
3014 ys = [bottom, head]
3015 l, = self.plot(xs, ys,
3016 color=linecolor, linestyle=linestyle,
3017 marker=linemarker, label="_nolegend_")
3018 stemlines.append(l)
3019
3020 if orientation == 'horizontal':
3021 marker_x = heads
3022 marker_y = locs
3023 baseline_x = [bottom, bottom]
3024 baseline_y = [np.min(locs), np.max(locs)]
3025 else:
3026 marker_x = locs
3027 marker_y = heads
3028 baseline_x = [np.min(locs), np.max(locs)]
3029 baseline_y = [bottom, bottom]
3030
3031 markerline, = self.plot(marker_x, marker_y,
3032 color=markercolor, linestyle=markerstyle,
3033 marker=markermarker, label="_nolegend_")
3034
3035 baseline, = self.plot(baseline_x, baseline_y,
3036 color=basecolor, linestyle=basestyle,
3037 marker=basemarker, label="_nolegend_")
3038
3039 stem_container = StemContainer((markerline, stemlines, baseline),
3040 label=label)
3041 self.add_container(stem_container)
3042 return stem_container
3043

◆ step()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.step (   self,
  x,
  y,
*  args,
  where = 'pre',
  data = None,
**  kwargs 
)

Specialized plotting. 

Make a step plot.

Call signatures::

    step(x, y, [fmt], *, data=None, where='pre', **kwargs)
    step(x, y, [fmt], x2, y2, [fmt2], ..., *, where='pre', **kwargs)

This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which changes some
formatting options. Most of the concepts and parameters of plot can be
used here as well.

.. note::

    This method uses a standard plot with a step drawstyle: The *x*
    values are the reference positions and steps extend left/right/both
    directions depending on *where*.

    For the common case where you know the values and edges of the
    steps, use `~.Axes.stairs` instead.

Parameters
----------
x : array-like
    1D sequence of x positions. It is assumed, but not checked, that
    it is uniformly increasing.

y : array-like
    1D sequence of y levels.

fmt : str, optional
    A format string, e.g. 'g' for a green line. See `.plot` for a more
    detailed description.

    Note: While full format strings are accepted, it is recommended to
    only specify the color. Line styles are currently ignored (use
    the keyword argument *linestyle* instead). Markers are accepted
    and plotted on the given positions, however, this is a rarely
    needed feature for step plots.

where : {'pre', 'post', 'mid'}, default: 'pre'
    Define where the steps should be placed:

    - 'pre': The y value is continued constantly to the left from
      every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``(x[i-1], x[i]]`` has the
      value ``y[i]``.
    - 'post': The y value is continued constantly to the right from
      every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``[x[i], x[i+1])`` has the
      value ``y[i]``.
    - 'mid': Steps occur half-way between the *x* positions.

data : indexable object, optional
    An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to
    plot in *x* and *y*.

**kwargs
    Additional parameters are the same as those for `.plot`.

Returns
-------
list of `.Line2D`
    Objects representing the plotted data.
2084 def step(self, x, y, *args, where='pre', data=None, **kwargs):
2085 """
2086 Make a step plot.
2087
2088 Call signatures::
2089
2090 step(x, y, [fmt], *, data=None, where='pre', **kwargs)
2091 step(x, y, [fmt], x2, y2, [fmt2], ..., *, where='pre', **kwargs)
2092
2093 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which changes some
2094 formatting options. Most of the concepts and parameters of plot can be
2095 used here as well.
2096
2097 .. note::
2098
2099 This method uses a standard plot with a step drawstyle: The *x*
2100 values are the reference positions and steps extend left/right/both
2101 directions depending on *where*.
2102
2103 For the common case where you know the values and edges of the
2104 steps, use `~.Axes.stairs` instead.
2105
2106 Parameters
2107 ----------
2108 x : array-like
2109 1D sequence of x positions. It is assumed, but not checked, that
2110 it is uniformly increasing.
2111
2112 y : array-like
2113 1D sequence of y levels.
2114
2115 fmt : str, optional
2116 A format string, e.g. 'g' for a green line. See `.plot` for a more
2117 detailed description.
2118
2119 Note: While full format strings are accepted, it is recommended to
2120 only specify the color. Line styles are currently ignored (use
2121 the keyword argument *linestyle* instead). Markers are accepted
2122 and plotted on the given positions, however, this is a rarely
2123 needed feature for step plots.
2124
2125 where : {'pre', 'post', 'mid'}, default: 'pre'
2126 Define where the steps should be placed:
2127
2128 - 'pre': The y value is continued constantly to the left from
2129 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``(x[i-1], x[i]]`` has the
2130 value ``y[i]``.
2131 - 'post': The y value is continued constantly to the right from
2132 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``[x[i], x[i+1])`` has the
2133 value ``y[i]``.
2134 - 'mid': Steps occur half-way between the *x* positions.
2135
2136 data : indexable object, optional
2137 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to
2138 plot in *x* and *y*.
2139
2140 **kwargs
2141 Additional parameters are the same as those for `.plot`.
2142
2143 Returns
2144 -------
2145 list of `.Line2D`
2146 Objects representing the plotted data.
2147 """
2148 _api.check_in_list(('pre', 'post', 'mid'), where=where)
2149 kwargs['drawstyle'] = 'steps-' + where
2150 return self.plot(x, y, *args, data=data, **kwargs)
2151

◆ text()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.text (   self,
  x,
  y,
  s,
  fontdict = None,
**  kwargs 
) 
Add text to the Axes.

Add the text *s* to the Axes at location *x*, *y* in data coordinates.

Parameters
----------
x, y : float
    The position to place the text. By default, this is in data
    coordinates. The coordinate system can be changed using the
    *transform* parameter.

s : str
    The text.

fontdict : dict, default: None
    A dictionary to override the default text properties. If fontdict
    is None, the defaults are determined by `.rcParams`.

Returns
-------
`.Text`
    The created `.Text` instance.

Other Parameters
----------------
**kwargs : `~matplotlib.text.Text` properties.
    Other miscellaneous text parameters.

    %(Text:kwdoc)s

Examples
--------
Individual keyword arguments can be used to override any given
parameter::

    >>> text(x, y, s, fontsize=12)

The default transform specifies that text is in data coords,
alternatively, you can specify text in axis coords ((0, 0) is
lower-left and (1, 1) is upper-right).  The example below places
text in the center of the Axes::

    >>> text(0.5, 0.5, 'matplotlib', horizontalalignment='center',
    ...      verticalalignment='center', transform=ax.transAxes)

You can put a rectangular box around the text instance (e.g., to
set a background color) by using the keyword *bbox*.  *bbox* is
a dictionary of `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle`
properties.  For example::

    >>> text(x, y, s, bbox=dict(facecolor='red', alpha=0.5))

Reimplemented in mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.

616 def text(self, x, y, s, fontdict=None, **kwargs):
617 """
618 Add text to the Axes.
619
620 Add the text *s* to the Axes at location *x*, *y* in data coordinates.
621
622 Parameters
623 ----------
624 x, y : float
625 The position to place the text. By default, this is in data
626 coordinates. The coordinate system can be changed using the
627 *transform* parameter.
628
629 s : str
630 The text.
631
632 fontdict : dict, default: None
633 A dictionary to override the default text properties. If fontdict
634 is None, the defaults are determined by `.rcParams`.
635
636 Returns
637 -------
638 `.Text`
639 The created `.Text` instance.
640
641 Other Parameters
642 ----------------
643 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.text.Text` properties.
644 Other miscellaneous text parameters.
645
646 %(Text:kwdoc)s
647
648 Examples
649 --------
650 Individual keyword arguments can be used to override any given
651 parameter::
652
653 >>> text(x, y, s, fontsize=12)
654
655 The default transform specifies that text is in data coords,
656 alternatively, you can specify text in axis coords ((0, 0) is
657 lower-left and (1, 1) is upper-right). The example below places
658 text in the center of the Axes::
659
660 >>> text(0.5, 0.5, 'matplotlib', horizontalalignment='center',
661 ... verticalalignment='center', transform=ax.transAxes)
662
663 You can put a rectangular box around the text instance (e.g., to
664 set a background color) by using the keyword *bbox*. *bbox* is
665 a dictionary of `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle`
666 properties. For example::
667
668 >>> text(x, y, s, bbox=dict(facecolor='red', alpha=0.5))
669 """
670 effective_kwargs = {
671 'verticalalignment': 'baseline',
672 'horizontalalignment': 'left',
673 'transform': self.transData,
674 'clip_on': False,
675 **(fontdict if fontdict is not None else {}),
676 **kwargs,
677 }
678 t = mtext.Text(x, y, text=s, **effective_kwargs)
679 t.set_clip_path(self.patch)
680 self._add_text(t)
681 return t
682

◆ violin()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.violin (   self,
  vpstats,
  positions = None,
  vert = True,
  widths = 0.5,
  showmeans = False,
  showextrema = True,
  showmedians = False 
) 
Drawing function for violin plots.

Draw a violin plot for each column of *vpstats*. Each filled area
extends to represent the entire data range, with optional lines at the
mean, the median, the minimum, the maximum, and the quantiles values.

Parameters
----------
vpstats : list of dicts
  A list of dictionaries containing stats for each violin plot.
  Required keys are:

  - ``coords``: A list of scalars containing the coordinates that
    the violin's kernel density estimate were evaluated at.

  - ``vals``: A list of scalars containing the values of the
    kernel density estimate at each of the coordinates given
    in *coords*.

  - ``mean``: The mean value for this violin's dataset.

  - ``median``: The median value for this violin's dataset.

  - ``min``: The minimum value for this violin's dataset.

  - ``max``: The maximum value for this violin's dataset.

  Optional keys are:

  - ``quantiles``: A list of scalars containing the quantile values
    for this violin's dataset.

positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n]
  The positions of the violins. The ticks and limits are
  automatically set to match the positions.

vert : bool, default: True.
  If true, plots the violins vertically.
  Otherwise, plots the violins horizontally.

widths : array-like, default: 0.5
  Either a scalar or a vector that sets the maximal width of
  each violin. The default is 0.5, which uses about half of the
  available horizontal space.

showmeans : bool, default: False
  If true, will toggle rendering of the means.

showextrema : bool, default: True
  If true, will toggle rendering of the extrema.

showmedians : bool, default: False
  If true, will toggle rendering of the medians.

Returns
-------
dict
  A dictionary mapping each component of the violinplot to a
  list of the corresponding collection instances created. The
  dictionary has the following keys:

  - ``bodies``: A list of the `~.collections.PolyCollection`
    instances containing the filled area of each violin.

  - ``cmeans``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
    the mean values of each of the violin's distribution.

  - ``cmins``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
    the bottom of each violin's distribution.

  - ``cmaxes``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
    the top of each violin's distribution.

  - ``cbars``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
    the centers of each violin's distribution.

  - ``cmedians``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that
    marks the median values of each of the violin's distribution.

  - ``cquantiles``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance created
    to identify the quantiles values of each of the violin's
    distribution.
8044 showmeans=False, showextrema=True, showmedians=False):
8045 """
8046 Drawing function for violin plots.
8047
8048 Draw a violin plot for each column of *vpstats*. Each filled area
8049 extends to represent the entire data range, with optional lines at the
8050 mean, the median, the minimum, the maximum, and the quantiles values.
8051
8052 Parameters
8053 ----------
8054 vpstats : list of dicts
8055 A list of dictionaries containing stats for each violin plot.
8056 Required keys are:
8057
8058 - ``coords``: A list of scalars containing the coordinates that
8059 the violin's kernel density estimate were evaluated at.
8060
8061 - ``vals``: A list of scalars containing the values of the
8062 kernel density estimate at each of the coordinates given
8063 in *coords*.
8064
8065 - ``mean``: The mean value for this violin's dataset.
8066
8067 - ``median``: The median value for this violin's dataset.
8068
8069 - ``min``: The minimum value for this violin's dataset.
8070
8071 - ``max``: The maximum value for this violin's dataset.
8072
8073 Optional keys are:
8074
8075 - ``quantiles``: A list of scalars containing the quantile values
8076 for this violin's dataset.
8077
8078 positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n]
8079 The positions of the violins. The ticks and limits are
8080 automatically set to match the positions.
8081
8082 vert : bool, default: True.
8083 If true, plots the violins vertically.
8084 Otherwise, plots the violins horizontally.
8085
8086 widths : array-like, default: 0.5
8087 Either a scalar or a vector that sets the maximal width of
8088 each violin. The default is 0.5, which uses about half of the
8089 available horizontal space.
8090
8091 showmeans : bool, default: False
8092 If true, will toggle rendering of the means.
8093
8094 showextrema : bool, default: True
8095 If true, will toggle rendering of the extrema.
8096
8097 showmedians : bool, default: False
8098 If true, will toggle rendering of the medians.
8099
8100 Returns
8101 -------
8102 dict
8103 A dictionary mapping each component of the violinplot to a
8104 list of the corresponding collection instances created. The
8105 dictionary has the following keys:
8106
8107 - ``bodies``: A list of the `~.collections.PolyCollection`
8108 instances containing the filled area of each violin.
8109
8110 - ``cmeans``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
8111 the mean values of each of the violin's distribution.
8112
8113 - ``cmins``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
8114 the bottom of each violin's distribution.
8115
8116 - ``cmaxes``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
8117 the top of each violin's distribution.
8118
8119 - ``cbars``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
8120 the centers of each violin's distribution.
8121
8122 - ``cmedians``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that
8123 marks the median values of each of the violin's distribution.
8124
8125 - ``cquantiles``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance created
8126 to identify the quantiles values of each of the violin's
8127 distribution.
8128 """
8129
8130 # Statistical quantities to be plotted on the violins
8131 means = []
8132 mins = []
8133 maxes = []
8134 medians = []
8135 quantiles = []
8136
8137 qlens = [] # Number of quantiles in each dataset.
8138
8139 artists = {} # Collections to be returned
8140
8141 N = len(vpstats)
8142 datashape_message = ("List of violinplot statistics and `{0}` "
8143 "values must have the same length")
8144
8145 # Validate positions
8146 if positions is None:
8147 positions = range(1, N + 1)
8148 elif len(positions) != N:
8149 raise ValueError(datashape_message.format("positions"))
8150
8151 # Validate widths
8152 if np.isscalar(widths):
8153 widths = [widths] * N
8154 elif len(widths) != N:
8155 raise ValueError(datashape_message.format("widths"))
8156
8157 # Calculate ranges for statistics lines (shape (2, N)).
8158 line_ends = [[-0.25], [0.25]] * np.array(widths) + positions
8159
8160 # Colors.
8161 if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']:
8162 fillcolor = 'y'
8163 linecolor = 'r'
8164 else:
8165 fillcolor = linecolor = self._get_lines.get_next_color()
8166
8167 # Check whether we are rendering vertically or horizontally
8168 if vert:
8169 fill = self.fill_betweenx
8170 perp_lines = functools.partial(self.hlines, colors=linecolor)
8171 par_lines = functools.partial(self.vlines, colors=linecolor)
8172 else:
8173 fill = self.fill_between
8174 perp_lines = functools.partial(self.vlines, colors=linecolor)
8175 par_lines = functools.partial(self.hlines, colors=linecolor)
8176
8177 # Render violins
8178 bodies = []
8179 for stats, pos, width in zip(vpstats, positions, widths):
8180 # The 0.5 factor reflects the fact that we plot from v-p to v+p.
8181 vals = np.array(stats['vals'])
8182 vals = 0.5 * width * vals / vals.max()
8183 bodies += [fill(stats['coords'], -vals + pos, vals + pos,
8184 facecolor=fillcolor, alpha=0.3)]
8185 means.append(stats['mean'])
8186 mins.append(stats['min'])
8187 maxes.append(stats['max'])
8188 medians.append(stats['median'])
8189 q = stats.get('quantiles') # a list of floats, or None
8190 if q is None:
8191 q = []
8192 quantiles.extend(q)
8193 qlens.append(len(q))
8194 artists['bodies'] = bodies
8195
8196 if showmeans: # Render means
8197 artists['cmeans'] = perp_lines(means, *line_ends)
8198 if showextrema: # Render extrema
8199 artists['cmaxes'] = perp_lines(maxes, *line_ends)
8200 artists['cmins'] = perp_lines(mins, *line_ends)
8201 artists['cbars'] = par_lines(positions, mins, maxes)
8202 if showmedians: # Render medians
8203 artists['cmedians'] = perp_lines(medians, *line_ends)
8204 if quantiles: # Render quantiles: each width is repeated qlen times.
8205 artists['cquantiles'] = perp_lines(
8206 quantiles, *np.repeat(line_ends, qlens, axis=1))
8207
8208 return artists
8209

◆ violinplot()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.violinplot (   self,
  dataset,
  positions = None,
  vert = True,
  widths = 0.5,
  showmeans = False,
  showextrema = True,
  showmedians = False,
  quantiles = None,
  points = 100,
  bw_method = None 
) 
Make a violin plot.

Make a violin plot for each column of *dataset* or each vector in
sequence *dataset*.  Each filled area extends to represent the
entire data range, with optional lines at the mean, the median,
the minimum, the maximum, and user-specified quantiles.

Parameters
----------
dataset : Array or a sequence of vectors.
  The input data.

positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n]
  The positions of the violins. The ticks and limits are
  automatically set to match the positions.

vert : bool, default: True.
  If true, creates a vertical violin plot.
  Otherwise, creates a horizontal violin plot.

widths : array-like, default: 0.5
  Either a scalar or a vector that sets the maximal width of
  each violin. The default is 0.5, which uses about half of the
  available horizontal space.

showmeans : bool, default: False
  If `True`, will toggle rendering of the means.

showextrema : bool, default: True
  If `True`, will toggle rendering of the extrema.

showmedians : bool, default: False
  If `True`, will toggle rendering of the medians.

quantiles : array-like, default: None
  If not None, set a list of floats in interval [0, 1] for each violin,
  which stands for the quantiles that will be rendered for that
  violin.

points : int, default: 100
  Defines the number of points to evaluate each of the
  gaussian kernel density estimations at.

bw_method : str, scalar or callable, optional
  The method used to calculate the estimator bandwidth.  This can be
  'scott', 'silverman', a scalar constant or a callable.  If a
  scalar, this will be used directly as `kde.factor`.  If a
  callable, it should take a `matplotlib.mlab.GaussianKDE` instance as
  its only parameter and return a scalar. If None (default), 'scott'
  is used.

data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

Returns
-------
dict
  A dictionary mapping each component of the violinplot to a
  list of the corresponding collection instances created. The
  dictionary has the following keys:

  - ``bodies``: A list of the `~.collections.PolyCollection`
    instances containing the filled area of each violin.

  - ``cmeans``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
    the mean values of each of the violin's distribution.

  - ``cmins``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
    the bottom of each violin's distribution.

  - ``cmaxes``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
    the top of each violin's distribution.

  - ``cbars``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
    the centers of each violin's distribution.

  - ``cmedians``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that
    marks the median values of each of the violin's distribution.

  - ``cquantiles``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance created
    to identify the quantile values of each of the violin's
    distribution.
7941 quantiles=None, points=100, bw_method=None):
7942 """
7943 Make a violin plot.
7944
7945 Make a violin plot for each column of *dataset* or each vector in
7946 sequence *dataset*. Each filled area extends to represent the
7947 entire data range, with optional lines at the mean, the median,
7948 the minimum, the maximum, and user-specified quantiles.
7949
7950 Parameters
7951 ----------
7952 dataset : Array or a sequence of vectors.
7953 The input data.
7954
7955 positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n]
7956 The positions of the violins. The ticks and limits are
7957 automatically set to match the positions.
7958
7959 vert : bool, default: True.
7960 If true, creates a vertical violin plot.
7961 Otherwise, creates a horizontal violin plot.
7962
7963 widths : array-like, default: 0.5
7964 Either a scalar or a vector that sets the maximal width of
7965 each violin. The default is 0.5, which uses about half of the
7966 available horizontal space.
7967
7968 showmeans : bool, default: False
7969 If `True`, will toggle rendering of the means.
7970
7971 showextrema : bool, default: True
7972 If `True`, will toggle rendering of the extrema.
7973
7974 showmedians : bool, default: False
7975 If `True`, will toggle rendering of the medians.
7976
7977 quantiles : array-like, default: None
7978 If not None, set a list of floats in interval [0, 1] for each violin,
7979 which stands for the quantiles that will be rendered for that
7980 violin.
7981
7982 points : int, default: 100
7983 Defines the number of points to evaluate each of the
7984 gaussian kernel density estimations at.
7985
7986 bw_method : str, scalar or callable, optional
7987 The method used to calculate the estimator bandwidth. This can be
7988 'scott', 'silverman', a scalar constant or a callable. If a
7989 scalar, this will be used directly as `kde.factor`. If a
7990 callable, it should take a `matplotlib.mlab.GaussianKDE` instance as
7991 its only parameter and return a scalar. If None (default), 'scott'
7992 is used.
7993
7994 data : indexable object, optional
7995 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
7996
7997 Returns
7998 -------
7999 dict
8000 A dictionary mapping each component of the violinplot to a
8001 list of the corresponding collection instances created. The
8002 dictionary has the following keys:
8003
8004 - ``bodies``: A list of the `~.collections.PolyCollection`
8005 instances containing the filled area of each violin.
8006
8007 - ``cmeans``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
8008 the mean values of each of the violin's distribution.
8009
8010 - ``cmins``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
8011 the bottom of each violin's distribution.
8012
8013 - ``cmaxes``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
8014 the top of each violin's distribution.
8015
8016 - ``cbars``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks
8017 the centers of each violin's distribution.
8018
8019 - ``cmedians``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that
8020 marks the median values of each of the violin's distribution.
8021
8022 - ``cquantiles``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance created
8023 to identify the quantile values of each of the violin's
8024 distribution.
8025
8026 """
8027
8028 def _kde_method(X, coords):
8029 # Unpack in case of e.g. Pandas or xarray object
8030 X = cbook._unpack_to_numpy(X)
8031 # fallback gracefully if the vector contains only one value
8032 if np.all(X[0] == X):
8033 return (X[0] == coords).astype(float)
8034 kde = mlab.GaussianKDE(X, bw_method)
8035 return kde.evaluate(coords)
8036
8037 vpstats = cbook.violin_stats(dataset, _kde_method, points=points,
8038 quantiles=quantiles)
8039 return self.violin(vpstats, positions=positions, vert=vert,
8040 widths=widths, showmeans=showmeans,
8041 showextrema=showextrema, showmedians=showmedians)
8042

◆ vlines()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.vlines (   self,
  x,
  ymin,
  ymax,
  colors = None,
  linestyles = 'solid',
  label = '',
**  kwargs 
) 
Plot vertical lines at each *x* from *ymin* to *ymax*.

Parameters
----------
x : float or array-like
    x-indexes where to plot the lines.

ymin, ymax : float or array-like
    Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are
    provided, all lines will have the same length.

colors : list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color`

linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, optional

label : str, default: ''

Returns
-------
`~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection`

Other Parameters
----------------
data : indexable object, optional
    DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
**kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties.

See Also
--------
hlines : horizontal lines
axvline : vertical line across the Axes
1105 label='', **kwargs):
1106 """
1107 Plot vertical lines at each *x* from *ymin* to *ymax*.
1108
1109 Parameters
1110 ----------
1111 x : float or array-like
1112 x-indexes where to plot the lines.
1113
1114 ymin, ymax : float or array-like
1115 Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are
1116 provided, all lines will have the same length.
1117
1118 colors : list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color`
1119
1120 linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, optional
1121
1122 label : str, default: ''
1123
1124 Returns
1125 -------
1126 `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection`
1127
1128 Other Parameters
1129 ----------------
1130 data : indexable object, optional
1131 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
1132 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties.
1133
1134 See Also
1135 --------
1136 hlines : horizontal lines
1137 axvline : vertical line across the Axes
1138 """
1139
1140 # We do the conversion first since not all unitized data is uniform
1141 x, ymin, ymax = self._process_unit_info(
1142 [("x", x), ("y", ymin), ("y", ymax)], kwargs)
1143
1144 if not np.iterable(x):
1145 x = [x]
1146 if not np.iterable(ymin):
1147 ymin = [ymin]
1148 if not np.iterable(ymax):
1149 ymax = [ymax]
1150
1151 # Create and combine masked_arrays from input
1152 x, ymin, ymax = cbook._combine_masks(x, ymin, ymax)
1153 x = np.ravel(x)
1154 ymin = np.ravel(ymin)
1155 ymax = np.ravel(ymax)
1156
1157 masked_verts = np.ma.empty((len(x), 2, 2))
1158 masked_verts[:, 0, 0] = x
1159 masked_verts[:, 0, 1] = ymin
1160 masked_verts[:, 1, 0] = x
1161 masked_verts[:, 1, 1] = ymax
1162
1163 lines = mcoll.LineCollection(masked_verts, colors=colors,
1164 linestyles=linestyles, label=label)
1165 self.add_collection(lines, autolim=False)
1166 lines._internal_update(kwargs)
1167
1168 if len(x) > 0:
1169 # Extreme values of x/ymin/ymax. Using masked_verts here handles
1170 # the case of x being a masked *object* array (as can be generated
1171 # e.g. by errorbar()), which would make nanmin/nanmax stumble.
1172 minx = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 0])
1173 maxx = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 0])
1174 miny = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 1])
1175 maxy = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 1])
1176 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy)
1177 self.update_datalim(corners)
1178 self._request_autoscale_view()
1179
1180 return lines
1181

◆ xcorr()

matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes.xcorr (   self,
  x,
  y,
  normed = True,
  detrend = mlab.detrend_none,
  usevlines = True,
  maxlags = 10,
**  kwargs 
) 
    Plot the cross correlation between *x* and *y*.

    The correlation with lag k is defined as
    :math:`\sum_n x[n+k] \cdot y^*[n]`, where :math:`y^*` is the complex
    conjugate of :math:`y`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x, y : array-like of length n

    detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending)
        A detrending function applied to *x* and *y*.  It must have the
        signature ::

            detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray

    normed : bool, default: True
        If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length.

    usevlines : bool, default: True
        Determines the plot style.

        If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the xcorr value
        using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted
        at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`.

        If ``False``, markers are plotted at the xcorr values using
        `.Axes.plot`.

    maxlags : int, default: 10
        Number of lags to show. If None, will return all ``2 * len(x) - 1``
        lags.

    Returns
    -------
    lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
        The lag vector.
    c : array  (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
        The auto correlation vector.
    line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D`
        `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation:

        - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True.
        - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False.
    b : `.Line2D` or None
        Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True
        None *usevlines* is False.

    Other Parameters
    ----------------
    linestyle : `.Line2D` property, optional
        The linestyle for plotting the data points.
        Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.

    marker : str, default: 'o'
        The marker for plotting the data points.
        Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.

    data : indexable object, optional
        DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER

    **kwargs
        Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and
        `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are
        passed to `.Axes.plot`.

    Notes
    -----
    The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with
    ``mode = "full"``.
1974 usevlines=True, maxlags=10, **kwargs):
1975 r"""
1976 Plot the cross correlation between *x* and *y*.
1977
1978 The correlation with lag k is defined as
1979 :math:`\sum_n x[n+k] \cdot y^*[n]`, where :math:`y^*` is the complex
1980 conjugate of :math:`y`.
1981
1982 Parameters
1983 ----------
1984 x, y : array-like of length n
1985
1986 detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending)
1987 A detrending function applied to *x* and *y*. It must have the
1988 signature ::
1989
1990 detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray
1991
1992 normed : bool, default: True
1993 If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length.
1994
1995 usevlines : bool, default: True
1996 Determines the plot style.
1997
1998 If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the xcorr value
1999 using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted
2000 at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`.
2001
2002 If ``False``, markers are plotted at the xcorr values using
2003 `.Axes.plot`.
2004
2005 maxlags : int, default: 10
2006 Number of lags to show. If None, will return all ``2 * len(x) - 1``
2007 lags.
2008
2009 Returns
2010 -------
2011 lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
2012 The lag vector.
2013 c : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
2014 The auto correlation vector.
2015 line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D`
2016 `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation:
2017
2018 - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True.
2019 - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False.
2020 b : `.Line2D` or None
2021 Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True
2022 None *usevlines* is False.
2023
2024 Other Parameters
2025 ----------------
2026 linestyle : `.Line2D` property, optional
2027 The linestyle for plotting the data points.
2028 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.
2029
2030 marker : str, default: 'o'
2031 The marker for plotting the data points.
2032 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.
2033
2034 data : indexable object, optional
2035 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
2036
2037 **kwargs
2038 Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and
2039 `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are
2040 passed to `.Axes.plot`.
2041
2042 Notes
2043 -----
2044 The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with
2045 ``mode = "full"``.
2046 """
2047 Nx = len(x)
2048 if Nx != len(y):
2049 raise ValueError('x and y must be equal length')
2050
2051 x = detrend(np.asarray(x))
2052 y = detrend(np.asarray(y))
2053
2054 correls = np.correlate(x, y, mode="full")
2055
2056 if normed:
2057 correls /= np.sqrt(np.dot(x, x) * np.dot(y, y))
2058
2059 if maxlags is None:
2060 maxlags = Nx - 1
2061
2062 if maxlags >= Nx or maxlags < 1:
2063 raise ValueError('maxlags must be None or strictly '
2064 'positive < %d' % Nx)
2065
2066 lags = np.arange(-maxlags, maxlags + 1)
2067 correls = correls[Nx - 1 - maxlags:Nx + maxlags]
2068
2069 if usevlines:
2070 a = self.vlines(lags, [0], correls, **kwargs)
2071 # Make label empty so only vertical lines get a legend entry
2072 kwargs.pop('label', '')
2073 b = self.axhline(**kwargs)
2074 else:
2075 kwargs.setdefault('marker', 'o')
2076 kwargs.setdefault('linestyle', 'None')
2077 a, = self.plot(lags, correls, **kwargs)
2078 b = None
2079 return lags, correls, a, b
2080
